webTitle: Chelsea deny big risk on £7.8m Gronkjaer

fields.headline: Chelsea deny big risk on £7.8m Gronkjaer
fields.trailText: With the future of transfers hot on the agenda again, Chelsea yesterday threw caution to the wind and splashed out £7.8m on the Danish international winger Jesper Gronkjaer.
fields.body:
Chelsea denied they were taking a multi-million risk yesterday when they made the third biggest signing in their history in splashing £7.8m on the Danish international winger Jesper Gronkjaer.

On the day that the Fifa-Uefa task force handed the European Union its proposals over the future of transfers, Chelsea concluded their year-long pursuit of the brilliant Ajax player.

Many clubs have virtually stopped buying because they fear the EU could soon drastically reduce the value of player purchases.

Gronkjaer has a 4-year contract with the London club but will not arrive until January 1 in order to recover from a thigh strain. By then Chelsea may discover they have paid heavily over the odds for him.

But Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson said: "I believe there will be a compromise deal that transfers will be retained in some form, but we have pre-empted that by certain agreed clauses in his contract anyway."

Hutchinson would not elaborate on those clauses but they are believed to include loyalty payments.

He also defended the delay in Gronkjaer's arrival in England after finally succeeding with their third approach for the player. "Jesper has played virtually continuously for 16 months because of Euro 2000, with only one week's holiday in the summer, and the minor strain needs some rest."

Chelsea have been linked with a number of foreign wingers but Hutchinson said: "Jesper was always top of our list for the wide left position."

The Greenland-born player has blown hot and cold about moving, claiming only three days ago that he did not want to leave Amsterdam, despite his strained relationship with the Ajax coach Co Adriaanse.

But yesterday Gronkjaer insisted: "I never had any doubts about joining Chelsea. The Premiership was always my first option. I could have gone to Italy or Spain."

Joe Kinnear is set to return to management this week after talks with Oxford's chairman Firoz Kassam yesterday. He has been working as a consultant with the Third Division strugglers but Kassam said last night that he is "'optimistic" the former Wimbledon manager will soon step up to work alongside the current caretaker Mike Ford.

Plymouth have appointed the former Scottish international Paul Sturrock as manager. Sturrock, who recently resigned at Dundee United, replaces Kevin Hodges at Home Park.

Fifa is taking no action against the former Republic of Ireland striker Tony Cascarino after admitting he was "a freak Irishman," ineligible for the country.

"The whole incident looks like a so what? situation," said a Fifa spokesman. "It's a thing of the past now."

fields.headline: Eriksson signs five-year deal
fields.standfirst:
Lazio may yet release their coach before next July

Little England misses the big picture
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson yesterday signed a five-year contract to coach England from July, although there are signs that Lazio may release him before his current contract expires.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin and Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson yesterday signed a five-year contract to coach England from July, although the signs in Italy last night were that the Football Association could get its man far earlier.

Eriksson is due to succeed Kevin Keegan full-time after seeing out his contract at Lazio, with the FA "hopeful" of reaching an agreement with the Italian champions for the Swede to take charge in three World Cup qualifiers in March in June.

But one Lazio official said it was "probably wishful thinking" to expect Eriksson to stay until June 30, and there is strong speculation that the club's president Sergio Cragnotti will now not hesitate to dismiss the 52-year-old at the slightest slip in the Champions League or Serie A.

Cragnotti and Eriksson had a stormy 35-minute meeting yesterday, and the president is thought to feel angry and betrayed by Eriksson's behaviour, despite his public pronouncements that he under-stood his coach's decision and realised he needed "a new challenge and other stimulation".

Cragnotti has extracted a pledge from Eriksson to see out his contract but knows he has ready-made replacements in Dino Zoff, a former Lazio coach who returned to the club as vice-president after leading Italy to the Euro 2000 final, and Roberto Mancini, an up-and-coming member of Lazio's coaching staff.

Eriksson has told the FA he would like to take charge for the qualifiers on a part-time basis but Lazio seem less than happy at that prospect and may try to block the arrangement when discussions resume. "The FA did not ask if Sven-Goran Eriksson could do the England job part-time," Cragnotti claimed.

Questions will inevitably be asked at Lazio as to whether he can give the club his full attention, and club officials believe that if tension festers between Cragnotti and Eriksson it would preferable to let the Swede go, although a spokesman said last night: "Any speculation that Eriksson will leave before [July] is just unfounded rumour."

The FA would no doubt be delighted to have Eriksson's full attention in late March, when England play crucial qualifiers at home to Finland and away to Albania in the space of five days.

Its chief executive Adam Crozier said yesterday that Eriksson had been the unanimous choice of the seven-man selection panel. He believes the Swede can bring "a whole new dimension" to English football. "If we are all being honest we have to move on and take a leap forward," he said.

David Dein, the Arsenal vice-chairman who was on the selection panel, said of Eriksson: "He's got an extraordinary knowledge of world football and of dealing with the top players.

"He is used to players who are earning extraordinarily large sums of money, so he will not be fazed by the superstar element. He's always had attractive and successful teams. He's won major trophies in three countries.

"In many ways he reminds me of Arsène Wenger. He's erudite, a linguist. It's a different sort of management entirely, and it's a brave new world. England's stock is not on the increase at the moment. We're actually dropping in world rankings. We need to stop that decline."

Crozier said Eriksson accepted that England had underpeformed in recent years but was excited by the challenge and saw huge potential.

Eriksson will bring his assistant Tord Grip from Lazio but was, Crozier said, more than happy to work with the English coaches beneath him, such as Peter Taylor and Steve McClaren. "He thinks it is a terrific idea for the England team now and in the future," Crozier said.

Taylor, who will take charge for this month's friendly in Italy in which Eriksson will have no imput, had said he thought the new man should be English but last night insisted he was "very much looking forward to working alongside someone of his stature and ability".

David Beckham also sounded excited. "I know people wanted an English manager but he has got a lot of experience and he is a great manager," he said. "I think it will be a good thing. We have got many good players and they will become a good team [under Eriksson]."

But other reaction to the appointment was less welcoming. The FA fielded many calls yesterday complaining that the job has not gone to an Englishman, and many high-profile managers agreed.

Liverpool's Gérard Houllier said: "I still believe the job should be done by an English coach. But if the FA have decided on a different course of action, then of course that decision should be respected. Eriksson is a very good coach."

Wenger said: "I always said that England's first priority must be to get the man with the right experience and the right competence and, second, that he should be English. But if they couldn't find one in England then Eriksson is a good choice."

fields.headline: England strangers in spin paradise
fields.standfirst: It promises to be a tough series - with worse to come
fields.trailText: Never mind the spin so far - all of the world's leading twirly men are lined up to embarrass England, so the sooner they get used to it the better, writes Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
As England embark on the more meaningful leg of their Pakistan tour, with their opening first-class match starting here today, we already know the awful truth. If they draw the series, it will be an outstanding achievement. And if they win, it will be akin to a miracle.

The agenda has already been set. Turning pitches will be prepared for two of the world's outstanding practitioners, Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed, who will bowl against batsmen largely unapprenticed to this form of attack.

In fact the sooner England become accustomed to quality spin the better, because in the next 15 months they will encounter all of the world's leading twirly men.

Sri Lanka's Muttiah Muralitharan stands on the horizon, silhouetted like an avenger. In the summer Australia's Shane Warne will have to be overcome, followed by India's Anil Kumble at the end of the year.

More must be done to ensure that the next England side does not arrive blinking and bewildered like missionaries in some uncharted land. According to Aamir Sohail, Pakistan's thoughtful former captain, tours every 13 years, or every four for that matter, are just not enough.

"England must send their best cricketers here, not when they're 28 or 30 but when they're 18 or 20," he said. "The only way they will learn about the very different conditions here is to spend a winter or two playing domestic cricket.

"They have shown that they have difficulty surviving, let alone scoring runs, against good spinners on turning wickets. It is hardly surprising because they don't come here too often, or India and Sri Lanka for that matter."

England's bowling coach Bob Cottam, who has spent the past week working with England's Test specialists, said last night: "It's a totally different game plan out here. When do we play spin? When does Michael Vaughan play leg-spin? Only when he plays against Surrey, I suppose, and if he misses that game he doesn't play it for a year.

"Basically my job has been to get the lads ready for the first Test. I've asked them what they want: a leggie and two seamers, or a leggie, a slow left-armer and a seamer. Whatever. Vaughany knew immediately. 'Four spinners,' he said, and he got them.

"And the quality of the net bowlers, like the facilities, has been first class. There is one 18-year-old here who, if he was English, would have 18 counties fighting over him. It's been top-quality practice.

"I remember the big culture shock when I toured here in 1958-59, the winter we should have gone to South Africa. It was my first England tour.

"I soon discovered that it was a totally different way of life. The team spirit is important because you can't loose yourself in the evening like you can in other countries.

"You become public property. If you're having a meal people will come up to you for a photograph or an autograph. They're not being rude. In fact they are very courteous, though it can be overwhelming. But the cricket differences stand out just as much."

If England are to take on the rest of the world on even terms, however, it is necessary to take a hard look at their own domestic game.

A decade ago, flat pitches were produced and the seam on the ball was reduced. It produced some of the highest-scoring and most boring cricket seen in years. But in essence the move was a sound one.

The experiment should be repeated, if not identically. Flat pitches, without changing the ball, might be the answer. "The pitches are the key," Cottam said. "Bowlers must learn to bowl a slower ball, use the crease and all the other tricks that get wickets out here."

webTitle: England wait for full report after Stewart named in Indian match-fixing inquiry

fields.headline: England wait for full report after Stewart named in Indian match-fixing inquiry
fields.trailText: England are waiting on the publication today of an Indian police report into alleged match-rigging that will include the name of Alec Stewart.
fields.body:
The former England captain Alec Stewart will today be named in an Indian police report into alleged match-rigging.

The 162-page report, which was handed over to India's sports minister Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa this week, contains details of matches that were allegedly fixed and names five Indian and at least seven non-Indian players, including the former West Indies captain Brian Lara.

Dhindsa, when asked on Star News television to identify players named in the report, said: "Lara is also there, and Stewart, the English player. There are two or three [non-Indian] others, including Pakistani players."

The report, which was compiled by India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), is based on testimony gathered from a number of bookmakers who gave details of match-rigging and their involvement with players.

It is not clear what Stewart is actually accused of committing any offence or whether he is merely mentioned by bookmakers. According to one source, non-Indian players named in the report are accused of "indirect" involvement in match-rigging and "being offered money by Indian bookmakers and punters".

Stewart, who is touring with England in Pakistan, refused to comment but the fact that his name appears in the report will put Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, in a difficult position. MacLaurin has stated that "if someone is under suspicion he should be removed from the game until his case is heard and his innocence is proved".

A spokesman for the ECB said yesterday: "We will not be saying anything until we see the report."

The publication of the report comes as the former Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Paul Condon, who is in charge of the International Cricket Council's investigation into corruption, prepares to speak publicly today for the first time on the subject.

The report names the Indian Test players Mohammed Azharuddin, Ajay Jadeja, Nayan Mongia, Manoj Prabhakar and Ajay Sharma. The Indian team physiotherapist Ali Irani is accused of passing on information on matches and the squad to bookmakers. But the report finds that there is insufficient evidence against the former Indian captain and coach Kapil Dev.

Other non-Indian players named in the report are said to include the Australian batsman Mark Waugh, the former Pakistan captain Salim Malik and the former Australian Test batsman Dean Jones.

A copy of the report is to be sent to the South African inquiry into match-rigging and will also be made available to the ICC and cricket governing bodies around the world.

The CBI has admitted that it does not have enough evidence to prosecute any players and that its report is based entirely on interviews with bookmakers. But officials are examining the possibility of bringing charges against Azharuddin and Sharma under special legislation aimed at curbing corruption among civil servants. Both worked for government-run corporations while playing cricket.

The report paints a worrying picture of how bookmakers and betting syndicates have worked their way into cricket, particularly in India.

The report claims: "Evidence has disclosed that the betting syndicates have spread their tentacles across the length and breadth of the country and have assumed dimensions of a massive organised racket."

webTitle: A scheme to provide a qualification and a home to young people

fields.headline: Building a solid future
fields.standfirst: Other training courses have tried and failed, but  Sue Beenstock  finds a scheme that is giving a job, a qualification and a home to young people with problems
fields.trailText: Other training courses have tried and failed, but Sue Beenstock finds a scheme that is giving a job, a qualification and a home to young people with problems
fields.body:
The cheque is pinned on Karen Kaur's office notice board - proof, she says, that the scheme on which she is a support worker can have transforming effects. "Look, here's the first pay cheque of one of my boys. He photocopied it for me. Isn't it great?" All the scheme's participants are under 25; most have struggled with school, vanished from other training courses, are without a secure home and have, in some cases, drifted into crime.

Her small, freshly-painted office in Hackney, east London, and the cheque fluttering on the cork board are evidence, says Kaur, that the work of the Youth Build Trust (YBT) can help where other training courses have failed. "This isn't just training; it's a guaranteed job and, perhaps more importantly, a home - somewhere secure to live at the end."

It is the housing element of the YBT scheme, currently running at 11 sites in Britain, that makes it unique. Young people who are unemployed and in housing need are given the chance to train in construction, get National Vocational Qualification I and II, a job at the end of the course and the chance to live in the house they build, or to apply for alternative accommodation through the housing association where they are working.

"Here they're doing the work for real," says temporary training manager Dave Telfer. It's not like college where you have a go for five minutes on a test bench," Building accommodation for a YBT colleague or for the YBT itself - Kaur's office is being refurbished by her team - is an important part of the motivation for most participants.

There is also more support than you would expect on the average training course. Elaine McGlone is the support worker for the first YBT project in Scotland, which was started earlier this year in Paisley. "I used to be a nurse and then worked for Dr Barnardo's, but this really stretches me - I'm their advocate," she says. McGlone deals with court visits, probation officers and can help trainees find accommodation. "And I can just help and encourage when they get out of bed the wrong way and feel rubbish."

Most of the participants are no angels, she says. Many have been in trouble with the police and dodged school for years, but only by giving them intense support can she be sure that those who are capable will complete the course.

Twenty-year-old Joe Allan began skipping school at the age of 12. He says: "I've been on four training courses and always dropped out. I knew they were just six months out of the dole. But this was worthwhile from day one. I haven't missed a day's work. This is real work, not training."

For others, a criminal record has seemed an insuperable barrier to finding work. The guaranteed job at the end of the YBT course should help Darren Caldwell, 22, escape his criminal past. "Two years for car theft was the big one," he says. "I thought that was it. People don't want to give you a job with that on your book."

Caldwell believes that working alongside other construction workers and trainers in the scheme is helping raise his expectations and build confidence. "They treat you with respect. They're on £200 and I'm on £55 a week but they'll buy you a drink and treat you as an equal because we're helping them on the job."

The YBT was set up 10 years ago by Kenneth Claxton, an architect who reckoned that a link between self-build and social housing could solve two problems at once - lack of qualifications and homelessness in the very young. "Brighton council asked me: 'What's the youngest age that someone can build their own house?' I thought it was an interesting question - and it led to us establishing YBT."

So far, the trust has probably helped about 300 people, financed from a variety of sources including the Housing Corporation, the Department for Education and Employment, the YMCA and European Social Fund. But similar projects in Europe are soaring ahead of us, claims Claxton. "The Germans are beating us hollow. They've been running this sort of scheme for 20 years and doing brilliantly."

webTitle: SSI disappointed at lack of progress over independent living

fields.headline: The right to freedom
fields.standfirst: SSI disappointed at lack of progress over independent living
fields.trailText: SSI disappointed at lack of progress over independent living
fields.body:
Moves towards helping younger disabled people lead more independent lives are being hampered by ambivalence on the part of some social services staff, according to a new report. The government's social services inspectorate (SSI) is calling for improved training in disability awareness and disability rights to enable staff to do more to help clients achieve independence.

The inspectorate is voicing particular concern over the direct payments scheme, by which people with disabilities can be given cash to organise their own care packages. Just days after social services directors trumpeted the growing success of the scheme, the report says it is taking off too slowly. Although more and more councils are introducing direct payments, actual numbers taking them up remain low in many areas.

The new arrangements are aimed at giving disabled people increased choice and power through a more flexible service. But the report says "most councils and staff still have fully to absorb and carry through the independent living philosophy".

Denise Platt, SSI chief inspector, says: "It is clear that direct payments are a good way for many people to achieve a sense of control over their life. We must therefore do everything possible to promote these services and to make independent living a reality."

The report, New Directions for Independent Living, comes hard on the heels of figures from the Association of Directors of Social Services, suggesting that more than 3,600 disabled people aged 18-65 were receiving direct payments under the discretionary system introduced in 1997. Now, a team of SSI inspectors, which studied 10 local authorities in England, declares it is "disappointed at the limited progress" made by most of the sampled councils. In some cases, the team felt staff were ambivalent about the new scheme and had "not fully assimilated principles of independent liv ing into their practice".

One social worker told the inspectors: "I am very worried about direct payments - vulnerable people managing their own services." Another asked if it was right to "risk" such payments. Other staff were either unfamiliar with the legislation, or lacked knowledge of the specific local procedures for arranging direct payments in their area.

Sian Vasey, an officer at the National Centre for Independent Living, says people with disabilities need support to access direct payments. "It can be a bit of a hassle to sort out, but once you've set things up it means you can fine-tune the services to exactly what you want. I use the money to pay people to get me up in the morning and it's useful if you want to go away overnight as you can pay someone to go with you.

"The next battleground is going to be ensuring that the direct payments cash is enough to meet your needs. I know some people who can afford to fund a personal assistant to get them up, but then there's not enough cash to enable them to do anything or go anywhere for the rest of the day."

Marion Harrington, head of commissioning elderly and disabled services for Westminster council, says that to deal with the "hassle factor", her authority has brought in a voluntary organisation to sort out issues such as tax and national insurance for disabled people who effectively become employers if they use direct payments.

"Otherwise it would be a huge amount of work for social workers and care managers. It is compli cated, so clients have to be quite motivated to want to take it on," Harrington says. "We've found it's mainly those at the higher end of the needs spectrum who have done so. Among those who have found it particularly useful are people who want to employ carers who speak their language or understand their particular cultural needs."

The inspectorate is highlighting a lack of clear eligibility criteria for direct payments. It criticises some authorities for operating blanket exclusions of certain user groups, or limiting the scheme to just one group such as people living with Aids/HIV, instead of making decisions on an individual basis.

In the main, the inspection team found that individuals making use of direct payments were more satisfied than those receiving services arranged by the council. By recruiting and employing their own staff, clients reported having more flexibility, enjoying a more reliable service and feeling more in control. One user commented: "It's just turned everything around - it has given me self-respect."

In general, though, the SSI found that many individuals with disabilities were being offered services in a piecemeal and fragmented way "with few areas being able to demonstrate joined-up approaches at all levels and across all services". In the 10 inspected councils, support for people with physical disability lagged behind arrangements for individuals with learning disabilities.

In terms of good practice, the inspectors single out Calderdale, West Yorkshire, where social services has put together very intensive care packages to support some extremely dependent people in their own homes.

 New Directions for Independent Living - Inspection of Independent Living Arrangements for Younger Disabled People is available free from DH Publications, PO Box 777, London SE1 6XH

fields.headline: Controversial drug wins approval
fields.standfirst: More children to be treated for hyperactivity with Ritalin
fields.trailText: Thousands more children are expected to be prescribed controversial drugs to curb hyperactivity despite new controls on their use. Ritalin and Equasym will now effectively be banned for children up to the age of six under guidance issued yesterday by the government's main advisers on NHS use of medicines.
fields.byline: James Meikle, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
Thousands more children are expected to be prescribed controversial drugs to curb hyperactivity despite new controls on their use. Ritalin and Equasym will now effectively be banned for children up to the age of six under guidance issued yesterday by the government's main advisers on NHS use of medicines.

But the medication, given in tablet form, is likely to be made far more widely available after winning approval from the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice).

The two brands, based on the generic drug methylphenidate, are effective in treating severe attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), the institute has concluded. ADHD makes children impulsive, restless and inattentive, often causing them to fail at school and even leading to suspension or expulsion.

But there have been years of debate over both its safety and availability. Some families have complained that their children had been victims of the "postcode lottery" with the drug being widely prescribed in some parts of the country but not in others.

Parents have been divided over its use. Some believe their children have been transformed for the better by the drug, which is similar to amphetamines, while others think that it has exacerbated the disorder and children have become addicted to the drug.

Opponents claim it is often over-prescribed, sometimes to children as young as 18 months against the advice of the manufacturers and the terms of the product licences.

Nice believes the two brands are prescribed in about a third of severe ADHD cases in England and Wales, 25,000 out of 73,000. Fuller use could add £44m a year to the NHS bill through extra specialist assessment, cost of drugs and follow-up care.

Its guidance says that methylphenidate should only be used as part of a comprehensive treatment programme after diagnosis by a child psychiatrist or paediatrician with expertise in ADHD. This could lengthen waiting lists to see specialists as GPs are now unlikely to be prepared to authorise courses in the light of the guidance. Young people should be monitored and the drug should be withdrawn if their condition stabilised. Andrew Dillon, chief executive of Nice, said the guidance was based "on a very careful consideration of the evidence."

Gill Mead, of the ADHD family support group, said it was "pleasantly surprised by the good guidelines" and urged all schools to work with parents to get access to appropriate services, including the medication. But Janice Hill, of Overload, which is campaigning against Ritalin, said Nice "do not address any of the safety concerns about Ritalin."

Parents in the US are taking legal action against Novartis Pharmaceuticals, manufacturers of Ritalin, alleging the company failed to warn against possible side-effects and British lawyers are considering the possibility of similar action, having been approached by about 10 parents.

Novartis last night said Nice had "recognised the unequivocal evidence that shows Ritalin is safe and effective...allowing sufferers to improve their relationships both at home and school, and begin to realise their full potential. ADHD is a distressing and serious medical condition, caused by an imbalance of brain chemicals. If left untreated, severe ADHD can have devastating and long-term effects on sufferers and their families".

Nice has also backed the use of a new drug to treat hepatitis C, which many local authorities have seen as too expensive. It said doctors should use ribavarin, sold as Rebetol, when treating patients with moderate to severe form of liver disease, in combination with a far more commonly used drug interferon alpha. This could cost the NHS an extra £18m a year.

But both the Haemophilia Society, representing many haemophiliacs infected by hepatitis through contaminated blood products, and the campaign group C Change feared the recommendation would still be hit by rationing.

'It was like he was possessed'
Lee Millar has always been a handful. The baby who never slept for more than four hours at a stretch turned into a toddler who was too rough with other children and could not sit still. When playgroups and nurseries started complaining about his behaviour, his mother, Donna, sought professional help. Lee, then five, was diagnosed with ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) and prescribed Ritalin.

Within weeks, a difficult boy had become unmanageable.

"It was like he was possessed, like the Exorcist," said Donna, 36, from Edinburgh. "His older brother, Derek, suffered a terrible time. Lee would attack him for no apparent reason. Lee was cutting paper out on the floor and he turned round and stabbed Derek in the foot with the scissors and laughed. When I shouted at him he looked me straight in the eye and said: 'I don't care'. He was nothing. He was dead."

After six months, Donna stopped the drug.

"They told me at the beginning that it was non-addictive but the withdrawal symptoms were terrible," she said.

"He was flushed and sweating. His T-shirt would be wringing with sweat and he couldn't bear you touching him."

Lee, now seven, is still a handful, but Donna feels he has matured and much of the aggression has gone. She would like him to have some kind of behavioural therapy, but since she refused the Ritalin, she says the family has been ignored.

webTitle: NHS inquiry into pay gender gap

fields.headline: NHS inquiry into pay gender gap
fields.standfirst: Former regional director wins landmark case landmark victory
fields.trailText: Thousands of senior women managers in the NHS stand to benefit from an out of court settlement yesterday accepting that the former head of nursing in the south west region was unfairly paid less than male colleagues of similar rank and responsibilities.
fields.byline: John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
Thousands of senior women managers in the NHS stand to benefit from an out of court settlement yesterday accepting that the former head of nursing in the south west region was unfairly paid less than male colleagues of similar rank and responsibilities.

Margaret Buttigieg, regional director of nursing in Bristol from 1996 to 1999, received an undisclosed five figure sum in compensation after the NHS executive decided not to fight the case further.

As part of the settlement it also agreed to investigate procedures for fixing the salary levels of all its senior women managers to establish whether "there is an inbuilt discrepancy between the salaries of women and men".

The case arose after Ms Buttigieg discovered she was being paid £47,069 a year while male regional directors were getting between £62,981 and £76,307.

The NHS executive said the disparity resulted from a civil service job evaluation exercise, performance related pay increases and differences in experience and qualifications.

MSF, Ms Buttigieg's union, called in a job evaluation expert who disputed this defence and cast doubt on the thoroughness of job evaluation in the NHS.

Information unearthed during the case showed women directors across all regional offices were getting less than their male counterparts, even when the posts had the same job evaluation score.

Roger Kline, MSF's head of health, said: "This agreement drives a coach and horses through the current pay arrangements for all staff in regional offices of the NHS and has implications for women in middle ranking and senior positions throughout the civil service.

"We have demonstrated that current pay arrangements cannot withstand equal pay challenges. Thousands of women are likely to benefit from the pay review that will follow this landmark case."

Mr Kline said there was plenty of evidence that senior female staff were paid less than men with similar responsibilities. Those with a nursing background were paid less than men coming from the world of finance, human resources or general management.

Patrick Canavan, the regional officer who negotiated the agreement, said it would have huge repercussions for senior women civil servants outside the NHS, who worked under the same job evaluation scheme. Ms Buttigieg said: "I am delighted not just because an injustice is exposed, but because it will enable senior nurses and other women managers to get a fairer pay deal which recognises their skills."

The Department of Health said it was studying the implications of the case. A review of its civil servants' salaries to establish equal pay for work of equal value would report in June next year. The MSF and other trade unions would be invited to make representations, a spokeswoman said.

Ms Buttigieg, a former director of the Community Practitioners and Health Visitors Association, agreed the financial settlement on condition that the NHS executive issued a statement agreeing "to investigate how it determines salary levels of its senior women managers, and whether as a result of the methods used to determine such salaries there is an in-built discrepancy between the salaries of women compared to those of men".

Earlier this year MSF won £12m for female speech and language therapists in the NHS. The union represents 65,000 NHS workers including pharmacists, laboratory scientific staff, chaplains and clinical psychologists.

fields.headline: RIM titles in three-way split
fields.trailText: 6pm: All three bids for Regional Independent Media have been cleared by the competition authorities, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Regional Independent Media newspapers are to be shared among Gannett UK, Johnston Press and the Guardian Media Group.

The announcement comes just hours after the Secretary of State Stephen Byers gave clearance to the three bidders for Regional Independent Media.

In a gentlemanly arrangement struck by the three parties, Gannett will bid for all of the RIM titles, which include the Yorkshire Post, but will then sell on selected papers to its rivals.

"Preliminary discussions between the three publishers suggest that certain of the existing RIM titles represent a better commercial fit for each of them," the group said in a joint statement.

The decision comes just six months after Gannett beat Johnston and UK rival Trinity Mirror to the regional publisher Newscom.

Privately-owned RIM, valued at between £500m and £700m, is one of Britain's last independent regional newspaper groups. It publishes more than 100 titles, including the Yorkshire Evening Post, Sheffield Star and Lancashire Evening Post.

The Leeds-based group was created in 1998, when it bought the regional newspaper interests of United News & Media for £376m. Its major shareholders include the venture capital firm Candover, which holds a 50% stake.

Mr Byers, acting on advice from the Competition Commission, said the proposed sale of RIM's newspapers was not counter to the public interest.

fields.headline: Trio of new managers appointed
fields.trailText: It's been a day of managerial appointments in the Nationwide League, with new bosses unveiled at Huddersfield, Oxford and Barnet.
fields.body:
It's been a day of managerial appointments in the Nationwide League, with new bosses unveiled at Huddersfield, Oxford and Barnet.

Lou Macari is the new manager of Huddersfield. The former Celtic boss, who has been in temporary control of the Terriers since the dismissal of Steve Bruce last month, signed a two-year contract today.

The former Scottish international is joined by his erstwhile assistant Joe Jordan, who will work alongside first-team coach John Deehan, staying at the club despite the new regime.

Macari said: "It is a big challenge and one I am looking forward to. We are a three-man management team and Joe and John will not have official titles. We will share the workload."

Meanwhile, Oxford United have appointed David Kemp as their new boss and former Millwall manager Alan McLeary as his number two.

United, six points adrift at the bottom of the Second Division with only one win from 16 league matches this season, also announced that ex-Wimbledon manager Joe Kinnear will join as full-time director of football until the end of the campaign.

And Tony Cottee, whose contract with Norwich was terminated yesterday by mutual consent, has joined Barnet as player-manager.

John Still, the boss at Underhill for the past four seasons, has moved upstairs to become director of football and will work with Cottee for the immediate future. He has also taken a seat on the board.

Barnet chairman Tony Kleanthous said: "I am delighted John Still is joining the board and Tony Cottee has committed himself to a three-year contract with us.

"We would also like to thank Norwich for their co-operation in releasing Tony from his contract."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Policeman loses leg after bomb blast

fields.headline: Policeman loses leg after bomb blast
fields.trailText: A policeman seriously hurt in a bomb attack today by dissident republicans in Northern Ireland has lost a leg, sources said.
fields.body:
A policeman seriously hurt in a bomb attack today by dissident republicans in Northern Ireland has lost a leg, sources said.

The device was hidden in a traffic cone and exploded as he moved it out of the way of a gate at Castlewellan RUC station, Co Down, early this morning.

The injured officer is a full-time reservist in his 40s and married with children. He was taken to Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital where he underwent emergency surgery. A male colleague was treated for shock.

No one has claimed responsibility but the first minister, David Trimble, said local police chiefs recently warned about increased activity among dissident republican paramilitaries the Real IRA, which carried out the Omagh bombing.

"There was a warning from the local superintendent some weeks ago about Real IRA activity there," he said.

"It's a reminder to us that there is still a significant terrorist threat and consequently anything that is done with regard to changes in policing has to be looked at very carefully to make sure that the capability and effectiveness of the RUC is not in any way diminished."

Local politicians on all sides condemned the bombing. Nationalist SDLP MP Eddie McGrady said: "I'm greatly dismayed by this attack. I'm dreadfully concerned this is the commencement of future terrorist attacks, no doubt to destabilise the political situation."

South Down Ulster Unionist assemblyman Dermot Nesbitt said it was a despicable attempt to strike fear into the local community.

"If anything, this morning's events provide us with even more reason to address the issue of decommissioning," he said.

The RUC chief inspector William Dorman said: "This is a totally reckless, unwarranted attack, not only against my officers but the community as a whole.

"The officers had returned to the station for a short, well-earned break after an extremely busy Halloween night when the attack took place." Mr Trimble has banned Sinn Fein ministers from attending North/South council meetings in a bid to force the IRA to move on disarmament, but furious republicans said it would not work.

The health minister, Bairbre de Brun, of Sinn Fein, will decide today what to do over a planned meeting on food safety with her Dublin counterpart Michael Martin in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh, on Friday.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, and the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, have already had telephone talks on the fresh crisis which threatens to envelope the peace process.

The blast at Castlewellan Royal Ulster Constabulary station came just hours after two Protestants were shot dead in north Belfast in separate attacks linked to the loyalist feud.

Progressive Unionist worker Bertie Rice, 63, and 39-year-old former Ulster Democratic Party member Tommy English were both murdered in their homes yesterday.

The killings, just three days after the murder of Ulster Defence Association member David Greer, 21, mark the re-ignition of the bloody feud between two rival loyalist factions.

The bitter row between the Ulster Volunteer Force, politically represented by the PUP, and the Ulster Defence Association/Ulster Freedom Fighters, represented by the UDP, has already claimed three lives in the past few months.

UDP leader Gary McMichael today appealed for dialogue between the two sides. He said: "The UDA and UVF need to sit down and sort themselves out.

"There needs to be a truce formalised or it (violence) will inevitably appear somewhere else."

The feud erupted in the summer in the Shankill Road area, where more than 200 families have been driven from their homes in what appeared to be a territorial dispute.

But now, fresh arguments have broken out between individual paramilitaries in the north of the city. However, sources said Mr Rice and Mr English were "soft targets" without direct involvement in the dispute.

The violence has led to soldiers and extra police being placed back on the streets of north Belfast.

webTitle: Middle East talks promised, but killings continue

fields.headline: Middle East talks promised, but killings continue
fields.trailText: As Israelis and Palestinians today tried to arrange their first high-level, face-to-face talks in six weeks, violence continued on the West Bank with troops and gunmen from both parties exchanging heavy fire.
fields.body:
As Israelis and Palestinians today tried to arrange their first high-level, face-to-face talks in six weeks, violence continued on the West Bank with troops and gunmen from both parties exchanging heavy fire.

According to hospital officials, two Palestinians were killed and twelve wounded in a firefight in Al Khader, near Bethlethem, when Israeli helicopter gunships fired missiles at the village in retaliation for earlier losses. An Israeli security source said the helicopters were being used to evacuate the Israeli casualties. Abu Dhabi television reported that two Israelis had been killed and four wounded.

Three Palestinians, two of them aged 15 and 17, were also killed in clashes at the Karni crossing between Israel and the Gaza Strip, medical officials said, adding to the three Palestinians killed in the area yesterday.

The death toll in nearly five weeks of violence now stands at 159, not including the two Israeli soldiers whose deaths have not been confirmed by the army. Most were Palestinians or Israeli Arabs.

The Israeli army also reported firing shells at the Palestinian village of Beit Sahour, also near Bethlehem, in response to gunfire and retaliating to violence against the Jewish settlement of Gilo, near Jerusalem.

"It is possible we will decide that military steps taken so far have not been enough," warned Danny Yatom, a senior aide to the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak. "Today, there was a very negative jump in the scope and severity of events."

Meanwhile Shimon Peres, Israel's elder statesman, said he will hold talks with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat on Wednesday or Thursday to try to clear the air after 35 days of fighting.

Barak and Arafat both attended a US-sponsored Middle East summit in Egypt on October 17, but refused to meet face-to-face.

Peres, who as the architect of Israeli-Palestinian peacemaking has spent many hours negotiating with Arafat, said he did not have high expectations for his meeting with the Palestinian leader. He told Israel army radio: "I just think that, even when there is shooting, we need to talk."

Israel's top peace negotiator Gilead Sher will also participate in the meeting, expected to be held in Bethlehem.

Israeli foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami and Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat are due to meet separately this week with US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, as part of American efforts to end the fighting and renew the peace process.

Erekat said he will present a letter to Clinton with four Palestinian demands, including international protection and the establishment of an international inquiry commission into the violence.

Arafat met with German chancellor Gerhard Schröder in Gaza City today, saying he was grateful for the visit "at a time when we are subjected to military attacks." He said Germany had agreed to treat 50 wounded Palestinians, including several who are in serious condition.

The Palestinian leader asked for greater European involvement in peace talks. "We are looking for a German stance, a European stance to push the peace process forward, to protect the peace process," Arafat said in a joint news conference with Schröder. But Germany has declined any further involvement, limiting its role to financial aid.

In the Gaza Strip, more than 20,000 Palestinians joined a funeral for five of seven Palestinians killed in the past two days at the Karni crossing.

The crowd repeated slogans shouted over a loudspeaker mounted on the lead truck: "Goodbye, martyrs, we will meet in paradise. We will take revenge against the Israelis, and this will happen soon."

Israel's top peace negotiator Gilead Sher will also participate in the meeting, expected to be held in Bethlehem. Israeli foreign minister Shlomo Ben-Ami and Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat are due to meet separately this week with US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, as part of American efforts to end the fighting and renew the peace process. Erekat said he will present a letter to Clinton with four Palestinian demands, including international protection and the establishment of an international inquiry commission into the violence. Arafat met with German chancellor Gerhard Schröder in Gaza City today, saying he was grateful for the visit "at a time when we are subjected to military attacks." He said Germany had agreed to treat 50 wounded Palestinians, including several who are in serious condition. The Palestinian leader asked for greater European involvement in peace talks. The crowd repeated slogans shouted over a loudspeaker mounted on the lead truck: "Goodbye, martyrs, we will meet in paradise. We will take revenge against the Israelis, and this will happen soon." webTitle: Forget the hot air on family values and think positive

fields.headline: Forget the hot air on family values and think positive
fields.standfirst: I've received a leaked peek at the government's thinking on the family
fields.trailText: A plain brown envelope arrives. Inside is a draft of the government's next paper on "The Family", billed as part of Labour's armoury for the election. Some gun - more a voluminous paper bag of hot air, vacillating, banal and aimless. It displays yet again Labour's fatal need to be all things to all people, all the time. It trims to the moralisers while boasting of socially progressive policies. It bends to business, while expressing angst about over-worked parents - something to annoy everyone. Why never a clear principle?
fields.body:
A plain brown envelope arrives. Inside is a draft of the government's next paper on "The Family", billed as part of Labour's armoury for the election. Some gun - more a voluminous paper bag of hot air, vacillating, banal and aimless. It displays yet again Labour's fatal need to be all things to all people, all the time. It trims to the moralisers while boasting of socially progressive policies. It bends to business, while expressing angst about over-worked parents - something to annoy everyone. Why never a clear principle?

The committee designed to anchor the government's family values was seized by the strong male arm of the Home Office, instead of tucked under the protective wing of Health. But the "family" needed the smack of firm discipline, the aura of parenting orders. The paper's one redeeming feature is that it has plainly been tugged in two warring directions amid much disputation. It's easy to imagine Patricia Hewitt, Margaret Jay, Margaret Hodge, Patricia Hollis - women being the liberalisers in this government - tugging for sensible practical policies, while Jack Straw, Paul Boateng, Alan Howarth and the men demand tin-eared cheap moralising.

So this is the result: you wonder anyone can still write without irony: "The government believes the family is the basic building block of our society." Sententiously it proclaims that happy two-parent families are best - but tugging the other way, it adds, "However, we know that other family structures can also be successful." It ping-pongs on this, getting nowhere. Who is this for? It is the kind of empty talk that makes politics mocked, a foggy code in a game far from life as lived nightly in soap operas or on the sofas where real families watch them.

A confusing string of facts has been assembled, thrown in by the committee's two opposing sides. Absorb these: 72% of families are headed by married couples, only 12% by a cohabiting couple. (Many of these must be old.) Lone motherhood has trebled to 22% (panic?). Last year saw the fewest marriages ever recorded (40% of them are remarriages, do they count?). The government actuary predicts a doubling of cohabitation in 20 years. By 2011, 39% of men and 31% of women will never marry. Two warring sentences about one another: "Children brought up by two birth parents had higher levels of life satisfaction, fewer psychological problems." But this is immediately countered by: "Children brought up in re- structured families without care experience or early disadvantage did not differ significantly from those brought up by birth parents."

All this is just a way of saying the blindingly obvious: children with either one or two parents do fine in stable, loving surroundings. Children with fighting parents, children in care or brought up cripplingly poor are at higher risk. All that matters is how many more or fewer children are in danger of serious emotional or physical deprivation - whatever their families.

What is the magic that politicians pretend to see in the marriage certificate? It increasingly eludes the present generation of parents where 40% of babies are now born outside marriage, but mainly to cohabitees. The "building block" and "institution" looks hollow to them and weddings an embarrassing sham. Four out of 10 marriages end in divorce.

There is a whole chapter on domestic violence, reflecting the same figures Scotland Yard announced last week: two women a week killed, a violent attack reported every minute and unreported every six seconds. But the government's rosy picture of ideal marriage never links these two together. If one in four women is attacked by her partner, half of them repeatedly in front of their children, isn't escape and bringing up children alone a better choice for that 25% of "families"? Single motherhood is often a cause to celebrate, an escape forbidden in the bad old days.

"We are not telling people how to live their lives, and even if we wanted to, we couldn't make it happen," says the paper, but its tone says otherwise. Jack Straw would like to tell people how to live their lives, though he has no more sticks and whips to crack families into line than did the back-to-basics Tories. William Hague's puny whip is to restore the £285 a year married couples allowance, as if that will get wicked cohabitees galloping up the aisle. What can Labour offer? This paper says that the (divorced) lord chancellor and the (divorced) Jack Straw are jointly producing a marriage information pack to give couples considering marriage.

Here's the reality check. Chapter 3: What Families Want. Real families said it was after-school clubs, parks, streets closed to traffic and, above all, childcare. No one asked government for help with their marriage. Many specifically said they wanted no interference "forced on the majority of caring, competent parents". There is no electoral mileage in marriage. Nor will it fool the Daily Mail. They'll make mincemeat of this. Where's the beef, they'll ask? Where's the marriage-promoting policy? The Mail might enjoy a note under a blank section called Divorce and Relationship Breakdown, reading: "Lord chancellor's department are unable to give any indication of what new initiatives may be taken forward in the area of divorce and relationship breakdown. Hopefully be in a position to provide some input in this area". The answer, mercifully, is that there are no new initiatives in this area after the welcome abandonment of the impossible Tory divorce law reform.

One section reveals how weak Labour is with employers on work/life balance, which strikes at the real heart of family life. Fathers with children aged under 11 work an average of 48 hours; a quarter work 50 hours. Mothers say they want flexi-time and term-time working, but Labour has left it to a voluntary campaign to persuade employers: no word of legislation here.

Unless the ministerial group rewrites this paper, any brouhaha it attracts will focus on this marriage nonsense. The great bulk of the document will pass unnoticed - a shame since it contains a long list of all the good Labour is doing for children. More than a million have been lifted out of poverty, benefits are better, schools are improving, a national childcare strategy begins, with a host of unsung programmes that really might rescue children from failure.

To promote these, why not call this paper "Our Nation's Children" or some such? Leave marriage, cohabiting and single parents alone. Be bold in mocking politicians who preach to empty pulpits. Make a virtue of high-spending practical policy over Tory sermonising that thinly camouflages their planned cuts in all such children's projects. It would be good to hear this draft was ditched long ago: of course no family values nonsense will mar the group's new paper on children.

webTitle: Space station crew near new home

fields.headline: Space station crew near new home
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The first residents of the international space station drew closer to their new home with each orbit of Earth on Wednesday and got a surprise call from Russian Mission Control.
fields.body:
The first residents of the international space station drew closer to their new home with each orbit of Earth on Wednesday and got a surprise call from Russian Mission Control.

US astronaut Bill Shepherd, the station's skipper, didn't recognise the female voice speaking to him, almost exactly 24 hours into his flight aboard a Russian Soyuz capsule.

"Shepster, do you know who you're talking to?" the woman asked from the control centre outside Moscow. He named someone, but the woman said no, that it was his wife - Beth Stringham-Shepherd.

She's his strength and conditioning coach, and will monitor his exercise following his arrival at the space station on Thursday. Shepherd's stunned reaction: "Whoa!"

After some chat about the astronaut's treadmill and cycling exercises aboard the space station, Stringham-Shepherd told her husband it was great to hear his voice. She also told him his heart rate was a respectable 109 beats per minute at liftoff.

"Love you, honey," the astronaut called out.

"I love you, too," she replied and then said hello to her husband's crewmates, Russian cosmonauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev. "You guys looked awesome," she said.

The crew also received a boost on Wednesday from Russian President Vladimir Putin.

"It's up to you, the first permanent crew on the international space station, to open a new chapter in the history of international space exploration: to make habitable the orbital 'house' that has been created through the labour of specialists from various countries," Putin said in a telegram.

He called the ISS a "clear and convincing example of mutually beneficial cooperation, which is capable of uniting people of different nationalities for solving key tasks in scientific progress."

One day into their planned 115-day mission, Shepherd, Gidzenko and Krikalev were 11,000 miles from the space station and closing the gap by 700 miles with every passing orbit. Docking is scheduled for 9.24am Thursday.

The crew reported everything was going well aboard the Soyuz, a three-man capsule similar in size to the US space agency's Gemini spacecraft that carried just two astronauts at a time in the mid-1960s.

"We're having a pretty good day in orbit. We're getting a lot done," Shepherd told flight controllers. "Sergei and Yuri are doing a great job as everybody told me, and we're looking forward to a good docking tomorrow."

This will be the first time a Soyuz capsule docks with the international space station, parts of which have been flying for two years.

Space shuttles have made five trips to carry up supplies and new components, the latest one in October. And an unmanned Russian cargo ship, called Progress, has linked up just once.

That Progress ship undocked Wednesday to make room for the Soyuz arrival, and plunged through the atmosphere 3 1/2 hours later over the South Pacific. Shuttle astronauts had unloaded all its contents and stuffed it with packing material and trash.

Once docked, the Soyuz will remain attached to the space station and serve as the crew's emergency escape vehicle in case of depressurisation, fire or some other accident or medical crisis. It will be replaced every six months by a new capsule.

The crew already have their work cut out for them. Their first job will be to turn on all the life-support systems; also at the top of their to-do list is activating the space station's toilet. On Friday, Krikalev will start working on a couple of bad batteries in the Zvezda living quarters, and his colleagues will try to organise the place to their liking.

All the activities will be monitored by Russian Mission Control as well as by Nasa's Mission Control in Houston. Houston will take over control from Moscow once the American lab Destiny arrives in January with critical computer systems.

The three men will call the space station home for four months, or until the end of February, when another three-person crew will take their place.

webTitle: Dracula's coming home - and other true stories

fields.headline: Dracula's coming home - and other true stories
fields.standfirst: Tales you may have missed from Britain's regional papers
fields.trailText: Tales you may have missed from Britain's regional papers
fields.body:
Village welcomes 'vampire'
The residents of a North Yorkshire town are stocking up on garlic and crucifixes after a real-life Dracula announced plans to move to the small seaside village where his literary ancestor arrived in a wooden coffin in Bram Stoker's classic novel.

Vlad Dracula Prince Kretzulesco - the last living member of the clan - is considering settling in Whitby.

He currently lives in Castle Dracula, in east Germany. But Mr Dracula indicated he would be delighted to up sticks to England and possibly return to the town where the bloodcurdling legend began.

He said: "To visit the place where Mr Stoker wrote the book would be wonderful. I know a little of Whitby and my family's connection with the town and if I were welcome, maybe I could go there and look for a place to live."

Mr Dracula, 60, an antique dealer, is anxious to leave Germany after numerous arson attacks and death threats from neo-Nazis.

He said: "The British are good to foreigners and have liberal attitudes - no matter if you are black, green or lilac. If anyone offered me their castle I would jump at the opportunity."

Craig Collier-Huckins from Whitby's Dracula Society said: "It would be wonderful to have him here and we would welcome him with open arms."
Yorkshire Evening Post

Reptile's return
"I jumped out of my skin," said a Wolverhampton pet shop owner after receiving an unscheduled delivery last week. "I couldn't believe what I was seeing."

Jimmy Wick, boss of Cabin Aquatics and Livestock, in Wolverhampton, was about to open his store when he noticed a duffle bag hanging from a padlock on the front door. As he opened it, he came nose-to-nose with a 2ft crocodile.

The three-year-old West African dwarf crocodile was taken from Dudley Zoo last month. Experts at the zoo are now trying to resuscitate the reptile and ensure it survives its ordeal.

Mr Wick added: "I had read about the stolen crocodile and thought this was the same one. The bag was open and it could have climbed out - but it was so cold it was comatose.

"It could have died if it had been left there any longer and I'm glad it's back with someone who can look after it properly."
Wolverhampton Express and Star

Cuppa crisis
Everyone likes a nice cup of tea. And although you might expect a computer software firm to be at the forefront of new technology, a hot drinks machine proved an automation too far.

Retired tea lady Ellen Howland was lured back to work because the boss of a High Wycombe company hated his vended office drinks so much.

Ellen, 81, had long hung up her pinny and was astonished when Peter Kelly begged her to come and sort out his tea trauma.

Mr Kelly decided his staff deserved better and now Ellen is plying employees at the company with tea and toast twice a day.

Mr Kelly said: "I refuse to have vending machines because you cannot get a decent cup of tea or coffee out of them. We are a computer software company  but we insist on having a traditional tea lady."

Ms Howland said: "There's no way that vending machines serve good tea or coffee, so I make the tea and toast. I love it. I like to be working and being with other people."
Bucks Free Press

Letter of the week
My favourite memories of the ABC [which has closed in Tunbridge Wells] occurred when the cinema became a theatre for a charity concert in aid of the Kent and Sussex Hospital.

Among the artistes were Wee Georgey Wood and Richard Hearn (later Mr Pastry).

Wee Georgey Wood found that he was not placed at the top of the bill. This infuriated him so much that he locked himself in the toilet, refusing to perform.

After much talking with managers and agents, agreement was made. I was the official accompanist for the show playing with the Old Barn dance band and performing a piano fantasier on the theme of Smoke Gets in Your Eyes.

The concert proved a great success, made much money and everybody went home happy and satisfied.
Frances Eling, St James Park, Tunbridge Wells
Kent and Sussex Courier

fields.headline: Bishops learn about racism
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury and other senior Church of England figures are to take a 24 hour racism awareness course as part of a drive to eliminate discrimination against black people in the church.
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Canterbury and other senior Church of England figures are to take a 24 hour racism awareness course as part of a drive to eliminate discrimination against black people in the church.

George Carey, together with the Archbishop of York, David Hope, and members of the archbishops' council will attend the course following acceptance of charges of institutional racism in the wake of the Macpherson report on the murder of Stephen Lawrence.

A report to the church's general synod calls for repentance and says black people in the pews feel "few, marginalised and poorly treated".

Philip Mawer, secretary general to the synod and archbishops' council, has already attended the Methodist-run course in Sheffield. He said: "The Church of England sinned in the 1950s when people came over from the Caribbean and were not welcomed [and] as a result many black people turned from the church."

The report argues that minority communities remain under-represented on local synods and in the clergy: 1% in the dioceses of Blackburn and Liverpool and 7% in Southwark.

All 550 staff at Church House, administrative headquarters of the church, are also being sent on equal opportunities courses.

The report argues that minority communities remain under-represented on local synods and in the clergy: 1% in the dioceses of Blackburn and Liverpool and 7% in Southwark. All 550 staff at Church House, administrative headquarters of the church, are also being sent on equal opportunities courses.

fields.headline: 'Blatant' racism at Brixton jail
fields.standfirst: Prison service report finds black inmates told to 'go back to Africa'
fields.trailText: Prison service report finds black inmates told to 'go back to Africa'
fields.body:
Staff at Brixton prison harassed and bullied colleagues and inmates in a "blatantly" and institutionally racist regime, a report commissioned by the prison service claims.

It blames management for failing to tackle the problem and makes more than 80 recommendations for change.

But the service's director general, Martin Narey, last night admitted that the south London jail's poor record was not unique.

The commission for racial equality is now likely to launch its own investigation into race relations at Brixton, which were severely criticised by the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, last year. He called its performance standards intolerable and announced plans to privatise it.

Its turbulent progress continued when Bob Chapman was replaced as governor by Stephen Twinn in July, two weeks after the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, condemned its healthcare.

Yesterday's report found that a small number of officers "sustained and promoted racist behaviour", with ethnic minority staff complaining that they had been let down by their white peers and managers.

Prisoners from ethnic minorities alleged that they had been assaulted and refused special dietary needs, and said white staff had "told them to go back to Africa".

They also reported incidents of racial stereotyping, which prison officers dismissed as "banter".

In many cases prisoners - the vast majority of them black - were locked in their cells for hours without authority. The practice was stopped immediately it was discovered and is now under internal investigation.

Most damningly, the report found that prison heads failed to tackle race discrimination. "At the highest levels _ it was plain that racial issues were not given appropriate priority," it said.

Mr Narey, who launched the investigation in May, said yesterday that many of the recommendations had already been implemented. The CRE is now considering the report.

"I have already acknowledged that the service is not only institutionally racist, but that pockets of blatant racism still exist," he said. "Brixton may be a bad example, but it is not alone. But I am determined that, working closely with the CRE, we can eradicate all racism, both at institutional and individual levels."

Brixton's records included six racially based complaints in the past two years. In one case, Claude Johnson, a black prison officer, experienced continued harassment after winning damages for race dis crimination. In another, a junior governor, Ian Davis, joked that his colleague, Dee Douglas, was able to understand the bongo drums. His only punishment was to be sent on a one day race relations course.

Staff also complained sexual discrimination was common; an officer assaulted a junior governor after refusing to carry out her instructions.

Mark Healey, chairman of the Prison Officers' Association, said he did not believe that Brixton was a "hotbed" of racism."The problem is the same as anywhere else, but people are more aware of it because of the environment," he said.

The full report has not been published because of allegations against named prison officers, who could face disciplinary charges.

webTitle: Rugby league club found guilty of racism

fields.headline: Rugby league race ruling
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A leading rugby league club was found guilty of racial discrimination yesterday by an employment tribunal, which also criticised the attitude of its chief coach.
fields.body:
A leading rugby league club was found guilty of racial discrimination yesterday by an employment tribunal, which also criticised the attitude of its chief coach.

Leeds Rhinos failed to act promptly and efficiently when Paul Sterling, an international winger, aired repeated grievances, the tribunal ruled after two weeks of hearing evidence in Leeds. The Rhinos' Australian coach, Dean Lance, was found to have discriminated "unconsciously" against Sterling, whose efforts to get back into the team after three previous, successful seasons were blocked for months.

Lance was censured for an "ill-considered" comment to Sterling that he would not be selected for the first team "irrespective of performance".

The tribunal rejected the most serious criticisms by Sterling, however, ruling that the player's belief that Lance operated a policy of "ethnically cleansing" the side had no evidence to support it. The written judgment described Lance as "professional and honourable" and said that the Rhinos should not lay disproportionate blame at his door.

Lance, a relative newcomer to Leeds, is expected to serve the remaining two years of his contract. Sterling is at present on international duty for the rugby league World Cup.

webTitle: Cantona set for return to Marseille

fields.headline: Cantona set for return to Marseille
fields.trailText: Eric Cantona could be about to return to football as sports manager with his hometown club of Marseille, according to newspaper reports in France.
fields.body:
Eric Cantona could be about to return to football as sports manager with his hometown club of Marseille, according to newspaper reports in France.

Today's Le Parisien states that Cantona was offered the position on Monday. The role would make the former Manchester United striker responsible for all sporting matters, with sport manager Marcel Dib and club chairman Eric Di Meco removed from their posts . Brazilian Abel Braga would remain as coach of the club however.

According to Le Parisien, Cantona is very interested in the position, but wants precise guarantees that he will be able to have a say in team affairs, and also have enough money to bring in new players during the winter break.

Olympique Marseille have declined to comment on the report, which is the latest rumour to surround the troubled club. At present they lie in 15th place in the French first division, just one point above the relegation zone.
