fields.headline: Stop the press
fields.standfirst: TV's Crossroads helped printer Peter Leedale find a new direction in life.  Helene Mulholland  reports
fields.trailText: Profile: TV's Crossroads helped printer Peter Leedale find a new direction in life. Helene Mulholland reports
fields.body:
Peter Leedale is living proof that you're never too old. After a lifetime in the printing trade, this grandfather of three has gone back to studying. "I don't think age is important," he says. "It's all totally relative."

Which is why he has enrolled as a student mental health nurse at Luton university. Currently in his first year, he will be 58 when he qualifies. "I've found something I am good at," he says with feeling.

At a time when the health sector is crying out for more trained staff - the Department of Health is said to estimate the shortfall in mental health nurses in England as being close to 3,000 - his decision to join the nursing profession is timely; his commitment, absolute.

Leedale, from Milton Keynes, recalls how he grew up with not even a spark of ambition, leaving grammar school with no qualifications. His father soon got him into the printing trade, where Leedale stayed until a couple of years ago. It was in the twilight years of his printing career that he first discovered his vocation.

The son of a pharmacist, with a sister also in nursing, Leedale says he had always been interested in health- care and first aid. When he found out about Crossroads, a respite charity set up in the 80s by the old ITV flagship soap in memory of one of its leading actors, he began moonlighting. "I had friends who had serious disabilities," says Leedale, who also has a granddaughter with cerebal palsy. "When you know somebody like that in the community, you meet others with similar disabilities.

"I knew Crossroads helped them and I got interested in that type of care. The sort of shift I had in the printing industry meant I had plenty of time to fit in other things."

When redundancy finally loomed, Leedale decided to sever links with printing for good and got a job as a healthcare assistant with the British Nursing Agency, working in a variety of settings. Soon, he began to feel frustrated. "I wanted to know why I was doing what I was doing. Also, you see things that are wrong and you think you can do better but you can't comment unless you do it from a position of knowledge and strength." So with the support of colleagues and clients alike, Leedale decided to become a nurse.

Having no qualifications was the first hurdle. Leedale found he could sit an academic aptitude test set by the UK Central Council, the regulatory body for nursing. He passed. With that under his belt, he was eligible to apply to nursing colleges, and was warmly accepted at Luton.

"My sister was thrilled to bits, but amazed, because of my age. To me it's a natural progression, but a lot of people are surprised." Although there are only five students in his year training to be mental health nurses, the first 18 months of study is a common foundation course shared with 39 other students who have opted for a career in general nursing. Leedale's training base is at Stoke Mandeville hospital, Buckinghamshire.

While he claims that the academic demands test him to the limit, the fledgling student's grades suggest that he is more than coping with study, despite a 40-year gap. The biggest and less surmountable stressor is financial. "They ask why people drop out of courses," he exclaims. "A lot of it has got to be the financial pressure."

As a mature student on a diploma course, Leedale receives a higher than usual bursary, but it is still far from ideal.

His partner, Ann, is working longer hours to make up the difference. "I would like to have more cash, for Ann not to work such long hours, for us not to worry about money so much. But I have no doubts about what I am doing."

His younger counterparts, however, are not so sure. "Some colleagues on my course are very focused, but others, now they are on the course, say: 'I don't know whether I really want to do this'."

One obvious benefit Leedale brings to his training, is his ability to speak up. "A lot of the others find they're being pushed around and ignored," he says.

"Perhaps because I'm that bit older, people are not inclined to do that to me so much." But like his colleagues, he finds that the encouraged practice of learning by observation does not happen as often as it should. "Often you are used as part of the team, and are not being trained. You do the job that everyone would, in order to free up the trained staff for the more specialist roles."

Leedale insists that he has no problem with taking instructions from his youngers. All he is interested in is becoming a fully qualified nurse. His immediate aim, on doing so, is to work on an acute mental health ward. "I'm looking at it as a means of gaining good experience before I specialise. My aim is to increase my grades through practice and hopefully end up working in the community. Whether I achieve that, depends on what happens in mental health in the meantime."

With official retirement only nine years away, Leedale remains sanguine. If health trusts don't keep him on after 65, he will go back to work for nursing agencies, which are less stringent about age limits.

His advice to anybody else contemplating a budding career in the twilight years is this: "Go for what you want, because throughout life you can miss a lot of opportunities which will never come around again. I know there are a lot of constraints, but if you sit down and set about things, there are often ways around them."

For now, Leedale's biggest challenge is placating his younger daughter, who is about to get married. "She's not impressed because on her marriage certificate she has to put her father's profession," he says. "She doesn't want to put 'student'."

fields.headline: Burning desire
fields.standfirst: Those Bonfire Boyes are going to blazes
fields.trailText: Those Bonfire Boyes are going to blazes
fields.body:
All over the sedate county of Sussex, torch-wielding mobs are about to burst on to the streets. Men and women with blackened faces will drag burning barrels. Effigies will be burnt to the sound of beating drums. The mob's mission is to reclaim bonfire night.

Bonfire Societies, peculiar to the south-east of England, are experiencing a huge resurgence in interest. Pagans believe that the lighting of bonfires and the burning of effigies are ritualised sacrifices, Protestants celebrate the defeat of a Catholic plot, while some Catholics commemorate the loss of Guy Fawkes, the freedom fighter. Anarchists use the day to have a go at anybody in authority, while hedonists see it as a damn good excuse for a party.

However you see it, the day on which parliament and the monarchy were almost destroyed, has become one of the greatest focuses in Sussex for anti-authoritarian community activity. The bonfire season, from August to the end of November involves about 30 societies travelling to compete with each other and raise money for local causes.

In Hastings, the bonfire society was revived six years ago after a 40-year absence. Every year, crowds in excess of 20,000 people join and watch the procession and the burning of effigies on the beach. The town is closed to traffic as the Bonfire Boyes march, drum and burn their way through the town.

On their way to the bonfire site they make sure to pass through "America ground", an area of land where rebellious fishermen once made a unilateral declaration of independence, long before eco-warriors did at Wanstead or Glasgow.

This year, under the full moon on October 14, the Bonfire Boyes of Hastings burned a giant effigy depicting policemen arresting revellers. The effigy was in protest at recently enforced bylaws prohibiting drinking alcohol in the street. The politics are always populist, ranging across the political spectrum. Squint and the scene resembles a witch-hunt or a scene from King Kong.

Thatcher was a popular effigy in the 80s, French president Jacques Chirac was burned in 1992 for his decision to resume nuclear testing in the Pacific. The Teletubbies, Saddam Hussein, Tony Blair and French farmers have been flattered by the flames.

The festivities have rarely been popular with political elite. Keith Leech, chairman of Hastings Bonfire Society, says: "Popular activities which could lead to rioting and a consequent fall from power by the ruling classes were repressed. Guy Fawkes Night celebrations were targeted because they were rowdy, drunken, disorganised gatherings of people with fire, torches and gunpowder, fuelled by a popular patriotic feeling. The potential for political riot was high."

Between 1830 and 1850, militias and newly-formed police forces were used to suppress and curtail the festivities, giving rise to the sanitised and commercialised bonfire parties now held across much of Britain. In Lewes, the self-proclaimed "home of bonfire," violent clashes between bonfire mobs and the police occurred regularly between 1838 and 1847.

As a result, the Bonfire Boyes started the Bonfire Societies to co-ordinate an organised movement. Each society adopted uniforms that disguised their identities and deliberately irritated the authorities. Black-faced smugglers, Indians and harlots still drag flaming barrels through the streets of Lewes just as they did hundreds of years ago.

Over time the spirit has changed, anti-Catholic feeling has been replaced by a non-sectarian air of competitiveness between the visiting societies. Nowadays, the aim is raise money for charity and poke fun at any authoritarian figure considered an "Enemy of Bonfire".

In Hastings, the bonfire society was revived six years ago after a 40-year absence. Every year, crowds in excess of 20,000 people join and watch the procession and the burning of effigies on the beach. The town is closed to traffic as the Bonfire Boyes march, drum and burn their way through the town. On their way to the bonfire site they make sure to pass through "America ground", an area of land where rebellious fishermen once made a unilateral declaration of independence, long before eco-warriors did at Wanstead or Glasgow. This year, under the full moon on October 14, the Bonfire Boyes of Hastings burned a giant effigy depicting policemen arresting revellers. The effigy was in protest at recently enforced bylaws prohibiting drinking alcohol in the street. The politics are always populist, ranging across the political spectrum. Squint and the scene resembles a witch-hunt or a scene from King Kong. Thatcher was a popular effigy in the 80s, French president Jacques Chirac was burned in 1992 for his decision to resume nuclear testing in the Pacific. The Teletubbies, Saddam Hussein, Tony Blair and French farmers have been flattered by the flames. The festivities have rarely been popular with political elite. Keith Leech, chairman of Hastings Bonfire Society, says: "Popular activities which could lead to rioting and a consequent fall from power by the ruling classes were repressed. Guy Fawkes Night celebrations were targeted because they were rowdy, drunken, disorganised gatherings of people with fire, torches and gunpowder, fuelled by a popular patriotic feeling. The potential for political riot was high." Between 1830 and 1850, militias and newly-formed police forces were used to suppress and curtail the festivities, giving rise to the sanitised and commercialised bonfire parties now held across much of Britain. In Lewes, the self-proclaimed "home of bonfire," violent clashes between bonfire mobs and the police occurred regularly between 1838 and 1847. As a result, the Bonfire Boyes started the Bonfire Societies to co-ordinate an organised movement. Each society adopted uniforms that disguised their identities and deliberately irritated the authorities. Black-faced smugglers, Indians and harlots still drag flaming barrels through the streets of Lewes just as they did hundreds of years ago. Over time the spirit has changed, anti-Catholic feeling has been replaced by a non-sectarian air of competitiveness between the visiting societies. Nowadays, the aim is raise money for charity and poke fun at any authoritarian figure considered an "Enemy of Bonfire".

Direct donation

Sniffer dog

Burglars who broke into a house in Essex thought they were snorting cocaine after finding a bag of powder, but it was the ashes of the owner's dead dog.

Booty bonus

A woman from Portslade, Sussex, got her car back after it had been stolen, and found that the boot was full of melons.

Mixed luck

Free cheers

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: We need a new policy
fields.body:
We need a new policy

You report that the Youth Justice Board plans to "name and shame" magistrates who sentence more children and young people to custody than the national average (Custody figures too high, October 25). This is an inadequate response to the fact that Britain now imprisons more young people than almost any other country in Europe - and the numbers are growing.

On any given day, we now have more than 10,000 young people either remanded or sentenced to prison, at huge public cost. Yet prison is ineffective in preventing re-offending, proves brutalising for vulnerable young people and often acts as a "school for crime".

Re-offending rates for young offenders given custodial sentences stand at almost 90% - and research shows that imprisonment can actually increase the likelihood of re-offending, with offenders committing more and more serious crimes. In contrast, evidence from programmes run by Barnardo's and others shows that community-based programmes for young offenders show re-offending rates averaging only 65%, with two-thirds of those then convicted of less serious offences.

Keeping a young person in prison costs between £300 and £550 a week, or up to £2,000 a week in secure accommodation, whereas community-based supervision programmes cost between £80 and £100 a week. There will always be some young offenders who, for their own safety and that of their community, will require custodial sentences. Most young offenders do not fall into this category and we now need an urgent review of sentencing policies for young offenders.

Pam Hibbert

principal policy officer, Barnardo's

Trauma is the key

I was interested to read of Renée McAlister receiving a Mental Health Media award as a "survivor" after being diagnosed schizophrenic (Taking the lead, October 25).

In my view, every diagnosis of schizophrenia should be replaced, as it was for McAlister, with one of post-traumatic stress disorder. It was easy for the psychologists in her case to do this, as the horrifying traumatic event that she experienced was a one-off and witnessed by others. The significance of this new diagnosis not only led to her getting different treatment, but to the potential for recovery.

Unfortunately, the diagnosis of schizophrenia almost inevitably follows any hallucinatory experience, which leads the patient to believe that they have a disease from which they will never fully recover - itself a traumatic experience. I believe that in many cases the "trauma" leading to a diagnosis of schizophrenia has occurred early in the patient's life, is often ongoing in some form and, above all, has gone unrecognised, frequently affecting a particularly sensitive person at a time when they may be especially susceptible to it.

Sadly, few psychiatrists are either willing or capable of unearthing such trauma. It is so much easier to stick on a label and prescribe drugs.

Joan Woodward

psychotherapist,Birmingham

The TB question

I was very interested to read about Ali Khalili and tuberculosis - partly because I worked alongside him until my retirement in 1990, and partly because I, too, had TB while working as a consultant in the NHS (Return of an old enemy, October 11).

My own experience was somewhat different to his. In the first place, my chest X-ray was persistently normal. I virtually diagnosed myself in that I sent a specimen of sputum to the laboratory and, more or less as an afterthought, asked for TB bacilli to be looked for.

Why did I get TB? Well, it is true that I was born in India but, as my name suggests, my genes are European. My symptoms started when I was skiing in Austria, after I had crashed and injured several tendons in my left leg and arm, but continued to ski in spite of quite severe pain. I had been working very hard and was probably in a sense "run down". I had also been exposed to contact with a tuberculous Indian patient not long before I developed the symptoms.

It may be that Khalili's TB was as much a result of fatigue and stress as of his non-European genes.

Peter McMullin

Winchelsea, East Sussex

Housing the homeless

It is with both fascination and dismay that I read about the ongoing debate over the sale of council housing (Dividing walls, October 18).

This strategy has caused misery to many more than can be easily assessed. Having worked with homeless people in three major cities, it saddens me to see the same pattern repeated in them all.

The market must be prepared to take some responsibility for those homeless people caught in the trap created by the need to make a fast buck. Amid all the talk about the new Human Rights Act, has anyone remembered that housing is a fundamental right?

How about actually releasing the majority of the profit generated from the sale of council housing and actually doing something with it? If this is too radical, perhaps we could consider transferring public housing stock at more than little or no cost to the pseudo private sector, using funds generated to provide practical housing solutions for all our citizens.

Billy Gibson

Birmingham

Clarification

I would be grateful if you would make it clear that the letter printed in my name on October 25 was written by me as honorary secretary of the London Labour Mayors' Association, although I believe that the London Association of Mayors would not disagree with my views.

Len Snow

London

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Choosing a top dog
fields.body:
Choosing a top dog

Peter Melchett has sadly had enough of running Greenpeace UK and wants to grow his veggies and help stock Iceland's supermarket shelves as an environmental advisor. So who will take over that well-branded multinational? History usually dictates that a charismatic NGO leader is followed by a bit of dullard but the chirpy board and staff mood at Greenpeace (membership rising, court cases won, back in the public eye) is that a young radical communicator is needed. The hope seems to be that he or she will not take the organisation much further down the corporate route.

The front runners are actually rather few. Insiders with a chance are Sarah Burton, the legal officer who has a long track record and Stephen Tindale, who started at Friends of the Earth, joined New Labour and is now back as Greenpeace's political officer. He is a new father, so his wife may not welcome the 75-hour weeks and occasional prison sentences. Elsewhere, Tony Juniper, number two at FoE, is a prime candidate who has made no secret of his desire to run a mainstream green group, and came close with the World Wildlife Fund. George Monbiot should also be on the list but no one ever offers him anything except libel writs and death sentences (and he is probably too radical for Greenpeace anyway).

So could Greenpeace take the English football coach route and look abroad? Ute Bellier is German and was Greenpeace International's chair, but is thought to be far too happy in the Lake District running their forest campaign. Very long shots would be the Indian writers and activists Arundati Roy and Vandana Shiva who would be a dream double ticket, but would be far too much of a handful; which really only leaves Al Gore, Mo Mowlam, Jose Bove and Euan Blair. Odds are: 6-4 Juniper, 4-1 Tindale, 2-1 Burton, 7-1 Bellier, 25-1 Monbiot 1,000-1 Shiva, Roy, Gore, Bove, Blair.

Red/green alliance

It's a frog. Specifically a red-thighed one having a snack before bedtime, as drawn by Ken Livingstone for London Zoo's Adopt an Animal week last week. Other celebs who contributed wildlife drawings include Frank Skinner and Dermot O'Leary. Others yet to contribute include T Blair, Z Ball and S Fry.

Blowing hot and cold

Nature bites back. Several years ago that dearly beloved but deeply eco-ignorant author John Mortimer welcomed global warming because - eco-soundings paraphrases a bit here - it would bring nice warm weather to the south of England and all his friends could grow grapes in New Labour's chiantishire. Alas, the genial barrister was unable to push his new book on Monday because the massive storm stopped him reaching the BBC radio studios. No doubt Mortimer tuned in to hear leading British climatologist Dr Mike Hulme of East Anglia University warning that global warming actually meant similar storms could be expected far more frequently with far more deluges in ever heavier bursts throughout the Home Counties.

Changing times

So, which shadow cabinet minister seven years ago chatted up young Euan Blair and unwittingly, according to his father, helped turn Tony Blair green? Step forward ... No. She really, really doesn't want it made public, perhaps because she keeps having alarming confrontations with ecologists and others who keep banging on about the environment.

Being prepared

While storms lash Britain it is worth remembering that thousands of poor people die each year in climate disaster elsewhere. The Tearfund development agency in a report this week says disaster preparedness programmes have been proved effective. An early warning system in the Honduran city of La Ceiba saved all but nine inhabitants during Hurricane Mitch when 10,000 of the unprepared died elsewhere. Most crucial in planning is using local knowledge to create an early warning system, educating local communities so they can build in safe places, and mapping areas likely be affected so, for example, people can move to higher ground. Investing a few thousand pounds saves millions in subsequent relief. Of the 80,000 people who died in natural disaster last year 96% lived in developing countries.

fields.headline: Make it happen
fields.standfirst: If Blair wants to develop a green political agenda he will have to do better, says  Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth
fields.trailText: If Blair wants to develop a green political agenda he will have to do better, says Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth
fields.body:
Last week, Tony Blair finally made his first "big green speech" as prime minister. Sitting in the audience, I was reminded of popular singer Mariah Carey. His speech was technically proficient, artfully constructed, powerfully delivered - and devoid of soul.

It's worth asking why Mr Blair has found it so difficult to connect with the environmental agenda, let alone with groups like Friends of the Earth (FOE), whose campaign against GM crops he huffily dismissed as the "tyranny of pressure groups". The roots lie in his political formation in the labour movement. Old Labour was a producerist tendency, there to defend the rights of workers and eradicate poverty through wealth redistribution.

New Labour saw that modern societies required a more sophisticated approach. It spoke to and for employers as well as employees, and realised that people also consume goods and services. As good social democrats, New Labour believed scientific materialisation and economic growth were the cure for poverty. Environmentalism was at best seen as an eccentric sideshow, and at worst against business, against science and against the poor.

These are myths. But Blair and his advisers have believed them. Hence, New Labour never embraced environmental priorities, and Blair has yet to deliver his election promise to "put environmental concerns at the heart of policy-making".

Blair's speech contained a sharp and intelligent analysis of how environmental action is good for the economy and business. But if he genuinely "wants to push green issues back up the political agenda", he has a lot to do.

First, he must recognise that sustainability really is the next big idea in politics. Political leadership on the environment now means working out how to replace free-market capitalism, as capitalism displaced communism. Environmentalists now know that humanity has to learn to live within ecosystem limits.

Second, greens believe in fair shares of natural resources for everybody. If climate change places a limit on the safe production of greenhouse gases, then permitted emissions must be shared between north and south, with greater reductions in the north to help poor and vulnerable societies.

Third, greens recognise the moral claims of future generations. Our consumption and development pressures must be restrained accordingly.

It is easy to caricature these beliefs as anti-business. In private, this is indeed what Blair has said about environmentalists, particularly during the debates on global trade, the World Trade Organisation and GM foods ("I am neither pro nor anti this technology" said Blair last week, eyes darting around the room to see if his audience bought this remarkable assertion). In a classic and depressing New Labour spin operation before the big speech, Alistair Campbell briefed the media that his boss would be attacking green "dogmatism". Afterwards, other acolytes ran around denying any such intention.

Blair is certainly a pragmatic politician. What his heart does not naturally understand, his head may be forced by events to apprehend. New Labour used to believe that the environment was of limited political importance, because the word itself never figured high up the list of focus group concerns. The awkward truth is that politicians who turn their backs on environmental problems find that they rise up and bite them hard in the bum.

As New Labour learnt over GMOs, fuel taxes and rural issues, so in the US the Democrats are discovering similar political lessons for themselves. Al Gore faces defeat because of the insurgent campaign of the green Ralph Nader in crucial states like California. Gore and the New Clinton Democrats have only themselves to blame for Nader's appeal. Clinton also promised that the environment would be at the heart of government, and he did not deliver.

In Europe, environmentalism has often found a voice in government because of proportional electoral systems and the consequent rise of credible green parties. But Britain's, or at least England's, arthritic political system makes this almost impossible.

So what can Mr Blair do to turn his green problems around?

First, he must produce a programme for Labour's second term that promotes radical green policies in every sector, from a dematerialisation of the economy, to organic and environmental farming, to granting fundamental environmental rights to all citizens. The usual bland pabulum produced by Millbank policy wonkers will not do. He must spell out targets and timetables, polluter tax programmes and recycled revenue spending. That is how to provide the environmental services and products that enable consumers to go green conveniently (which he said he wanted).

Second, he must lead on the international stage, and help forge a partnership between north and south. In the climate debate, the most backward country is the US. Whether Gore or Bush wins, Blair should use Britain's "special relationship" to persuade the US to join Europe in implementing the Kyoto agreement.

Finally, Blair must abandon the quaint notion that business will suddenly green itself. He pleaded with environmentalists to enter into partnership with industry, praising business leaders for their alleged environmental credentials. But FOE and other environmental groups already have constructive discussions with business leaders, even with companies who have been campaign targets for many years. That is part of successfully persuading business to change. Generally, industry does not welcome environmental initiatives. For all Blair's idealistic talk about constructive partnerships, there is unlikely to be any cosy consensus over the way forward. Environmental politics has to be hard-ball politics, because it is about managing fundamental change. It means deciding how to curb the car, shift to green energy, ban unsafe synthetic chemicals, minimise wasteful consumption, sustainably harvest wild resources and regulate trade. That has to be the job of the government, because business and consumers will not do so unprompted.

webTitle: Row over treatment of schizophrenic man dying of cancer

fields.headline: Final plea for dignity
fields.standfirst: Row over treatment of schizophrenic man dying of cancer
fields.trailText: Row over treatment of schizophrenic man dying of cancer
fields.body:
A psychiatric patient dying of cancer is being denied his wish not to be injected with powerful anti-psychotic medication. Ron Holbeche, who is diagnosed schizo- phrenic, has untreatable cancer in his abdomen and lower back muscles. He suffers such acute pain he finds it difficult to walk. Friends and family do not expect him to live longer than five months.

With the support of his family, 57-year-old Holbeche has requested to be relieved of the Depixol injection he has been receiving for more than 10 years. He says that not only is it humiliating to have the compulsory injection into his wasted muscles, but it causes him additional pain. He also claims the powerful tranquiliser drains him of energy, preventing him from carrying out his one lifelong passion - painting.

Holbeche has offered to take the medication in tablet form. But two nurses and a psychiatrist last week drove to his flat in Crediton, Devon, to inject him. He says he was told that if he did not accept the injection, he would be taken back to psychiatric hospital.

The treatment has angered local mental health workers and Holbeche's family. They argue that it is unreasonable to continue injecting such strong medication into a seriously ill man. Holbeche's son, Kieron, who has been caring for his father, says: "Since the injection, my dad's soul has been destroyed. He is hurt and depressed. His painting acts as his own kind of therapy and medication during this part of his life. All I want is for my dad to spend his last few days with dignity."

Holbeche's circumstances are, however, different to those of most other psychiatric patients receiving anti-psychotic medication in injection form. He spent 14 years in secure psychiatric units, including Broadmoor hospital, after being convicted in 1976 of manslaughter with diminished responsibility. He had stabbed a man in a fight after being found sleeping with his girlfriend.

In 1990, Hilbeche was conditionally discharged on a Home Office section and went to live in Crediton. He was told he must comply with psychiatric treatment designed to prevent him from "relapsing" and possibly becoming a risk to the public.

Despite his past, however, Holbeche has been accepted into the local community and has held painting classes in homes for elderly people and for adults with learning disabilities. Known locally as "Crow", he has also had his own painting exhibitions in the town. He has not re-offended and has spent less than three weeks as an in-patient during the past 10 years.

"Crow is a well known and well-liked in the community," says Andrew Barkla, a worker with mental health charity Mind, in Exeter. "He is good at talking and listening to people and is very respectful towards them. He fits in very well. In the nine years I have known him I have not had any sense that he presents any kind of risk to anybody."

Exeter and District Community Health, the NHS trust responsible for Holbeche's treatment, says it does not discuss individual patient cases. But exchanges between his solicitor and the trust are continuing, with the former considering going to a mental health tribunal and then, if necessary, to judicial review. Holbeche is due to be given his next injection tomorrow.

Barkla says that if the government goes ahead with its plans for community treatment orders (CTOs), there will be more cases of patients complaining of being compulsory medicated in their homes - despite ministerial assurances that people will not be injected over the kitchen table.

"Other patients living in the community may in the future be facing a similar situation as Crow," says Barkla. "For many patients, hospital is the preferred place to have their injections, leaving home an environment where they can experience a sense of freedom and live a normal life. But what CTOs risk doing is making the whole world a psychiatric hospital."

webTitle: Helping Bengali children with hearing problems

fields.headline: The hearing aide
fields.standfirst: Attempts to help Bengali children with hearing problems tend to fall down at the first hurdle: the appointment.  John Cunningham reports on a system that works
fields.trailText: Attempts to help Bengali children with hearing problems tend to fall down at the first hurdle: the appointment. John Cunningham reports on a system that works
fields.body:
Sometimes it is the smallest glitches that disrupt the smooth running of the NHS - and the simplest solutions that restore efficiency. Among Bengali families in London's east end, there is an alarming incidence of children with congenital hearing problems. In Tower Hamlets, where about half the population is Bangladeshi, it is up to four times the national average.

Children who are not treated at an early age are slow to develop speech and language skills, and so face long-term problems at school. Detecting hearing difficulties in infants was a matter for health visitors until, in a cost-cutting programme a decade ago, routine neo-natal testing was abolished.

The decision was much criticised and a local charity, Women's Health and Family Services, was instrumental in getting the NHS authorities to accept that the scale of the problem merited specialist provision. As a result, Great Ormond Street hospital was contracted to run a children's audiology clinic as an outreach project in the heart of the community.

However, what started as a good idea was quickly frustrated: about a third of families failed to turn up for their appointments.

The main reason for this was simple: many Bengalis did not speak enough English to find the way or read it well enough to understand the appointment letter. For although health commissioners knew about the experts at Great Ormond Street, they were less familiar with the reality of home and workplace, market and mosque in Brick Lane and Whitechapel, where Bengalis mostly speak in their native tongue. It can be an enclosed world, a Muslim enclave, where adults with little English feel secure in a network where, if help is needed, there is always somebody to translate for them.

Within this safe world, however, is the fenced-off domain of Bengali children with impaired hearing. While parents are concerned, they are hazy about the reasons for the high occurrence of hearing defects. Some just hope that the problem will go away as the child grows up; that time lost at school will somehow be made up; and that the all-important matter of finding a marriage partner will not be jeopardised. In a culture of arranged marriages, some parents feared it would be hard to find a partner for a son or daughter who could not hear well.

A Bengali-speaking development worker was the answer. Now doctors are used to a group of three trooping into the consulting room: child, mother - and Parveen Quadar. However, Quadar is much more than an interpreter; she is also the patient's advocate. Before the consultation, she rings to give directions to the clinic and to make sure the family will turn up. As well as sitting in during the consultation, she sees it as part of her role to win the family's trust, getting them to reveal any related difficulties.

Tony Sirimanna, a Great Ormond Street audiologist who runs the clinic in Hackney, is delighted. He says: "Before, there was a huge communications gap - an invisible screen which fell between doctor and the family. It was incredible how the families opened up in front of her. We can now work with the families to help the child."

Only 5% of those whom Quadar contacts beforehand have failed to show up at the clinic. Doctors are delighted with this improvement; wasted time has been almost obliterated.

Little Shanaz Khaton was visiting the clinic today with her mother, Roamiza, who became concerned when her daughter failed to respond when spoken to. The first step to get help was easiest - a referral letter from their Bengali GP; but two missed appointments followed - one of them because mother and daughter went to the Royal London hospital, rather than the clinic. Khaton does not speak English; she says her husband is always working and she would have to nag him to accompany her. Without him, she always relies on Quadar.

Ambor Alj does so even more. Two of his six children need to attend the audiology clinic. For him, as for many others, Quadar is their guide through the maze. As for the mystery of why so many Bengali children should be stricken, he says fatalistically: "Only god knows." The reasons most cited by Bengalis, says Quadar, are a family history of hearing problems and intermarriage. Alj says he married his first cousin.

Research in other countries points to genetic factors playing their part, says Sirimanna. Marriages to blood relatives, where both partners carry the deafness gene, obviously increase the chances of a baby being born with hearing problems.

Trying to lower the rate of partial and profound deafness among Bengalis could have cultural implications. Should first cousins be discouraged from marrying each other if each has the deafness gene which might not affect them, but could be passed to their offspring?

Sirimanna says all consultants and researchers are aware of the delicacy of the issue. Even trying to help a teenager with hearing problems can cause tensions: he has been asked by parents of young patients for a letter to show prospective in-laws, testifying that a son or daughter is able to hear well.

However, the difficulties with hearing aids can start with a much younger age group. Sometimes the children, like youngsters anywhere, have minds of their own. Shanaz screams if she has to wear hers at home; it makes a whistling sound, her mother says. Other children, Quadar chips in, throw theirs out the window, or flush them down the toilet.

That is something for parents rather than the clinic to tackle. After all, with some 700 children on its books, it is meeting a huge need. "The post of development worker has paid for itself many times over," says Sirimanna.

But the post is funded only until 2002. And to pay for the appointment in the first place, funds had to be cobbled together from several sources. Moreover, the development worker is employed not by an NHS trust, but by Women's Health and Family Services, which vigilantly monitors the needs of a bit of London where the NHS does not always have its ear close enough to the ground.

Soon, though, it may be required to do more. Health ministers are aware of the importance nationally of ensuring that the hearing of all children, not just those at risk, is routinely tested. Sooner rather than later, this is likely to become official NHS policy.

Born to disadvantage

About 1.3 in every 1,000 children are born with a significant hearing loss, according to the Royal National Institute for Deaf People. That equates to some 840 a year. But Asian children are between 2.4 and 3.6 times more likely than others to have such a loss. Although the vast majority of deaf children are born to hearing parents, heredity does play a part. Estimates vary, but a genetic factor is reckoned to contribute to deafness in between 20% and 60% of cases.

David Brindle

fields.headline: A class apart
fields.standfirst: Education failing the sight impaired
fields.trailText: Education failing the sight impaired
fields.body:
Life is made harder for children who have restricted sight because education and other services are not meeting their needs, the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB) says today. Those at mainstream schools often get educational materials in a format they cannot read, rather than on audio tape or in braille or large print, as they are entitled to.

The charity's claims are based on almost 900 questionnaire replies from children and young people aged 5-25, or their carers, in what was the biggest survey of its kind. The RNIB says 31% of school students frequently got inaccessible test papers; 44% said their sight affected their choice of GCSE subjects, and 60% reported finding geography, science, PE and technology harder because of their visual difficulties.

These shortcomings persisted in higher and further education: 47% of students said they did not usually get books in their preferred reading format, while 22% did not get help from academic libraries.

Shaping the Future, a summary report based on the findings, says that most blind and partially sighted young people are happy at school or college and that the public generally is considerate to them. But the government's commitment to inclusive education appears to be failing on several fronts.

This is particularly felt, the RNIB says, by those who have "additional complex difficulties", affecting their communication, learning and motor abilities, as well as sight loss.

The research findings are being unveiled at an RNIB conference in London, where the charity is also launching a website, Sort It!, offering advice and information for blind and visually impaired teenagers.

 Shaping the Future is available at £12 from 0845-702 3153

webTitle: How can the NHS stop dentists leaving?

fields.headline: Gaps and fillings
fields.standfirst: The NHS is 1,800 dentists down as more and more make the move into private practice.  Judy Hirst extracts the answers and looks at how to stem the flow
fields.trailText: The NHS is 1,800 dentists down as more and more make the move into private practice. Judy Hirst extracts the answers and looks at how to stem the flow
fields.body:
Do you floss regularly and visit your dentist at least twice a year? If not, you're in good company. More than half the population rarely, if ever, go for a dental check-up - and things are getting steadily worse.

There are several reasons. One in five refuseniks say they are afraid of how much they will end up paying. Some, the dentally phobic, are simply afraid. Others just find the whole business of someone probing into their orifices distasteful.

However, the most alarming reason why people fail to see a dentist is because they cannot find one - not on the NHS, that is. In recent years, there has been a haemorrhaging of dentists into private practice, to the point where, according to the British Dental Association, the health service is now 1,800 dentists short. A decade ago, dentists earned only 5% of their income from private work: today the proportion is nearer 25%. Not surprisingly, the market for private dental plans has been booming.

For patients who cannot afford to go privately and - unlike children, pregnant women and those on benefit - are not covered by fee exemption rules, the situation is becoming acute. One third of health authorities have difficulty meeting the demand for NHS dental treatment, with the south and west of England among the worst hit. In Cornwall, where the service is largely privatised, long queues form outside surgeries whenever an NHS practitioner opens up.

Even when people do find an NHS dentist - sometimes after travelling miles - the treatment is often second-rate compared to what is available privately. Root canal work and other time-consuming procedures are more likely to fail because of the penny-pinching rules governing NHS fees. Ill-fitting dentures, inferior filling materials and crowns, minimal preventive work, poorly matched veneers - the list goes on.

The government is well aware of the shortage of NHS dentists, and the need to raise quality standards. After some delay, it has launched a new strategy, with additional funding attached, to help modernise the sector. The prime minister has pledged that by September next year everybody will be able to get NHS dentistry if and when they need it.

So is this just another throwaway promise - like abolishing child poverty - that should not be taken too seriously? Or can it really be done? Junior health minister Lord Hunt, responsible for dentistry, emphasises that the government is putting £100m into enticing dentists back to the NHS, setting up "phone and go" dental access centres for non-registered patients and upgrading the service. But high street dentists say the figures do not stack up.

"The £100m figure is a myth," argues Anthony Kravitz, chief negotiator for general dental practitioners at the British Dental Association (BDA), "because £60m of it is coming from savings we've already agreed to make. It's not new money at all. And only a small percentage of dentists will gain from the incentive payments. The strategy does nothing to seriously address the shortage of NHS dentists."

Nor, even assuming dentists can be found to run them, will expanding the number of walk-in centres solve the long-term problem of access to dental care. The British Dental Health Foundation sees it as a worrying move away from regular NHS check-ups and treatment towards quick-fix dental first aid.

The reason for the exodus from NHS dentistry comes down largely to a question of money. Ever since the early 90s, when the Conservatives negotiated a new contract for dentists, the real value of the treatment fees paid to them by the NHS has been falling. Typically, a privately practising dentist can get a 50%-60% higher fee rate, so no wonder they are increasingly closing their doors to NHS work. The dental trade fairs are awash with money from this booming private sector, says Kravitz, and all the latest orthodontic treatments and hi-tech gizmos can be had for a price. But under our two-tier system, none of it is available on the NHS.

Ian Wylie, incoming chief executive at the BDA, believes the skinflint policy on dental fees reflects the low priority given to oral health generally. "It got barely a mention in the NHS national plan and dentists have felt increasingly marginalised over the years," he says. "Investment in dentistry has in no way kept pace with the rest of the health service."

Yet dental health is such a key barometer of overall welfare. Free dental check-ups, along with eye tests, were what everyone rushed to get when the NHS was founded. The state of the nation's teeth has since dramatically improved, but there are still huge social inequalities, and worrying signs - such as 20% fewer people registering with an NHS dentist since 1992 - that things are slipping into reverse.

"Dentists can help detect serious conditions such as oral cancer and arrest long-term problems connected to gum disease," says Wylie, who is moving from the King's Fund health policy institute, where he has been director of corporate affairs. "There is mounting evidence of links between poor oral health and heart disease, premature births,and malnutrition in the elderly. But practitioners need the time to do their job properly; something that, with fee-per-item contracts determining hourly rates, is at a premium within the NHS."

Interestingly, in dental health settings with different funding arrangements, both patients and practitioners report far higher satisfaction levels. In Ellesmere Port, South Cheshire health authority has been running a "personal dental service" - one of a number nationally - that pays dentists according to the number of patients registered, rather than cavities filled. By combining the forces of the local community dental service with all its NHS dentists, it has increased registration by 15%, which is an important achievement in an area with some of the country's worst dental health. "Plus, now they're off the fee-per-item treatment bandwagon, it has freed up dentists to look seriously at preventive issues, rather than just reaching for the drill," says Tony Jenner, South Cheshire's consultant in dental public health.

In Cornwall, the local health trust is directly funding a dental access centre to address the severe shortage of NHS treatment. "The funding system allows dentists to work in a very different way," says the service's clin ical director, Peter Nibbs. "They can offer people more time and have a more rewarding NHS career. Patient surveys have given us embarrassingly universal applause."

The government's new strategy offers health authorities some scope to commission these types of services locally, but only as add-ons to plug the most obvious access gaps. The present funding regime - the one that prompts a third of newly qualified dentists to say they want to work for private firms - is largely left untouched. The answer, argues the BDA, is to drastically improve NHS dentists' remuneration. Others retort that dentists are just greedy, unethical even: unnecessarily whipping out wisdom teeth and over-prescribing, to bump up their income.

"Of course there's some bad practice," says Wylie. "But the vast majority of the public have a lot of trust in their dentists. We have to show we value their work in the public sector, and allow them to do a good job."

The alternative - leaving the supply of dental services up to the vagaries of the market - can only reinforce the image of dentists as hustlers who, to coin the old phrase, put metal in your mouth and pull money out of your pocket.

The fluoride issue:

A five-year-old living in Manchester is three times more likely to suffer tooth decay and to have extractions than one living in Birmingham. The difference seems to be mainly down to fluoride.

Manchester's water is non-fluoridated, whereas Birmingham has had fluoride added to its water for almost 40 years. So how fair is that?

Not at all, say most dentists, doctors and public health experts. Which is why they have welcomed a major new report from York University which shows significant oral health benefits from fluoridating water, and no "clear evidence" of adverse health effects, other than some risk of mottled teeth.

Children in fluoridated areas have 15% less tooth decay and there is strong evidence that fluoride - a mineral that strengthens tooth enamel - has benefits for adults too. But only 10% of the country's water supply has fluoride added, in part because of fears about health risks and objections to compulsory mass medication.

The real stumbling block to extending fluoridation has been the water companies themselves. Since the industry's privatisation, they have had the final say on whether to add fluoride to water supplies. They have now indicated they will co-operate if the government indemnifies them from any resulting legal action.

But ministers are far from united on the fluoride issue and the deadlock looks set to persist.

webTitle: Social care skills shortage prompts Whitehall review

fields.headline: Focus on staffing crisis
fields.standfirst: Social care skills shortage prompts Whitehall review
fields.trailText: Social care skills shortage prompts Whitehall review
fields.body:
Concerns over the growing skills shortage in social care have prompted a review across Whitehall of the staffing demands of the government's burgeoning schemes for children and young people.

Hard-pressed social services directors have already been struggling to fill posts for the Quality Protects programme for youngsters in care. Now directors are increasingly anxious that the new Connexions advice service for teenagers will drain even more precious talent.

Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, says there has been a pan-Whitehall review of staff requirements. The Department for Education and Employment, which is running Connexions, is confident that the bulk of recruits will come from youth and careers services, with out further eroding social services' fragile resource base.

"But that doesn't mean to say we are letting our guard drop," says Platt. "The country has almost full employment for the first time in decades and the public sector is fishing in the same pool, for the same sorts of people, as many other employers."

Platt is speaking on Friday at a conference organised jointly by the Guardian and the National Insti tute for Social Work, and sponsored by the British Association of Social Workers, which will debate the challenges facing the social care workforce.

She says social care employers must be more family-friendly and cultivate climates of openness. Joint review reports of social services departments have shown that the most successful councils are those which promote "ways for staff to make constructive criticism of management decisions".

Employers must also urgently look at ways of making better use of existing staff. "I was visiting an authority recently where there were health aides going into people's houses one day, helping with personal care tasks, occupational therapy aides going in the next day and home care aides going in the day after that," says Platt. "The three were doing very similar things, but because of rigid demarcation there was no synergie."

Above all, Platt wants to hear more banging of the drum for the success and rewards of social care work. For her, one of the highlights of the recent social services conference was a fringe meeting where an adoptive mother enthused about her experience. "We need more, much more of that," says Platt.

fields.headline: Javed's the man
fields.trailText: "I feel like I am 12 years old again - full of unbearable anticipation for the next game," Pakistani cricket writer Saad Shafqat told me after England's thrilling and deserved victory under the Karachi floodlights.
fields.body:
"I feel like I am 12 years old again - full of unbearable anticipation for the next game," Pakistani cricket writer Saad Shafqat told me after England's thrilling and deserved victory under the Karachi floodlights.

England are, wait for it, exciting (not a word you would often have used about them six months ago). And, as if 13 years of hurt wasn't enough of an incentive for the Pakistanis, Nasser's boys have suddenly become a team worth beating. The Pakistani reaction to England is a complex one, but Dr Shafqat is used to making sense out of chaos - he is Javed Miandad's biographer.

There are two ways to try to unravel the enigma of Pakistani cricket. The first is to forget it and devote your energies to a more straightforward pastime like rocket science. The other is to try to make some sense of the Miandad factor. For me, Javed reflects the spirit of Pakistan cricket: passion, natural flair, unpredictability. His cliched image is that of a street fighter or alley cat, but he is more fighter than street, more cat than alley. He oozes danger, precisely in the manner that Simon Barnes of The Times so aptly ascribes to the Pakistanis. Also, he is misunderstood. He divides loyalties; loved and loathed as a player, and now, if you believe the reports, as coach too.

Lillee kicked him; Botham fumed; Imran looked down; and Wasim never quite trusted. An impressive list of adversaries, you might think. But Javed is unbowed. He played squash like a demon and batted like a magician. He draws strength from upsetting his opponents, like the TV Highlander who gets a power-up every time he decapitates a rival. He is fury on the pitch but meek as a lamb before the media. Mostly he is brilliant, at times he is awful. He is Pakistan personified.

From the start he was gloriously talented, a fearless strokemaker but prone to over-confidence and soft dismissals. He started with a Test-debut century at 18, and was the youngest to score a double-hundred.

The captaincy was thrust upon him at only 22 years of age (he was to hold the post for six separate periods), and Javed appeared at the centre of every controversy besetting Pakistan cricket.

But then he changed. He had decided to seize the day, each time he walked to the crease. The last-ball six at Sharjah brought with it cash awards, gold watches and cars. Javed Miandad became the immovable object in both forms of cricket. The fancy drives and concentration lapses were banished as he became Pakistan's highest runscorer, with a Test average of more than 50.

Javed was the rock that Imran Khan built his side on, culminating in that heady 1992 World Cup triumph, and an even bigger accolade from Viv Richards: if he had to pick anyone to bat for his life, said the Master Blaster, it would be Javed Miandad.

Throughout all this, he remained the ultimate competitor, constantly surprising and upsetting opponents, desperate to win. He carries that competitiveness into the coaching job, an attribute too abrasive for some of Pakistan's bloated stars. To use the commentators' phrase of the month, Javed will not die wondering. He has a million ideas a minute and he isn't shy about sharing them.

There is a school of thought that former greats make bum coaches. It is not a theory I subscribe to. Javed is Pakistan's best option as coach, and if some of the star players don't like it then too bad. The years of player power and decadence have been severely damaging to Pakistan cricket, and Javed is their wake-up call.

Long may he irritate.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. He can be contacted by email on kabbasi@bmj.com. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on wisden.com. To read his previous column, about Lord MacLaurin's comments on match-fixing, click here

fields.headline: Private beds go public
fields.standfirst: Guardian comment: The NHS should use private sector beds
fields.trailText: Guardian comment: Does it make sense for the health service to use spare capacity in the private sector? Of course.
fields.body:
Does it make sense for the health service to use spare capacity in the private sector? Of course. Only the ideologically obtuse would ignore the under-used capacity in the private sector, where bed occupancy is barely 50%, while NHS facilities are overstretched. This would be true at any time in the year, but is even more relevant now as winter approaches and the pressure on the NHS intensifies. So there is nothing wrong in principle with the "concordat" which the health secretary Alan Milburn signed with the private sector yesterday, allowing NHS patients to be transferred to private critical beds. This is no new phenomenon. NHS hospitals have been doing deals with private hospitals for years. Last year £1.25bn of NHS spending on hospital and community health services, almost 5% of the total, was spent with private hospitals. This involved 350,000 operations in an NHS performing 6m. The new deal might add a further 100,000.

The health secretary was right to say the problem with the NHS was lack of capacity, not of cash. In the next five years, the NHS will receive its biggest funding increase since it was founded 50 years ago. The aim is to transform the system into a quicker, more responsive, more patient-friendly service. This in turn - particularly the much shorter hospital waiting times - should further reduce demand for private medicine. But not overnight. Hence yesterday's deal. The spare capacity in private hospitals allows local block contracts (say 20 hip replacements by March) to be secured at marginal cost, and that means lower prices. This is good for taxpayers as well as patients. Some deals, where NHS doctors and nurses use the spare private operating theatre, will be even cheaper.

There are three caveats. First, the plan does not have a timespan attached. It should have. If the modernised NHS lives up to its ministerial billing, the private sector should become less important. Yet the agreement suggests it will help "longer term" planning. Second, it makes no mention of private "freeloading" - the fact that all training costs fall on the NHS, and not on private hospitals. This should not be ducked. Third, it fails to clarify what ought to happen when the private sector gets things wrong. At present, uncertainty reigns when because of private hospital failure a patient has to be transferred to an NHS intensive care bed. PPP pays the NHS; Bupa does not. PPP has the right approach.

webTitle: BB King's jive talk enters quotations pantheon

fields.headline: BB King's jive talk enters quotations pantheon
fields.trailText: A dictionary of quotations published next week aims to reflect "the widening of our cultural sphere" with thousands of hitherto neglected sayings by black and Asian people, and from popular culture and the world of business.
fields.body:
A dictionary of quotations published next week aims to reflect "the widening of our cultural sphere" with thousands of hitherto neglected sayings by black and Asian people, and from popular culture and the world of business.

The 19th century US black activist Booker T Washington is in with "No race can prosper till it learns there is as much dignity in tilling a field as in writing a poem", as is bluesman BB King with "Nobody loves me but my mother/And she could be jiving too".

The 1,300-page Encarta Book of Quotations criticises others for "under-representing or overlooking" such sources. But it omits many hallowed texts from the Bible and Shakespeare. The editor, Bill Swainson, said yesterday that the aim was better to reflect contemporary reality.

Compiled by the London
publisher Bloomsbury and backed by the software giant Microsoft, the book aims to follow up Encarta's World English Dictionary. This also had Microsoft finance and has sold more than 100,000 copies in 15 months in Britain, despite some criticism for its US emphasis.

The quotations dictionary
has 502 passages from the Bible compared with 1,301 in the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations.

Passages discarded include "Consider the lilies of the field ... they toil not, neither do they spin" (St Matthew, 6.28). There are 660 Shakespeare quotations, as against 1,346 in the Oxford.

Mr Swainson, brought up a churchgoer, regretted the loss of biblical texts, but said: "If the Bible, sadly, is less referred to and less of a source of folk lore than it used to be, this is inevitably going to be reflected in a book whose take on the world is international, wide-ranging and contemporary. We now inhabit and share a much wider world.

"The book moves away from being a canon of quotation. It is influenced by the fact that our culture has become a much more popular culture, influenced by things like TV shows."

The editor, Bill Swainson, said yesterday that the aim was better to reflect contemporary reality. Compiled by the London publisher Bloomsbury and backed by the software giant Microsoft, the book aims to follow up Encarta's World English Dictionary. This also had Microsoft finance and has sold more than 100,000 copies in 15 months in Britain, despite some criticism for its US emphasis. The quotations dictionary has 502 passages from the Bible compared with 1,301 in the Oxford Dictionary of Quotations. Passages discarded include "Consider the lilies of the field ... they toil not, neither do they spin" (St Matthew, 6.28). There are 660 Shakespeare quotations, as against 1,346 in the Oxford. Mr Swainson, brought up a churchgoer, regretted the loss of biblical texts, but said: "If the Bible, sadly, is less referred to and less of a source of folk lore than it used to be, this is inevitably going to be reflected in a book whose take on the world is international, wide-ranging and contemporary. We now inhabit and share a much wider world. "The book moves away from being a canon of quotation. It is influenced by the fact that our culture has become a much more popular culture, influenced by things like TV shows."

fields.headline: The best graveside scene: This is Spinal Tap
fields.trailText: The best graveside scene: This is Spinal Tap
fields.body:
Graceland. Nigel Tufnell (Christopher Guest), David St Hubbins (Michael McKean) and Derek Smalls (Harry Shearer) stand beside Elvis's grave.

"I'm not sure this was such a great idea," David mutters. "I don't feel any better than I did at the hotel."

"He was going to do a TV special from here, before he died," remarks Derek.

David breaks into song.

" Well since my baby left me / I found a new place to dwell / It's down at the end of Lonely Street / At Heartbreak Hotel ."

Nigel turns to his band-mate.

"Do it with the harmony parts."

David and Nigel try and harmonise.

" Well since my baby left me ..."

David looks pained.

"The same key, though, I think."

" Well since my baby left me ..."

Nigel becomes confused.

"If I'm going, Well since my baby left me. Meeee ."

"No, you can't hit that note!"

Now Derek joins in.

"... since my baby left me / I found a new place to dwell ..."

"That's alright", says Nigel.

David is irked.

"It sounds raga. You don't want to go raga on this stuff."

"No, not with this you don't. Well since my baby left me ..."

"It sounds... fucking barbershop."

"Hey!" Derek protests. "Watch the language. You're paying homage to the King!"

David stares at the grave.

"Well, this is thoroughly depressing."

"It really puts perspective on things, though, doesn't it?"

"Too much. There's too much fucking perspective ."

See also: Paper Moon, The Texas Chainsaw Massacre

Don't see also: Psychomania

Pointless trivia: Christopher Guest provided the voice of Slamfist in 1998's Small Soldiers.

fields.headline: Eidos chief executive quits
fields.trailText: 2pm: Eidos, the computer games group behind cyberstar Lara Croft, has announced the resignation of chief executive Charles Cornwall, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games group behind cyberstar Lara Croft, has announced the resignation of chief executive Charles Cornwall.

Mr Cornwall has quit following a nightmare year for the company, which has seen its shares lose over 75% in value and the collapse of takeover talks with French rival Infogrames.

His resignation follows the departure last month of chief financial officer Jeremy Lewis.

However, investors have been encouraged by good sales figures for the latest Eidos releases, which include versions of hit film Chicken Run and gameshow Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

Eidos is best known for its Tomb Raider franchise, which made a software icon out of Lara Croft and is being turned into a Hollywood blockbuster starring Angelina Jolie.

The computer games group said Mr Cornwall had left to spend more time on his business interests in the US and South Africa. He will be replaced by Michael McGarvey, chief operating officer at Eidos.

Mr McGarvey said: "Eidos is entering a new chapter and I look forward to working closely with the rest of the management team to take Eidos forward to the next stage of its development."

The City welcomed the news, as it could clear the way for another takeover bid, lifting Eidos shares 6.2%, or 12.5p, to 292.25p.

webTitle: NetValue claims first with online ad reach measure

fields.headline: NetValue claims first with online ad reach measure
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Ratings firm NetValue has launched what it claims is the first system for measuring online advertising reach, reports Amy Vickers
fields.body:
Internet ratings firm NetValue has launched what it claims to be the first system for measuring advertising reach.

NetValue said Ad-Impact would be able to produce profiles of ad campaigns running on the top 400 European websites, and compare socio-demographic profiles of people exposed to campaigns.

The company is selling its service to agencies to provide ad profiling data for their clients wishing to measure the impact of banner ads. So far, AKQA and Profero have signed up.

Jannie Cahill, marketing manager at NetValue, said: "It's about moving away from the obsession with click-through - which is so low at the moment - and looking at the frequency of exposure of online advertising."

The system works by integrating NetValue's internet audience panels, which provides it with reach data on websites, with the company's database software arm, TNS AdNettrack, which automatically captures data on banners running across leading websites.

Ad-Impact is being run in conjunction with NetValue research partner Taylor Nelson Sofres, which runs the Barb TV measurement contract.

Running initially in the UK and France, the service is also planning to launch in Spain and Germany in before the end of the year, and then roll out to the US, Mexico, Hong Kong, Italy, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, China, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore.

webTitle: Brussels veto attack puts new pressure on Blair

fields.headline: Brussels veto attack puts new pressure on Blair
fields.standfirst:
Commission president calls for elimination of Europe 'manacle'
Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: The president of the European commission, Romano Prodi of Italy, landed Tony Blair's government in hot water over the future integration of the EU again last night when he chided unnamed member states for clinging to their national vetos on decision making.
fields.body:
The president of the European commission, Romano Prodi of Italy, landed Tony Blair's government in hot water over the future integration of the EU again last night when he chided unnamed member states for clinging to their national vetos on decision making.

What Mr Prodi called "a manacle chained to Europe" was immediately seized upon by the government's Conservative critics as proof of his own honesty in campaigning for "an EU superstate" - and Mr Blair's "casual dishonesty" in seeking to take Britain into such a state by stealth.

What outraged Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary, were remarks made by Mr Prodi at a Brussels press conference five weeks before the Nice summit attempts to curb the veto on certain policy areas in order to achieve faster and more efficient decision- making once the EU 15 become 20 or even 25 nations-strong.

Mr Prodi was reported as saying that qualified majority voting (QMV), where bigger states have extra votes, should be extended to include sensitive areas like social policy, asylum and immigration and what he delicately called "certain taxation provisions" - the most politically sensitive point of all.

His remarks suggest the commission wants to apply existing tax agreements reached by John Major and Margaret Thatcher more uniformly, notably over VAT rates, widely different across the EU, and excise duties. Tory ministers conceded most current QMV arrangements to help create the single market in the 1980s.

Yesterday Mr Prodi explained: "It is important that we reinforce the will of the union to support enlargement, preserving our efficiency and having an extension of qualified majority vote... I think this is a fundamental point. Let's put it in very simple terms: it is basically eliminating the right of veto as much as possible - the right of veto is really a manacle chained to Europe."

Labour ministers routinely say they are prepared to abandon the national veto in favour of QMV on defined areas including environmental, transport and some employment policies. John Redwood protested last night that - unlike most EU states - the Blair government has never set out a formal position on the veto, despite persistent Commons questions.

Last night Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, issued a routine denial from the Foreign Office. He said that Mr Prodi and the commission "are entitled to their view" but that national governments will decide the issue at Nice - "treating each issue on their merits".

It was the third time Mr Vaz has been forced to issue a generic denial over Euro scare stories in as many days, as Conservatives and their newspaper allies seized on remarks by Brussels officials as proof that Labour ministers are lying about their federalist intentions.

On Sunday the issue was a still-informal scheme for harmonising passport and identity card design in the interests of security. Yesterday a document surfaced on the commission's website suggesting that the "charter of fundamental rights" - due to be endorsed at Nice - will acquire eventual legal force.

Labour ministers have repeatedly denied that as well. Mr Vaz calls it "a political declaration of existing rights, it will be non-binding".

The latest row involves the former Italian premier, now head of the commission. Mr Prodi was backed by Mr Blair for the top job in Brussels because of his reformist record and honesty but has since embarrassed Whitehall by his expressions of long-established Italian Euro enthusiasm.

webTitle: Freud loses Pepsi Cola account to Ketchum Life

fields.headline: Freud's Pepsi pinched by Ketchum Life
fields.trailText: 1.15pm update: Freud Communications has lost the UK consumer account for Pepsi after seven years, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Freud Communications, the agency that famously painted Concorde blue in a PR stunt for Pepsi Cola, has lost the UK consumer account for Pepsi after seven years.

The multi-million pound business has moved to rival PR agency Ketchum Life, which has picked up the entire UK consumer PR account for all Britvic's carbonated drinks.

Britvic markets some of the UK's best-known soft drinks brands, including Tango and R Whites lemonade as well as Pepsi.

Freud's will continue to work on Pepsi until the end of the year. After that it will retain the international consumer PR account for Pepsi and will continue to handle the corporate PR for Pepsi Cola UK.

Oliver Wheeler, a director of Freud Communications, said: "It is unfortunate that we will no longer be working with Britvic as an extension of our global Pepsi portfolio."

The account will be headed at Ketchum Life by deputy managing director Jenny Swift. She said: "This is a fantastic win for us. It plays entirely to our strengths."

Tango was previously handled by PR agency Henry's House, which also pitched for the consolidated account.

Ian Armstrong, senior brand manager on Tango who co-ordinated the pitch, said: "All the shortlisted agencies put up a strong performance but we were particularly impressed by Ketchum Life's strong grasp of their brief, their understanding of the strategies required and knowledge of the key influencers to deliver the object."

Freud's had been expected to lose the UK consumer account because of its work for Pepsico, the US owner of Pepsi.

The blue Concorde stunt was part of an international rebranding drive that saw Pepsi cans change from red to blue to distinguish them from arch-rival Coca-Cola.

Freud's also orchestrated a tie-in with the Mirror, which changed its pages from white to blue for a day.

Britvic, which distributes Pepsi in the UK, is widely expected to come up for sale in the near future with Pepsico the most likely buyer. This would create a conflict of interest if Freud were also working for Britvic.

webTitle: First beef - now lamb to the slaughter?

fields.headline: First beef - now lamb to the slaughter?
fields.standfirst: The possible existence of a sheep BSE equivalent has raised doubts over the future of the other red meat in British supermarkets. We're better informed this time, but it still could be a lottery, says health correspondent James Meikle
fields.trailText: The possible existence of a sheep BSE equivalent has raised doubts over the future of the other red meat in British supermarkets. We're better informed this time, but it still could be a lottery, says health correspondent James Meikle.
fields.body:
So the Sunday roast is under threat again. Once it was beef; now it is lamb. The longstanding worries among government advisers on whether BSE has moved from cattle to sheep, first expressed more than four years ago, finally exploded into the public limelight yesterday as the Ministry of Agriculture admitted that slaughtering the 44m-strong national flock was among the options to be considered if the worst came to the worst.

Presumably any moment now then there will be contingency arrangements discussed with New Zealand and other major exporters to see if they could increase supplies to maintain demand while our farmers restocked. Supermarkets will no doubt also be considering alternative arrangements.

Should we be worried? Yes, in that the science of these horrible diseases is still so uncertain that every precaution now needs to be taken against infecting the population. But if BSE has transferred to sheep through cannibalistic feeding practices that meant sheep and cattle remains were fed to sheep and cattle, this probably happened years ago.

That means the sheep that caught it, if it existed, are long dead. But there remains the haunting possibility it has existed for years as a hidden, slumbering, but still infectious disease, masked by another infection which is not thought to have been dangerous to man.

The problem is that the way BSE seems to work when deliberately used to infect sheep in laboratory conditions means that few cuts would be "safe" to eat, unlike with cattle. Should lamb be banned in the absence of evidence that it is free from BSE? No. Such an approach could lead to many other foods disappearing from the shelves too.

At least consumers can now make up their own minds as they were unable to about beef for years, since chief medical officers and ministers sedated the public into thinking it was safe. Beef sales did drop after the link between BSE and deaths in humans was circumstantially established in 1996, but they have recovered as prices have fallen.

Are we simply greedy or more sophisticated about risk? Maybe the establishment is learning that the public can be trusted not to panic at every food alarm and as consumers we are finally learning the lesson of the BSE in cattle crisis that we should take an interest in our food, how it is fed, slaughtered and processed into food. And keep our fingers crossed.

fields.headline: Six days to go
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: On the stump yesterday
fields.body:
On the stump yesterday

George W Bush

Started the day in what was supposed to be safe Gore territory, San Jose, California, visiting inner city organisations, before flying to Portland, Oregon, to a 'Victory 2000' rally at the Memorial Coliseum. Then on to Bellevue, Washington, for a third rally. Today, Bush heads back to mid-west battleground, where he is neck-and-neck with Gore.

Al Gore

As Bush moved north through the Pacific states, Gore moved south. Started the day with a speech on targeted tax cuts in Portland, Oregon. Then flew to Los Angeles to tape an appearance last night on the Tonight Show with host Jay Leno (Bush did same show on Monday), before attending a star-studded fundraising event in Westwood, near Beverly Hills.

Joining the campaign trail

For Gore: Stevie Wonder, Carlos Santana

For Nader: Patti Smith

TV ad spending so far

Gore: $62m

Bush: $65m
