webTitle: Unfashionable Udinese pip Juve to go top

fields.headline: Unfashionable Udinese pip Juve to go top
fields.trailText: Four matches into the new season, and the Serie A table looks as distorted as a Pizzinato masterpiece. Unfashionable Udinese are top, Atlanta are second and Bologna are fourth. Meanwhile, the big names are struggling in the background.
fields.body:
Four matches into the new season, and the Serie A table looks as distorted as a Pizzinato masterpiece. Unfashionable Udinese are top, Atlanta are second and Bologna are fourth. Meanwhile, the big names are struggling in the background.

Take Juventus. Last week, Edgar Davids and Zinedine Zidane were sent off as they crashed and burned at home to Hamburg, prompting bitter verbal assaults on coach Carlo Ancelotti. Surely, he must have thought, Udinese's All Saints' Day visit to the Stadio Delle Alpi might offer some form of salvation. If he did, he was to be sadly mistaken.

Udinese, unbeaten in Serie A this season under Luigi de Canio, took the lead with a 23rd-minute Roberto Sosa header. Worse still for Ancelotti, they then doubled the lead when Sosa scored again on 69 minutes, latching onto a through-ball from in-form midfielder Martin Jorgensen and clipping it home. Although Alessandro del Piero managed a late penalty, there was to be no repeat of the last-minute heroics that saw Juve come back from two goals down to draw with Milan last month.

The result puts Udinese top of Serie A, after Roma fell to third after their first defeat of the season at Internazionale.

Roma started brightly, but after Hakan Sukur headed home his first Serie A goal after 18 minutes to put Inter ahead, something changed. No longer were Fabio Capello's side full of dash and elan. Instead they resembled a winded prizefighter, barely coming forward and only offering wild, inaccurate jabs towards a bemused - and unsupported - Gabriel Batistuta.

But in the second half everything changed. No longer did Inter's Francisco Javier Farinos and Luigi Di Biagio boss the midfield. Or Roma's attack stay toothless. Instead the away side began to dominate.

First, Francesco Totti played Batistuta in with a sublime pass, only for his shot to be superbly saved by Stephane Frey. Then Totti burst through, only for Frey to deflect his powerful shot onto the bar. Other chances followed, but in the 67th minute Uruguay international Recoba - who was again booed by some fans in the San Siro - connected with Gresko's cross to make the game safe for Inter.

"The Roma I saw in the first half is not the Roma I wanted to see," Capello admitted after his side's 2-0 defeat. "We relied too much on long balls launched over in the hope of finding Batistuta who was all alone out there."

"In the second half we put a few good moves together and we were very unlucky on several occasions. But Inter played well today."

In Rome, Sven-Goran Eriksson's turbulent week continued, as he received a mixed reception before Lazio's barely deserved 2-1 win against newly promoted Brescia. Eriksson's pre-match introduction to the crowd on the huge video screen was met by a handful of jeers and whistles, but his emergence from the tunnel was then followed by a round of applause as he was besieged by photographers.

And the uneasy mood in the Stadio Olimpico became even more pronounced when Brescia took the lead after just three minutes with a Dario Hubner penalty. With Lazio pedestrian in their play and their attitude, the whistling increased - although there was no direct booing of Eriksson.

But on 34 minutes Lazio grabbed an equaliser their performance barely merited. Simone Inzaghi - on for Claudio Lopez, who damaged knee ligaments after just 13 minutes - was pushed over in the box and easily despatched the resulting penalty.

Despite the goal, Lazio found it hard to find any fluency. And as the minutes ticked down they were frustrated by two superb blocks by Pavel Srnicek - one at point-blank range from Hernan Crespo. But with just 15 minutes left, Eriksson brought on Ravanelli and switched from 4-4-2 to 4-3-3, and his tactical switch was rewarded when Inzaghi broke through to grab the winner just two minutes later.

Another coach under pressure was Parma's Alberto Malesani. Before the home match against Milan he admitted he was feeling the stress. "In the last days I haven't slept very well," he said. "But this doesn't mean that I'm going to surrender. I want to stay here."

And his hopes of staying were boosted when his side recorded their first Serie A win of the season with a 2-0 victory, both goals coming from Cameroon international Patrick Mboma. Milan, however, were poor and only managed one shot on target all game, much to the disgust of their manager Zaccheroni. "We didn't react," he thundered. "We were not a team because we didn't do anything together."

Meanwhile, Malesani looked forward to a good night's sleep. "If we always play like this we'll get back to our winning ways," he beamed. "I believe very much in my players. There is a strong feeling of togetherness in the group and everyone wanted to get over our current problems."

Elsewhere, Atlanta managed shrug off match-fixing allegations with a comfortable 3-0 win over Verona, Fiorentina struggled to a 2-2 draw at home to Bari, Bologna beat Reggina 2-0, and Napoli picked up their first point of the season with a 1-1 draw against Lecce.
fields.bodyText: Four matches into the new season, and the Serie A table looks as distorted as a Pizzinato masterpiece. Unfashionable Udinese are top, Atlanta are second and Bologna are fourth. Meanwhile, the big names are struggling in the background. Take Juventus. Last week, Edgar Davids and Zinedine Zidane were sent off as they crashed and burned at home to Hamburg, prompting bitter verbal assaults on coach Carlo Ancelotti. Surely, he must have thought, Udinese's All Saints' Day visit to the Stadio Delle Alpi might offer some form of salvation. If he did, he was to be sadly mistaken. Udinese, unbeaten in Serie A this season under Luigi de Canio, took the lead with a 23rd-minute Roberto Sosa header. Worse still for Ancelotti, they then doubled the lead when Sosa scored again on 69 minutes, latching onto a through-ball from in-form midfielder Martin Jorgensen and clipping it home. Although Alessandro del Piero managed a late penalty, there was to be no repeat of the last-minute heroics that saw Juve come back from two goals down to draw with Milan last month. The result puts Udinese top of Serie A, after Roma fell to third after their first defeat of the season at Internazionale. Roma started brightly, but after Hakan Sukur headed home his first Serie A goal after 18 minutes to put Inter ahead, something changed. No longer were Fabio Capello's side full of dash and elan. Instead they resembled a winded prizefighter, barely coming forward and only offering wild, inaccurate jabs towards a bemused - and unsupported - Gabriel Batistuta. But in the second half everything changed. No longer did Inter's Francisco Javier Farinos and Luigi Di Biagio boss the midfield. Or Roma's attack stay toothless. Instead the away side began to dominate. First, Francesco Totti played Batistuta in with a sublime pass, only for his shot to be superbly saved by Stephane Frey. Then Totti burst through, only for Frey to deflect his powerful shot onto the bar. Other chances followed, but in the 67th minute Uruguay international Recoba - who was again booed by some fans in the San Siro - connected with Gresko's cross to make the game safe for Inter. "The Roma I saw in the first half is not the Roma I wanted to see," Capello admitted after his side's 2-0 defeat. "We relied too much on long balls launched over in the hope of finding Batistuta who was all alone out there." "In the second half we put a few good moves together and we were very unlucky on several occasions. But Inter played well today." In Rome, Sven-Goran Eriksson's turbulent week continued, as he received a mixed reception before Lazio's barely deserved 2-1 win against newly promoted Brescia. Eriksson's pre-match introduction to the crowd on the huge video screen was met by a handful of jeers and whistles, but his emergence from the tunnel was then followed by a round of applause as he was besieged by photographers. And the uneasy mood in the Stadio Olimpico became even more pronounced when Brescia took the lead after just three minutes with a Dario Hubner penalty. With Lazio pedestrian in their play and their attitude, the whistling increased - although there was no direct booing of Eriksson. But on 34 minutes Lazio grabbed an equaliser their performance barely merited. Simone Inzaghi - on for Claudio Lopez, who damaged knee ligaments after just 13 minutes - was pushed over in the box and easily despatched the resulting penalty. Despite the goal, Lazio found it hard to find any fluency. And as the minutes ticked down they were frustrated by two superb blocks by Pavel Srnicek - one at point-blank range from Hernan Crespo. But with just 15 minutes left, Eriksson brought on Ravanelli and switched from 4-4-2 to 4-3-3, and his tactical switch was rewarded when Inzaghi broke through to grab the winner just two minutes later. Another coach under pressure was Parma's Alberto Malesani. Before the home match against Milan he admitted he was feeling the stress. "In the last days I haven't slept very well," he said. "But this doesn't mean that I'm going to surrender. I want to stay here." And his hopes of staying were boosted when his side recorded their first Serie A win of the season with a 2-0 victory, both goals coming from Cameroon international Patrick Mboma. Milan, however, were poor and only managed one shot on target all game, much to the disgust of their manager Zaccheroni. "We didn't react," he thundered. "We were not a team because we didn't do anything together." Meanwhile, Malesani looked forward to a good night's sleep. "If we always play like this we'll get back to our winning ways," he beamed. "I believe very much in my players. There is a strong feeling of togetherness in the group and everyone wanted to get over our current problems." fields.headline: The Way They See It
fields.standfirst: How the pundits and the powerful have reacted to the appointment of Sven-Goran Eriksson
fields.trailText:
"England's humiliation knows no end. All that is left is for the football men of England to pull the sackcloth up over our heads and let the grave-dancers pile on the ashes. We've sold our birthright down the river to a nation of seven millions skiiers and hammer throwers who spend half their lives in darkness."
Jeff Powell, commentator, the Daily Mail
fields.body:
"England's humiliation knows no end. All that is left is for the football men of England to pull the sackcloth up over our heads and let the grave-dancers pile on the ashes. We've sold our birthright down the river to a nation of seven millions skiiers and hammer throwers who spend half their lives in darkness."
Jeff Powell, commentator, the Daily Mail

"In one way, it's a brilliant appointment. It's brilliant for Adam Crozier. It's a classic business tactic. Any high-profile executive who wants to survive beyond the first year has to be associated with one big idea. The foreign coach is Crozier's. Those who spend time in his company claim it has been on the agenda since day one."
Martin Samuel, the Daily Express

"The ice bath of reality has been a long time coming. Even those of us who argued that England had sunk low enough to justify the hiring of a foreign coach are not immune to the shock. But only if we keep repeating the discredited mantra that England are a great footballing power will Eriksson's appointment continue to be seen as an outrage."
Paul Hayward, the Daily Telegraph

"I think it's a betrayal of our coaching structure. When they talk about we've nobody here, suddenly Terry Venables is not considered because they have put criteria down that maybe the Archbishop of Canterbury wouldn't meet."
Gordon Taylor, head of the PFA

"The appointment of a foreign coach beggars belief. The England manager is the figurehead of our game because it's the pinnacle job in this country, and this is another example of us giving away another of our family treasures to Europe."
John Barnwell, head of the League Managers' Association

"I could not see France, for example, looking beyond their own country if a new coach was required."
Gerard Houllier, Liverpool manager

"England have reached this point because, unfortunately, the English coaches didn't succeed. Appointing a coach from abroad is no problem. The problem will be if he does not succeed!"
Pele, some Brazilian or other

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them.
fields.trailText: COULD GIGGS HAVE PLAYED FOR ENGLAND?
fields.body:
COULD GIGGS HAVE PLAYED FOR ENGLAND?

"Did Ryan Giggs have the option of playing for England?" asks William Holdaway. "I know he played for England at schoolboy level, but I gather that qualification depended on the location of your school. This could settle a long-standing and increasingly boring argument... do your best!"

You're right, William. Contrary to popular belief, Giggsy never had the option of playing for England. He was born in Cardiff to Welsh parents, and only moved to the Manchester area when he was seven.

He did captain England schoolboys when he played at that level for Manchester United, but as Mark Wylie of the Manchester United museum explains: "That was due to residence. Plenty of Scots have played for England schools. It just depends on where you go to school."

WHEN ENGLAND PLAYED USSR IN 1958

"Can you name the England team that played against USSR in the 1958 World Cup?" asks Russ Wilson.

England actually played the USSR twice during the Swedish tournament. The first game was a Group D match played on June 8 1958 in Gothenburg. Despite going 2-0 down after 56 minutes, goals from West Brom's Derek Kevan and Preston's Tom Finney earned them a 2-2 draw.

The England side for that match was: McDonald - Howe, Banks, Clamp - Wright (c), Slater - Douglas, Robson, Kevan, Haynes, Finney.

However, after the sides finished second in the group with three points, they were forced to play off on June 18. Unfortunately, England - with Finney unfit and Bobby Charlton unused in the stands - could not breach the Soviet defence this time. Although Chelsea winger Peter Brabrook had a goal disallowed for handball, the Russians held firm and eventually won 1-0 when their left-winger Ilyin scored on 68 minutes.

The England team for that match was: McDonald - Howe, Banks, Clayton - Wright (c), Slater - Brabrook, Broadbent, Kevan, Haynes, A'Court.

WHY ARE EXETER CALLED THE GRECIANS?

"Why are Exeter City nicknamed The Grecians?" asks Philip Mawdsley. "I know that the city was once home to a legion of Roman soldiers but that doesn't really explain how the football club picked up its peculiar nickname. Even native Exonians I've asked don't seem to know."

The answer - according to Hazel Harvey's book Exeter Past - stems from a fair on Southernhay in July 1726, in which the Siege of Troy was enacted. Apparently the inhabitants of St Sidwell's (outside the city walls) identified themselves with the attacking Greeks, or Grecians.

Less than a decade later, football matches between the city dwellers (who called themselves the Blues) and "the rugged inhabitants of St Sidwell's" were commonplace. Soon "Greeks" had given way to "Grecians" and by the mid-1800s the term instantly identified a resident from St Sidwell's.

So perhaps it's not surprising that the football ground just off the end of Sidwell Street acquired a "Grecian Gate". And when the team that played there, St Sidwell's Old Boys, changed its name to Exeter City, they were given the nickname "Grecians".

SHILTS FROM THE SPOT

"Against which player did Peter Shilton make his only penalty save for England? It's got me stumped," admits Carl Hollingworth.

Shilton's only penalty success in an England shirt came when he saved a spot-kick from Andreas Brehme of West Germany in a 1985 3-0 victory in Mexico City.

Sadly, Brehme had the last laugh, pelting one past the spring-haired custodian in some match or other in Turin five years later. And a few days after that, Brehme became the first man to settle a World Cup final from the spot. Ah well.

DODGY KITS

"There have been some dodgy colour combinations coming out of the team kit bag over the years," opined Rob Hancock last week. "I remember Coventry sporting an awful brown ensemble during the seventies. Does anyone have any other nominations for the mother of all crap team colours?"

"I think Coventry also had, around the time of the brown one, a weird black/red/yellow combo," reckons Wayne Sammut. "And I'm also sure that in the 1978 World Cup in Argentina one team - I think it was France - forgot their kit and had to borrow one from a local Sunday side."

Meanwhile, Sean Langton says: "My team, Brighton, had a speckled pink away kit during the early nineties, around the same time that the home kit was blue and white stripes, with striped shorts and red numbering - effecting the look of a Tesco's carrier bag.

"All this while being sponsored by NOBO! In fact the only time we could safely wear a replica kit with heads held high was away to Hull."

"What about that silver and tangerine combo Chelsea trotted out a few years back?" asks Sean Walsh. "It looked like a flight attendant's uniform from the 1970s. The flight attendants could pull it off - literally and figuratively - but not footballers.

"Also, Juventus' original color was pink and they commemorated it a couple years back with a bright pink 'Juvecentus' centenary jersey."

CLUBS ON CELLULOID - AGAIN

"In This is Spinal Tap, the bassist Derek Smalls can be seen to be wearing an early-80s Shrewsbury Town shirt. Have there been other incidences of silver screen glory for the lower league clubs?" asks James McKie.

"Whilst watching Spinal Tap again, I noticed Derek Smalls sporting a claret and blue baseball cap. He wears this a lot through the first half of the film," says Andy Barnes. "The writing is difficult to make out, but as they go barbers shop at the grave of The King, you can just make out the words West Ham across the front. A pretty good reference to their supposed East-end roots, but a bit odd considering he's got his Shrewsbury Town shirt on at the same time."

Meanwhile, Will Poole turns his attention to every Stoke fan's favourite play, An Evening with Gary Lineker. "The Martin Clunes character is a none-too-convincing fan of the mighty Potters," he says. " He is pictured several times listening to games on his radio in Spain. How? Is there good coverage of Radio Stoke over there? It's hard enough to follow them from London."

Will is also none too sure that playwright Arthur Smith planned for Stoke to feature in the play at all. "Apparently, when Smith wrote the original play, the character supported a London club. But before Nick Hancock played the Martin Clunes role in the original stage version, he insisted on the change. Is this true?"

POSH AND BECKS AND BABY BROOKLYN

"Did David Beckham and Posh Spice ever elaborate on where in Brooklyn they conceived their son? Much as I love the borough, it's not exactly littered with flash hotels and Armani boutiques. Maybe they were just too embarrassed to name a son 'Manhattan'?" asks Sean Cronin of Brooklyn.

"I'm just glad Dave and Posh didn't conceive in Peckham," says Dave Cassidy from Philadelphia.

CAN YOU HELP?

"Can you help me with a question that's been nagging at me for years now?" asks Tim McCarthy. "On American TV during the late 70s/early 80s, Miller Lite ran adverts with famous athletes endorsing their product. The only football one I saw involved an English winger (possibly named Steve) talking about how he used to take out the trash with his feet when he was a kid. He then pours a bottle with his foot.

"I'm guessing the guy played for Liverpool, Everton or Forest due to the possible time frame, but I'm not sure. Any idea who it was and what team he played for?"

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

fields.headline: Is Weakest Link BBC1's answer to Millionaire?
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: The Weakest Link looks set to become the BBC's first "exocet missile" after the Anne Robinson quiz show almost toppled ITV in the ratings, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Weakest Link looks set to become the BBC's first "exocet missile" after presenter Anne Robinson almost toppled ITV in the ratings.

Her first appearance in the BBC1 schedules was a sensational hit, pulling in 7.8m viewers.

It was almost enough to beat ITV in the ratings and clinches Ms Robinson's position as one of the few hosts who could provide a real challenge to ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire?.

The quiz show has been winning audiences of more than 4m on BBC2 but made its debut on BBC1 last night as part of the new-look schedule.

It opened with a 32% share over 40 minutes from 8pm, according to unofficial overnights.

ITV's long-running police drama, The Bill, which was scheduled against the Weakest Link, was only narrowly ahead with an average audience of 8.2m and a 33% share between 8pm-9pm.

BBC1 boss Lorraine Heggessey will be thrilled with the performance of The Weakest Link, which has virtually wiped out the 3.5m-viewer gap that previously existed with ITV.

Last week in the same BBC1 slot, sitcom My Family attracted just 6m, while The Bill averaged 9.5m.

The Weakest Link's debut is thought to be the best by a BBC1 quiz show for five years.

The programme enjoyed a strong inheritance from EastEnders, with the build-up to Frank Butcher's departure from Albert Square drawing a massive 13.2m and 57% share from 7.30pm.

A second instalment of EastEnders from 8.40pm drew 9.8m. But despite this hefty leg-up, the second outing for BBC1 Pete Postlethwaite drama The Sins, following on at 9.10pm, dropped from last week's 6.6m to 6.1m.

Elsewhere last night, Channel 4 documentary repeat The Real Prince Philip held up well, averaging 2.5m and a 12% share over nearly two hours from 9pm.

Over on Channel 5 at the same time, Bruce Willis shoot 'em up Last Man Standing posted a healthy 2.1m and 10% share.

webTitle: RAF bid to rescue trapped islanders

fields.headline: RAF bid to rescue trapped islanders
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: An air rescue operation is under way to free 17 people trapped on a tiny Welsh island by the storms.
fields.body:
An air rescue operation is under way to free 17 people trapped on a tiny Welsh island by the storms.

Eight young children and nine adults with limited food rations have been on the barren, windswept island of Bardsey in north Wales since October 22.

Rescue crews went into action today after renewed attempts to reach the island by boat failed, a spokesman for Holyhead coastguard said.

"We are in the process of sending a helicopter over from RAF Valley in Anglesey to get them off," said John McClymont.

"The group, which I understand includes eight young children, went over by boat 11 days ago. It is a beautiful island where people spend time bird watching and communing with nature, but the intention was to spend five or six days there.

"I would imagine that they went over with enough food for about a week so they will definitely be running low now. They will have all stayed in accommodation on the island which is about a mile-and-a half long by one mile wide.

"The island is very exposed and barren and not the ideal place to spend time during the weather we have had. It is only a couple of miles from the mainland but the sea around Bardsey Sound is treacherous and the boat which took them out there has not been able to return."

He added that Bardsey Island Trust run tours to the secluded spot and had been struggling to re-establish contact with the island. But with some of the worst storms to hit Britain for a decade during the last few days, trust workers were forced to call for outside help.

"The helicopter flying out there will also be taking a farm worker and his wife back because they have been stuck on the mainland," Mr McClymont added.

"They are the only inhabitants of the island and there has been nobody to look after their livestock during their absence."

• Police searching for a man who disappeared after jumping into a river two days ago said today that they now believe he will not be found alive.

Ian Tompkins, 28, disappeared after jumping into a tributary of the River Nene in Northampton as he tried to help his partner and their two dogs to safety when they got into difficulty in the water.

A police team of about 20 officers and the force helicopter have been at the scene searching for him, but without success.

A Northamptonshire Police spokesman said: "Sadly the emphasis has now shifted from a search and rescue to a locate and recover operation. It now does not seem conceivable that Mr Tompkins is still alive. His family are fully informed about the progress of the search and are aware that our operation is now to find and recover rather than to rescue him."

"I would imagine that they went over with enough food for about a week so they will definitely be running low now. They will have all stayed in accommodation on the island which is about a mile-and-a half long by one mile wide. "The island is very exposed and barren and not the ideal place to spend time during the weather we have had. It is only a couple of miles from the mainland but the sea around Bardsey Sound is treacherous and the boat which took them out there has not been able to return." He added that Bardsey Island Trust run tours to the secluded spot and had been struggling to re-establish contact with the island. But with some of the worst storms to hit Britain for a decade during the last few days, trust workers were forced to call for outside help. "The helicopter flying out there will also be taking a farm worker and his wife back because they have been stuck on the mainland," Mr McClymont added. "They are the only inhabitants of the island and there has been nobody to look after their livestock during their absence." • Police searching for a man who disappeared after jumping into a river two days ago said today that they now believe he will not be found alive. Ian Tompkins, 28, disappeared after jumping into a tributary of the River Nene in Northampton as he tried to help his partner and their two dogs to safety when they got into difficulty in the water. A police team of about 20 officers and the force helicopter have been at the scene searching for him, but without success. A Northamptonshire Police spokesman said: "Sadly the emphasis has now shifted from a search and rescue to a locate and recover operation. It now does not seem conceivable that Mr Tompkins is still alive. His family are fully informed about the progress of the search and are aware that our operation is now to find and recover rather than to rescue him."

webTitle: Red says no to Granada takeover

fields.headline: Red Productions snubs Granada takeover offer
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The independent production house behind Queer as Folk has turned down a lucrative takeover offer from Granada, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The independent TV producer behind Queer as Folk and Clocking Off has turned down a lucrative takeover offer from Granada.

Red Productions, headed by Nicola Shindler, was approached by Granada Creative's chief executive, Andrea Wonfor. But Ms Shindler told Granada she did not want to sell up yet.

Ms Shindler, 32, has enjoyed remarkable success with Red, which has offices in Granada's Manchester headquarters.

Red is working on several projects, including a new series for ITV, Bob and Rose, with Queer as Folk writer Russell T Davies.

Selling to Granada would have meant giving up the rights to her productions, Ms Shindler said, signalling that the deal was not as attractive as it might have appeared.

She stressed, however, that she maintained a strong relationship with Granada, and praised its new controller of drama, Andy Harries, and director of programmes Grant Mansfield.

webTitle: Driver escapes unhurt in Bristol train crash

fields.headline: Driver escapes unhurt in Bristol train crash
fields.trailText: A mail train crashed into a stationary coal train in Bristol early this morning after it passed two red lights.
fields.body:
A mail train crashed into a stationary coal train in Bristol early this morning after it passed two red lights.

The crash happened at Lawrence Hill station, Bristol, shortly after 3.30am when the mail train hit the stationary wagons and catapulted the coal train's engine onto its trucks.

The mail train had gone through two signals at red. As they are spaced out about three-quarters of a mile from each other, the train could have passed the lights more than a mile from the scene of the accident

The mail train's driver, who was taken to hospital, suffered cuts to his face and chest, as well as a broken arm. Two other crew at the scene were believed to have escaped uninjured.

Fire brigade officer Geoff Hutchings said the driver had an "amazing escape". The engine he was driving rode up over three wagons of the coal train and his cab was now embedded in a road bridge.

This morning the engine was balanced precariously on the mangled wreckage of the wagons, wedged under a road bridge which carries the main A420 road into Bristol. A Railtrack spokesman said it is likely to take three days to clear the track on the main route from Bristol to Birmingham.

The British transport police confirmed that all three drivers involved in the incident had been breathalysed and the tests were negative.

Responsibility for the incident is now due to be handed over to the health and safety executive.

webTitle: MGM stalks Myers for Pink Panther

fields.headline: MGM stalks Myers for Pink Panther
fields.trailText: Mike Myers is in final negotiations with MGM for the part of Inspector Clouseau in a Pink Panther remake which, if successful, could pocket him as much as $20m (about £14m)
fields.body:
MGM is reported to have earmarked Mike Myers for the part of Inspector Clouseau in its upcoming remake of the 60s comedy classic The Pink Panther. Variety reports that the winsome star of Austin Powers and Wayne's World is in final negotiations which, if successful, could pocket him as much as $20m (about £14m) for the film.

Over the past six months the casting of the Pink Panther movie has been elusive at best. At one stage, the studio was said to have offered the role to Kevin Kline. For a few months in the spring it appeared that Kevin Spacey (determined to move into comedy after having cut his teeth in thriller and dramas) was preparing to take the role.

Current reports, however, suggest that Myers is looking the more secure bet for a film slated for a fast-track production schedule. MGM is hoping to schedule him in either before or after the February shoot of the independent comedy Timepiece, in which Myers will play a harassed documentary film-maker.

The role of the bumbling French detective Clouseau was immortalised by the late Peter Sellers in a 1963 Blake Edwards comedy which spawned a crop of sequels (the last of which was made up of out-takes and released after Sellers' death in 1980). Myers' long admiration of Sellers is thought to be a crucial factor in securing him the chance to follow in the actor's footsteps.

webTitle: Hong Kong reporters make Jiang see red

fields.headline: Hong Kong reporters make Jiang see red
fields.trailText: China has protested over the burning in Hong Kong of a picture of the president, Jiang Zemin, as a debate rages over his tirade against local journalists who suggested he had an "imperial" manner.
fields.body:
China has protested over the burning in Hong Kong of a picture of the president, Jiang Zemin, as a debate rages over his tirade against local journalists who suggested he had an "imperial" manner.

Beijing's liaison office in Hong Kong says it "strongly condemns" the incident in which a small group of protesters burnt a newspaper cutting outside the local office of the Chinese foreign ministry.

Pro-Beijing newspapers in Hong Kong have demanded that the protesters face criminal prosecution although no law appears to have been broken.

Mr Jiang lost his temper completely last Friday when asked about official Chinese support for Hong Kong's chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, serving for a second term.

"I'm angry," he shouted at a group of Hong Kong reporters, accusing them of being "too simple [and] sometimes naive".

"I am not a journalist," he continued, "but I have seen a lot. I need to teach you a lesson about life."

Mr Jiang was stung by a question suggesting that his endorsement of Mr Tung amounted to an "imperial instruction".

Twice he moved to rejoin Mr Tung but then spun on his heels and advanced on the reporters again, jabbing his finger in the air.

"Let me tell you," he shouted, "I've lived through many battles. I've seen it all. I've been to every country in the west!"

The outburst has given Jiang-watchers fresh insight into the often tetchy character of the supreme leader of a nation of 1.3bn people.

Infuriated by demonstrators last year on a state visit to Switzerland, Mr Jiang boycotted the official welcoming ceremony and told the Swiss president, Ruth Dreifuss, that "you have lost a friend".

Mr Jiang, writes his biographer Willy Lam, is obsessed with appearances and likes to project an image of self-confidence. There is a famous press picture of him "combing his hair before Spanish monarch Juan Carlos during a public function in Madrid".

"He's really spoilt by the mainland reporters," says a Hong Kong journalist who has followed Mr Jiang around the world. "He likes to be admired and addressed as Chairman Jiang."

The affair has provoked a lively debate in Hong Kong over whether Mr Jiang unintentionally justified the charge against him of behaving like an emperor, or whether he was delivering a fatherly reprimand.

"He is the president of [China]," says independent legislator Emily Lau. "He should behave calmly instead of being so agitated. I have never seen state leaders behaving in such a way."

But Ma Lik, secretary-general of the main pro-Beijing party, the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, argues that Mr Jiang's tirade was "acceptable" even though it might have damaged his image.

Mr Ma believes that the reporters were too young and inexperienced, and did not know how to "respect the leadership".

Mr Jiang's harangue at the photo-opportunity in Beijing - while Mr Tung sat with an embarrassed smile - was shown in full on Hong Kong TV. Independent newspapers printed verbatim texts but the pro-Beijing press only published a sanitised version.

Ruling the Chinese Communist party has always required a strong hand to prevent internal dissent. Mr Jiang inherits a tradition established by Mao Zedong, and continued by the late Deng Xiaoping, of forceful leadership.

Some Hong Kong journalists now fear that editors may instruct them to tone down questions to Chinese leaders. They note Mr Jiang's warning that "if you [the reporters] make an error in your report, you will have to be responsible for it".

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: The "we don't want a foreigner to manage England" brigade speaks out
fields.body:
The "we don't want a foreigner to manage England" brigade speaks out

What an embarrassment," thunders Paul Knights, as the debate about Sven-Goran Eriksson rumbles on for a second day. "How can a Swede represent the strength of patriotism that surrounds our game? I would rather England lose with a second rate English manager than be victorious with somebody who embodies absolutely nothing related to our nationalisms. Will he sing our national anthem?" he asks.

"This appointment can only send out the message that England are not the breed of football talent that we thought we were. Or is this the discreet platform for Britain's entry to the Euro!?"

Keith Barry is equally incensed. "I am VERY much against the appointment of ANY foreign manager to run our national team," he writes in BIG letters. "In fact I would rather give the job to my mother-in-law than a foreigner. The FA are useless. Using Kevin Keagan proves that. I can think of lots of English managers, so why can't the FA? I suppose the next thing will be a foreign Prime Minister. I wonder how everyone would feel about a 'Herr Schmidt' running the country?"

For a more enlightened view about Eriksson go here

Being a liberal football website, most Football Unlimited readers actually seem to accept that Eriksson is the best available man for the job. Especially those from Sweden. "Congratulations England," says Dan Johansson. "Sven's a damn genius! If you don't want him, please send him over to Sweden because unfortunately the coaches of our national team are one big sad joke." And Patric Hedenstein agrees: "England took the man we from Sweden wanted," he says. "If you are disappointed, lets trade our Lars and Tommy for "Svennis".

Elsewhere, several readers claim that if PFA chief Gordon Taylor is so hostile towards Eriksson, then maybe England are onto a good thing. "Regarding your nation's new whipping boy, how bad can any appointment be if it's opposed by Gordon Taylor?" asks American reader Dan Herbst.

Meanwhile Dominic Jones is a bit more blunt. "Why doesn't Gordon Taylor put a sock in it and resign, I'm certain there must be a career waiting for him as a bedpan," he says. "The man should be in a museum - as should all the other dissenters who don't see this as the most positive move the FA have made. We need to get our heads out of the sand and see just how far we as a footballing nation have fallen behind the leaders of the international pack. Not since England got into the semi-finals in 1996 have I been so happy!"

Does this usher in a brave new era?

While many of you support Sven Goran Eriksson, there are several emails attacking the level of coaching in this country. "The FA couldn't do anything else," says Roger McFallon. "If there is an Englishman with the qualifications, where is he?"

Picking up on this theme, Stephen Cunningham makes a sustained and well-argued attack on the coaching methods in this country. "We have no coaching culture in this country, a player ends his career, gets a sheepskin coat, a pocket book of football cliches and he goes to manage a club without any coaching experience or qualifications at all. On the job training they call it. No other major footballing country operates this way," he says.

"This is why we have no quality English coaches. The French have a system which grooms coaches as well as players from the grass roots up to national level. England, I believe has the least number of Uefa certified coaches as a percentage of registered players in Europe. None of the top five teams in last seasons Premiership was coached by an Englishman. It's a pathetic, sad indictment. The clubs realised this a few years ago and appointed foreigners, the FA has just woken up to the size of the problem.

"It's all very well having a support team of Taylor, McClaren and Kidd at national level but if a structure for developing coaches from grassroots upwards is not implemented this will be a recurring problem. In short when the 'Little Englanders' ask if there is no one English to coach England, the answer is certainly "No!".

And Peter Van Dyk agrees. "It's about time the FA did something courageous to arrest the slide in English standards," he says. "Of course, it is unlikely that they will continue in this vein - forcing clubs to educate players in more than football at their academies, implementing official standards for coaches to meet, demanding better behaviour from players (regarding refs) and fans.

"But we can be sure that they haven't changed. That they made this appointment is merely a measure of how low we have sunk - expect them to drop support for Eriksson like a hot potato when the miracle doesn't happen. And don''t expect any rational comments from the press after the first setback, either."

Meanwhile... a despairing Spurs fan writes.

"What is it with sports writers and Spurs fans?" asks Martin Cloake. "Roy Collins mentions Spurs' "notoriously grumpy" fans, and calls us "unreasonable". Over the past few weeks, national press coverage of Tottenham's current travails has painted a picture of an expert manager under pressure from impatient and irrational supporters. It's a nice story, but not true.

"We're now in the 10th year of Alan Sugar's regime, during which time we've seen the man he recently acknowledged as the best coach in Britain sacked, four other managers, a number of our best players driven out and the establishment of Spurs as a side unable to attract even ordinary players," he continues.

"Now we have a manager who refuses to accept any responsibility for anything that goes wrong, (a trait he shares with the chairman), who rarely plays any of our promising youngsters - and if he's forced to he swiftly moves to destroy their confidence by freezing them out, and who blames the fans for the failure of his apparantly infallible powers of motivation and organisation.

"We're told there are "no players to sign", yet other clubs seem to manage, and we see players who are apparantly not good enough for Spurs go on to supposedly smaller clubs like Internazionale and do well.

"Graham's had two years to get things right (longer than he gives the kids), Sugar's had ten. Throughout this time Spurs have averaged gates above 30,000 at home, and rarely fail to take up a full away ticket allocation. This obviously doesn't make us as loyal as the legendarily committed Newcastle fans, who boosted the gate at St James' Park to as much as 7,000 in that club's poor period.

"In the circumstances, it was pretty admirable that at the beginning of Tuesday's game against Birmingham, the crowd were getting behind the team. The vitriol eventually directed at the bench and the players was a recognition of the fact that after ten 'transitional' years, THFC is a club shot to pieces from top to bottom.

"That story may not be as easy to write as just cutting and pasting some old "fickle Spurs fans" passage, or as simple as assuming that it's Graham's Arsenal connection that Spurs fans don't like. But it's the truth."

fields.headline: William Hurtz
fields.standfirst: Bringing a contemporary style to film animation
fields.trailText: William Hurtz, who has died aged 81, started out in film animation as a lowly "inker", before becoming an important figure in the history of animation
fields.body:
Given the nature of the work of film animators - a team of people beavering away at benches, one drawing a face, another an arm, another a background on individual pieces of celluloid - very few emerge from anonymity. William Hurtz, who has died aged 81, was an exception, starting as a lowly "inker", before becoming an important figure in the history of animation.

Hurtz grew up in a wealthy Chicago family in the 1920s. His father, the owner of a paint company, and his mother, an artist, were keen for their son to study painting. Thus, from the age of 10, he attended the Chicago Art Institute. After moving to Los Angeles, he continued his studies at Chouinard Art Institute, which eventually became the California Institute of Arts, or Cal Arts, producing many of Hollywood's finest animators.

In 1938, Hurtz got a job assisting Art Babbitt, one of the chief animators at Walt Disney Studios. One day, while cleaning up Babbitt's drawings of dancing Chinese mushrooms, from the Nutcracker Suite sequence of Fantasia (1940), Babbitt asked him how much he was earning. "When he heard it was $25 a week, he got mad, went up to Walt's office and got me a $10-a-week raise," Hurtz recalled. "I think the lack of a regular wage scale was one of the main reasons for the strike."

The strike, on May 29 1941, was proposed by Hurtz, an active member of the Hollywood Cartoonists Union, after Babbitt was sacked for being critical of the inequalities, and for attempting to get Disney to allow his animators to join a union. The conflict lasted for several months, but its positive result helped raise the status and wages of animators in Hollywood.

Hurtz, who was labelled a "dangerous red" and dismissed by Disney, became part of the film motion picture unit of the US Army Signal Corps during the second world war, making animated training films at Hal Roach Studios. After being demobbed, he joined other former Disney animators - such as John Hubley, Bob Cannon and Steve Bosustow - who had formed United Productions of America, better known as UPA.

Hurtz had learned, while working on wartime instructional films, that complicated concepts could be expressed in line and colour with extreme economy. Reacting against the detail of the Disney style, UPA created spare, elegant, highly stylised and more contemporary drawings.

The group established itself as a new creative force in short cartoons with the 1951 Oscar-winner Robert Cannon's Gerald McBoing Boing, on which Hurtz was the layout artist. The company's democratic structure allowed its members to explore their individual styles, and Hurtz was able to direct A Unicorn In The Garden (1953), based on a story by James Thurber.

In an effort to duplicate the unfinished look of Thurber's New Yorker cartoons, Hurtz assigned some work to the studio's least competent draftsmen - to get the "nice, lumpy look" he was after. He also worked on some Mr Magoo cartoons, UPA's most successful productions.

With the decline of UPA in the late 1950s, Hurtz left to work independently, most notably as director of several celebrated title sequences, designed by Saul Bass, for such films as Around the World In 80 Days (1956), Anatomy Of A Murder (1959) and Psycho (1960). The graphic motifs of the lastwere nervous, balletic horizontal and vertical bars that expanded and contracted in mirror-image patterns, suggesting, simultaneously, prison bars, city buildings and sound waves, as well as symbolising the schizophrenia of the main character, Norman Bates.

In 1959, Hurtz joined Jay Ward Productions, a newly-formed television animation studio, to supervise Rocky And His Friends, the popular comic series featuring a flying squirrel. This was followed by The Adventures Of Hoppity Hooper (1964) and George Of The Jungle (1967). While still with Jay Ward, Hurtz co-founded a company that made short animated films about the history of black Americans. In the 1990s, he storyboarded the Rugrats TV cartoons.

At the same time, he was finally able to direct his only animated feature, Little Nemo: Adventures In Slumberland (1992, pictured), based on Winsor McCay's long-running comic strip. The film, made at the Japanese studio TMS, and co-directed by Masami Hata, superbly blended Japanese and American animation styles to tell the story of the hero's travels to Nightmare Land to rescue King Morpheus and win the hand of the lovely Princess Camille.

"My father fancied himself an actor with a pencil. Throughout his life, what he really loved was to draw, draw, draw," remarked his daughter, who survives him, as does his wife and son.

fields.headline: Howell packs celebs into bowlofcherries
fields.trailText: 8am: Ex-Flextech boss Lis Howell has roped in more than 50 top TV presenters, journalists and writers - including Ferm Britton and Roger Cook - to her new internet venture, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Lis Howell has roped in more than 50 top TV presenters, journalists and writers - including Ferm Britton and Roger Cook - to her new internet venture.

The former Flextech TV and GMTV boss today unveiled her new website, bowlofcherries.com, a lifestyle-based service for the over-35s.

Among those signed up to give the site a celebrity feel are Toyah Wilcox, Fern Britton, Andy Sturgeon, Roger Cook and Julia Langdon. They will provide information, tips, opinions and articles.

The stars are also promised as occasional guests at weekly bowlofcherries cocktail parties.

Ms Howell, formerly senior vice-president of Flextech TV and the woman who devised and launched UK Living, has set up the business with help from four business partners and an unnamed private investor 'friend'. She will take the position of chief executive.

Ms Howell said: "This is all about expanding your lifestyle and having fun. bowlofcherries is for everyone who is just a little tired of the preoccupation with young socialites."

An initial start-up fund of £500,000 has been raised by the founding team of bowlofcherries.com, which includes David Hurst, previously publishing director of Financial Times Business and the venture's managing director.

The other founders are Jane McCormick, editor-in-chief, a newspaper and TV journalist; Alyson Pearce, marketing & events director; and Ola Steinsrud, a new media consultant, who is the founder of TVNorge in Norway.

Ms Howell said that the cash would keep the site running until Christmas or when the subscription and advertising revenues begin to kick in.

Former GMTV presenter Ross Kelly, another of those involved in the site, said: "I'm enthusiastic about bowlofcherries because it is designed to bring people together and encourage access and contact. You're in with your own 'in-crowd' carrying an access-all-areas pass to a rich variety of events, information and resources."

Content on the site will be free but there will be a £100 annual subscription for members who want to gain access to special deals and take part in the cocktail parties and get-togethers.

Ms Howell is hoping the cherry acronym - "contemporary hardworking exiles from the rock and rave years" - will stick as a new way of describing people in their late thirties and beyond.

fields.headline: Freeserve denies share option rethink
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Freeserve has denied reports that it is making it easier for staff to cash in on their share options, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Internet service provider Freeserve has denied reports that it is making it easier for staff to cash in on their share options as the dot.com sector fights to retain employees in the face of a continued share slump.

The reports come as pressure mounts on internet companies to revise staff share perks to reflect the continuing depression in tech stocks.

Freeserve, the UK's largest ISP, has seen its shares plummet to 150p this week, against a February high of 921p, leaving many employees' options well below their exercise price.

Today there was speculation that the company, which is 80%-owned by Dixons, was going to lower the price at which staff could exercise their share options.

However, Freeserve insisted it was actively recruiting staff rather than shedding them. It added that around half of Freeserve's staff bought share options at 150p.

A spokesperson said: "If we believed that giving incentives to staff was an issue, then we would consider re-basing share options. But it has not been considered by the Freeserve board or the remuneration committee. These concerns apply to all companies which operate in volatile markets, not just Freeserve."

The spokesperson added that re-basing the options would not require the approval of shareholders because the number of employees and shares involved would have no significant effect on the share price

Analysts welcomed the idea of recalculating share options, saying it could be the first of many moves as European internet companies seek to cling on to their workforces. The US tech giants Microsoft, Sprint and Amazon have all been forced to reset their employee options in recent weeks.

Andrew Moffat, internet analyst at ABN Amro, said: "These people have left their jobs in other, more secure industries and need incentives to stay. But the revising the share options must be about retaining staff rather than making the senior management millionaires."

Mr Moffat added that the options should not be based on share price performance alone, but should be related to fundamental growth in the business.

webTitle: Richard and Judy set to front  TFI Friday

fields.headline: Richard and Judy set to front TFI Friday
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Daytime TV presenters Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan are considering hosting an edition of TFI Friday, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
This Morning presenters Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan are set to make a break from their safe daytime careers to front an edition of Channel 4's controversial series, TFI Friday.

The veteran husband-and-wife team, best known for their cosy bedside interview techniques, are talking to TFI Friday producer Ginger Television about fronting an edition of the show.

Insiders confirmed the TV couple had been approached but said no decision had been made yet.

The vacancy has come up following Chris Evans' decision to pull out of the show ahead of its demise in December.

Ginger is lining up a series of guest presenters for the final series, which starts on November 10 with the Spice Girls in the interview seat.

The company is also said to have approached Sir Elton John about presenting the last ever TFI, which will be broadcast just before Christmas.

fields.headline: Gibson takes over Edinburgh TV festival chair
fields.trailText: 4pm: BBC documentaries head Jeremy Gibson is to take over as advisory chair of next year's Guardian International Edinburgh TV Festival. Jason Deans reports.
fields.body:
Jeremy Gibson, the newly promoted head of the BBC documentaries group, is to be the advisory chair of next year's Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival.

Mr Gibson will be responsible for leading GEITF's editorial direction, from commissioning sessions to overseeing final production. He will also head a festival committee that advises on and produces sessions.

Previous GEITF chairs have included Dawn Airey, Mark Thompson, Stuart Cosgrove, Jane Root and Ruth Pitt.

fields.headline: Lycos snaps up French internet giant
fields.trailText: 10am: Lycos Europe has revealed plans to buy the French internet firm MultiMania for £130m in shares, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Lycos Europe has revealed plans to buy the French internet firm MultiMania for £130m in shares - a move aimed at making Lycos the number one portal in France.

The deal clinches Lycos's position as the largest portal in Europe, tapping into 21m unique visitors and notching up 1.1bn monthly page impressions. It follows September's acquisition of the Scandinavian web provider Spray.

According to Media Metrix, Multimania is the seventh most visited site in France with over 1.2m unique visitors, 138m page impressions and a 40% market reach, second only to the France Telecom-owned Wanadoo.

Lycos Europe will offer seven of its own shares for three MultiMania shares, or 6.4% of its current number of outstanding shares.

Meanwhile, Lycos shareholders have approved the company's merger with the Spanish internet company Terra Networks, closing a deal first announced five months ago.

fields.headline: Heston shoots down Al Gore
fields.trailText: Charlton Heston has rallied gun-owners across America with an apocalyptic speech denouncing Democrat candidate Al Gore as a threat to civil liberties and likening the contest to both the American Revolution and the Civil War
fields.body:
With the US presidential election still too close to call, Charlton Heston has rallied gun-owners across America with an apocalyptic speech denouncing Democrat candidate Al Gore as a threat to civil liberties and likening the contest to both the American Revolution and the Civil War.

A long-time Republican, Heston was always expected to come out in favour of Texas governor George W Bush, but the sheer bombast of his language reveals how tense the contest has become in the final week before polling day.

The Oscar-winning star of Ben Hur and The Ten Commandments was speaking at a rally in Wisconsin in his capacity as president of the National Rifle Association. "Vote freedom," Heston urged the faithful. "Vote George Bush. Everything else is a distant and forgettable second place." If Gore was elected, he claimed, American gun rights would be "hammered into oblivion".

Heston went on to describe the contest as "the most important election since the Civil War" and compared the struggle to the war for independence (recently revisited in the Hollywood blockbuster The Patriot). "Instead of fighting redcoats, we're fighting blue-blood elitists," he stormed.

The right to bear arms is currently a crucial issue for a nation which sees some 30,000 deaths from handguns each year. If elected, Gore is expected to introduce tighter curbs on firearms. Bush, by contrast, recently approved legislation allowing people to carry a concealed weapon.

One NRA activist is reported to have claimed that in the event of a Bush victory, "the NRA will have an office in the White House". Having played the likes of Moses and John the Baptist in his time, Heston may yet be gearing up for a new role on Pennsylvania Avenue.

webTitle: Govt calls for quality kids shows

fields.headline: Government calls for quality kids' programming
fields.trailText: 11am: The government has warned broadcasters to drop 'lowest common denominator' children's TV shows, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The government today warned broadcasters to drop "lowest common denominator" shows for children and provide more quality, home-grown productions.

The broadcasting minister, Janet Anderson, singled out Power Rangers and cartoons for particular criticism. Her comments were aimed at satellite and cable broadcasters that schedule imported programming because it costs less than original productions.

Ms Anderson told a Voice of the Listener & Viewer conference that while "quality" shows such as Art Attack, the Worst Witch and See How they Run were upholding standards, the government shared concerns that others fell far short.

She said: "There are genuine concerns over the violent content of some children's programmes such as Power Rangers. Although it is not a matter on which the government has powers to intervene directly, we believe that film-makers and broadcasters need to think very carefully about their wider responsibilities to society.

"And it is unfortunately true that, while some broadcasters offer excellent drama and information programmes for children, not all broadcasters are providing the range of quality programming we and our children want."

Ms Anderson also hit out at terrestrial broadcasters that had followed the lead of unregulated satellite and cable channels by "dumbing down" children's programming.

"The broadcasting regulators have expressed concern about evidence of dumbing down as more children watch satellite and cable channels. And there is a strong temptation for the terrestrial channels to change the programming mix they offer in order to compete.

"TV executives sometimes argue that advertising revenues are low when children's programmes are showing so that the cheapest option - buying in undemanding cartoons from abroad - becomes the easiest option. But it is not the only option."

Ms Anderson revealed that the forthcoming communications white paper would emphasise the importance of the 9pm watershed in order to protect youngsters.

She told the VLV conference: "The government shares parents' concerns that violent and unsuitable material is being broadcast in ever earlier slots. Parents cannot always monitor every minute of their children's early evening viewing, and have a right to expect broadcasters to act responsibly."

The minister stressed that children's viewing habits showed that youngsters wanted high-quality programmes. The six most popular children's programmes in 1998 included three home-produced dramas, two cartoons and one information programme.

The six most popular children's programmes in 1998 included three home-produced dramas, two cartoons and one information programme.

fields.headline: Chrysalis launches internet radio station
fields.trailText: The Chrysalis Group has launched Puremix.com, a UK personalised multi-channel internet radio station. Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
The Chrysalis Group has launched its much-hyped internet radio station, Puremix.com.

Chrysalis claims the site is the UK's first ever personalised multi-channel internet radio station.

Puremix, which was originally code-named Ride the Tiger, has signed up a number of high-profile joint ventures for the launch.

It is to be the exclusive online music offering for Sony Computer Entertainment Europe's PlayStation website, and has signed strategic partnerships with Bertelsmann-backed BOL and Expedia.

Sales house 24/7 Media has been tasked with handling ad sales and sponsorship deals on the site.

The venture is the first major investment from Chrysalis New Media, a division of the Chrysalis Group. To date, Chrysalis has invested £4m in the venture, which it expects to see it through to next spring.

Keith Pringle, co-founder of the venture, said: "We've assembled one of the most experienced and talented media teams on the net. Together we've developed something special - Puremix is the future of internet radio".

The launch of Puremix will be supported by a £4m marketing campaign, which will aim to attract more than 500,000 users in its first year.

Competitor Capital Radio is currently working on its own personalised internet radio station, called Kikado, as is Virgin Radio, which plans to launch a raft of internet-only radio stations in the coming months.

webTitle: Jon Snow slams ITC over News at Ten

fields.headline: Jon Snow slams ITC over News at Ten
fields.trailText: Jon Snow, the Channel 4 News anchor, has launched a scathing attack on the Independent Television Commission, branding its performance over ITV's News at Ten move as "woeful".
fields.body:
Jon Snow, the Channel 4 News anchor, has launched a scathing attack on the Independent Television Commission, branding its performance over ITV's News at Ten move as "woeful".

And he also hit out at ITV, claiming the network was only paying lip service to its public service obligations.

"Personally I think the BBC has done us all a service by putting the ITC and ITV on the spot... it seems to me to be the last chance saloon for any serious bid to keep some form of public service broadcasting commitment in the popular commercial sector," Mr Snow said.

"The ITC performance over News at Ten, both at the time of the original decision to move it and since, has been woeful."

He said that the next year's 10pm ITV news was not the "reporter-led half-hour news programme of old", but a bulletin that was 10 minutes shorter and would not be scheduled at a fixed time five nights a week

Mr Snow added that the review of TV regulation in the upcoming communications white paper was "not before time", given the ITC's poor record of maintaining the standard of news output.

Delivering the Hetherington Memorial Lecture at Stirling University's Media Research Institute, he also demanded to know how "the ITC has permitted persistent erosion of the amount of money spent on news" by the leading commercial broadcaster.

The presenter also appeared to take a swipe at Granada and its former Compass Catering boss, Charles Allen.

He said the cash squeeze on news came at a time when ITV "remains an increasingly unimaginative cash cow for media conglomerates who know considerably more about cooking than about broadcasting".

Mr Snow added: "The ITV companies have demonstrated such manifest irresponsibility in their custodianship of public service broadcasting that they have proved the case for more regulation."

fields.headline: Amazon moves into Japan
fields.trailText: 10am: Amazon has launched its first Asian site to tap the lucrative Japanese book retailing market, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet retailer Amazon.com has made a swift move into the Japanese market, planning to smash the country's cosy book retailing market.

The move is Amazon's first retailing venture in Asia, its fourth site outside the US after the UK, Germany and France.

Amazon.co.jp will offer 1.7m titles in Japanese and English in its bid to tap into Japan's £2.21bn market for e-commerce.

In a news conference in Tokyo, Amazon founder and chief executive Jeff Bezos said: "We want to be earth's most customer-centric company."

Amazon has a headstart in Japan, with more than 193,000 customers already using its US site.

webTitle: Chris Smith gives BBC news six months

fields.headline: Smith's ultimatum to BBC
fields.trailText: Chris Smith has given the BBC six months to demonstrate the wisdom of moving the Nine O'Clock news.
fields.body:
Chris Smith has given the BBC six months to demonstrate the wisdom of moving the Nine O'Clock News.

If audiences have fallen significantly by March, he will be demanding the flagship bulletin is reinstated.

He said: "In a democracy where television is the primary source of news, the loss of access to that news is very worrying

"If we see a diminution in audience or quality, I have no doubt parliament will also have something to say."

At today's Royal Television Society autumn symposium, Mr Smith compared the BBC decsion with ITV's decision to scrap News at Ten saying: "After six to nine months it became very clear that ITV had lost 1.3m viewers to news".

"If we see the same sort of phenomenon happening with the BBC's move, that will be for me the key test."

The Culture secretary has no formal powers to intervene in the BBC schedules but he has already raised his concerns with BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland.

fields.headline: TV push for online shares firm
fields.trailText: 8.45am: TD Waterhouse Group, the global online financial services company, is launching its first UK TV ad campaign, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
TD Waterhouse Group, the global online financial services company, is launching its first UK TV advertising campaign to take share dealing to the masses.

The campaign will focus on the ease of buying and selling shares over the internet and features a wide range of people rushing to dealing screens on the trading floor. The endline is, "The trading floor is wherever you are."

Paul Stallard, vice-president, marketing director, of TD Waterhouse, said: "Having secured the number one position in the UK in only two years, we want to retain and build on our reputation as the leading quality broker in the market.

"We are aiming to show that share dealing is an everyman experience, that anyone can access it whenever they want and wherever they are."

The TV campaign was created by Maher Bird Associates. It breaks this week and will be supported by branded taxis, colour press advertisements and 96-sheet posters.

TD Waterhouse Group provides investors with a broad range of brokerage, mutual fund, banking and other consumer financial products. Worldwide, it serves 4.3m accounts in the US, Canada, the United Kingdom, Australia, Hong Kong, Japan and India.

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 2.
fields.trailText: November 2: SCA Hygiene Products, owner of Velvet toilet tissue, is looking for a European marketing director following the resignation of David Macfarlane.
fields.body:
SCA Hygiene Products, owner of the Velvet toilet tissue and Bodyform brands, is looking for a European marketing director following the resignation of David Macfarlane, marketing director for Western Europe.

Barclays is looking for a marketing supremo to oversee its business retail units as part of a management restructure.

Brown-Forman, maker of Jack Daniels and Southern Comfort, is seeking a new marketing chief for its UK spirits division following the departure of Andrew Mallinson. The company is also believed to be reviewing its global agency arrangements for Southern Comfort, handled by D'Arcy in the UK.

The Post Office has hired Nigel Moore, previously a financial director at Royal Mail, as marketing director for its new home shopping division.

Procter & Gamble is planning a global relaunch for its Pantene haircare range. The relaunch, which kicks off in the UK early next year, will include new products, redesigned packaging and an increased adspend.

TBWA London has launched a provocative poster campaign for Pretty Polly's new lingerie.

Capital FM is to stage quarterly music events in the capital in an attempt to reclaim its position as the essential sound of young London.

webTitle: Bertelsmann drops legal action against Napster

fields.headline: Napster wins new friend
fields.standfirst:
Bertelsmann drops legal action against online music distributor
Net news
fields.trailText: Bertelsmann, one of the top five music publishing businesses in the world, yesterday broke ranks with its rivals and agreed to drop its copyright lawsuit against Napster, the rogue online music distributor.
fields.body:
Bertelsmann, one of the top five music publishing businesses in the world, yesterday broke ranks with its rivals and agreed to drop its copyright lawsuit against Napster, the rogue online music distributor.

The agreement appeared to be a tacit acknowledgement by Bertelsmann that the landslide change being wrought on music sales by the internet cannot be stopped. It also marks a significant stage in the development of online music distribution toward a more controlled environment endorsed by the recording industry.

Bertelsmann said it had formed a strategic alliance with Napster to develop the website into a secure, membership-based service and invited the other big four to participate. The lawsuit will be dropped once the membership-based service is put in place.

The music business has so far struggled to find a method of protecting royalty payments online.

The two companies said they had already put together a business model and that Bertelsmann would provide funds to further develop the service. In return for the funding Germany-based Bertelsmann will take a stake in Napster.

Napster is the brainchild of 19-year-old college dropout Shawn Fanning and enables fans to swap songs for free by trading MP3 files, a compression technology which turns music on compact disc into computer files.

One by one, the large record labels have reached licencing agreements with MP3.com - a similar smaller website. But Napster which has attracted 38m users has until now been cast as the enemy of the music business. Mr Fanning said he was excited that Bertelsmann "appreciates and values the uniqueness of the community Napsters' users have built".

Napster is awaiting an appeals court decision on whether the online service can continue operating pending a final decision on the lawsuit. The suit was also being brought by Universal Music - currently being taken over by Vivendi - Sony Music, Warner Music and EMI.

Bertelsmann chairman Thomas Middelhoff said: "Napster has pointed the way for a new direction for music distribution, and we believe it will form the basis of important and exciting new business models for the future of the music industry."

Time Warner, which owns Warner Music, gave an initial welcome to the decision by Bertelsmann. It said: "The Napster-BMG announcement seems to be a positive step for the industry. It demonstrates a couple of things very clearly. One, that the industry is rapidly moving towards adoption of a subscription model and two, in the online world, artists and intellectual property rights will be protected. It is clear consumers want access to music in a way that is safe, secure and easy to use."

In July, a US judge ordered Napster to shut down its services pending a full trial but the court of appeals allowed Napster to stay in business.

webTitle: Hindujas lodge offer for Express titles

fields.headline: Hindujas lodge offer for Express titles
fields.standfirst: Hinduja brothers ready Express bid
fields.trailText:
The billionaire Hinduja brothers yesterday formally lodged their offer for Express Newspapers, setting the scene for an intriguing battle for control of the once best selling titles, writes David Teather.
Hinduja brothers ready Express bid
fields.body:
The billionaire Hinduja brothers yesterday formally lodged their offer for Express Newspapers, setting the scene for an intriguing battle for control of the once best selling titles.

Sources close to the Hindujas suggested the bid would make it a serious contender for the division of United News & Media, which includes the Daily and Sunday Express and Daily Star.

Viscount Rothermere's Daily Mail & General Trust submitted its bid on Monday which advisers say is "in excess" of £100m but some speculation has put at £125m. The Hindujas' bid is thought to be of a similar size.

The offer was delivered by hand to the City advisers of United News, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, by the Hindujas' head of corporate finance Jonathan Brown last night.

At the same time United News chief executive Lord Hollick appeared to be shaping the titles for sale by bundling the online version of the Express, express.co.uk into the newspaper division - a move which will make the business more valuable. It had previously sat within United News & Media's internet business Xilerate.

The Hindujas are said to have put together a team of "mainstream print media business managers" although they still decline to name them.

The Hindujas are on good terms with editor Rosie Boycott and she could be asked to remain in the job.

The brothers are understood to have floated the idea of buying the Express earlier this year but have been sparked into action by the recent interest.

"They are friendly with Rosie, they like her and understand that she has been labouring under very difficult conditions," the source said.

The Hindujas believe their takeover bid would escape the kind of scrutiny from Britain's competition authorities likely to be imposed on the bid from DMGT.

The Hindujas' conglomerate is the biggest cable television operator in India and owns the Gulf oil business outside the United States as well as Leyland Ashok.
