fields.headline: Elizabeth Bradley
fields.standfirst: Coronation Street actress more engaging than her character
fields.trailText: Maud Grimes, the mother-in-law from hell of television's Coronation Street, was tough, rough, domineering, embitteredly disabled and altogether not an obvious candidate for socialite of the year. The actress Elizabeth Bradley, who has died aged 78 after playing the character for six years and 476 episodes - until she was written out last year - was charming, invariably courteous, bubbly, mentally sharp and physically active to the last.
fields.body:
Maud Grimes, the mother-in-law from hell of television's Coronation Street, was tough, rough, domineering, embitteredly disabled and altogether not an obvious candidate for socialite of the year. The actress Elizabeth Bradley, who has died aged 78 after playing the character for six years and 476 episodes - until she was written out last year - was charming, invariably courteous, bubbly, mentally sharp and physically active to the last.

Unlike the downmarket Maud, she was also the daughter of a senior civil servant, Sir John Abraham, who was deputy under-secretary at the Air Ministry from 1940 until he died in Winston Churchill's private plane when it crashed in 1945.

Bradley, who successfully played so many roles unlike herself, was trained in the hard school of repertory theatre, at Bexhill, Bradford and Tunbridge Wells. Late in life, she also took her place at the National Theatre and the Royal Court. On stage, she used her father's middle name, Bradley, and it stuck.

No one in her family had worked in show business, but Sir John, who had come to London from farming stock in Macclesfield, enjoyed the theatre, and delighted in taking his daughter to any performance remotely suitable for a child; from those trips her interest in theatre grew.

During the second world war, she served as a nurse. She studied at the Webber Douglas school of acting, and then went into repertory, where she met her future husband, the actor Gareth Adams, who appeared with her in several productions. In the 1950s, she stopped acting to raise her children, although, in the mid-1960s, she appeared in the Garrick Theatre production of the farce, Thark, with Kathleen Harrison.

When Gareth died suddenly in 1978, Elizabeth threw herself into a fulltime stage and television career. She was in the police series Z Cars and Softly Softly, and in a number of notable productions, such as Momento Mori and The Men's Room, as well as Casualty, Shine On Harvey Moon, The Nine Tailors, Dr Finlay's Casebook and Juliet Bravo.

She starred in David Storey's play Home, with John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson, when Dandy Nichols was taken ill, and she always gave distinctive and memorable life to her supporting roles. She joined Coronation Street in 1993.

That same year, after playing in Billy Liar at the National, she was nominated for an Olivier Award For Best Actress In A Supporting Role. At the Royal Court, she appeared in My Mother Said I Never Should, Women Beware Women, Restoration, and Touched. At the National for Sir Richard Eyre, who found her "a really fine actress and a witty and generous woman", she appeared in Abingdon Square, The Crucible, Black Snow and Caritas.

Her last stage role was as Alan Bennett's mother in the playwright's The Lady In The Van, which starred Dame Maggie Smith; her films included An American Werewolf In London (1981) and Dennis Potter's Brimstone And Treacle (1982).

She always put her resurgence as an actress down to a friend's remark after the death of her husband. He told her that Gareth had always said she would make it to the top. "I wanted to justify that and it helped ease the pain" she said.

She is survived by her three children, Brad, Johanna and Sodge.

Tony Coult writes: In 1982, Liz Bradley graced an odd little Ealingesque farce I wrote, that was being produced at the Albany Empire, Deptford. Playing a formidable, and slightly unstable, truth-saying Fen lady, she created a wonderfully solid comic centre of warmth and intelligence who eclipsed the play's faults and highlighted its occasional virtues. She performed the same service to many more accomplished writers, at the Royal Court, the National, and in the provinces. Her achievements in theatre were great; she was one of those unsung members of the profession who enrich everything they touch.

While we were in touch, she was a supportive friend who never quite understood why we all thought she was so magnificent. Tell her she was any good, and she would give you an anxious look, as if to say: "Don't believe you."

How nice that she died having a holiday. She deserved it!

Elizabeth Bradley, actress, born May 20 1922; died October 30 2000

fields.headline: Richard Keefe
fields.standfirst: Stephen Bottomore
fields.trailText: It is for his contributions to environmental film-making that the television producer Richard Keefe, who has died of a lymphona aged 51, will best be remembered. In the run-up to the 1992 Earth Summit, with his Channel 4 series How To Save The Earth (1991), he developed the theme of sustainable development; he also pioneered a hybrid, the "environmental wildlife" series, with Wild India (1992), Wild Islands (1997) and Wild Australasia (1998).
fields.body:
It is for his contributions to environmental film-making that the television producer Richard Keefe, who has died of a lymphona aged 51, will best be remembered. In the run-up to the 1992 Earth Summit, with his Channel 4 series How To Save The Earth (1991), he developed the theme of sustainable development; he also pioneered a hybrid, the "environmental wildlife" series, with Wild India (1992), Wild Islands (1997) and Wild Australasia (1998).

One of Richard's greatest talents was raising funds for such series, and these award-winning international co- productions, shot by leading wildlife cameramen, have racked up international sales. Among the single documentaries he made, Sex, Sin And Survival is arguably his finest, a plea for a humane approach to world population growth.

Keefe was a visual artist by inclination. The issues he tackled were presented in images of haunting beauty, capturing his love of the natural world and communicating his hopes for the future, often seen through children's eyes.

Richard was born in Bournemouth, and educated at Chichester high school and Bristol University, where he read geography. As head of Redknock school's English department, in Dursley, Gloucestershire, he put drama on the curriculum - which whetted his appetite for the performing arts.

In 1979-80, he went back to study radio, film and television at Bristol University. On graduating, aided by a formidable gift of the gab, he established television contacts through the BBC Nationwide programme. He then persuaded Save The Children to let him, an untried film-maker, produce a campaigning film for them. His documentary career had begun.

Richard had an abiding concern for those less fortunate than himself, particularly in the developing world, and much of the television he produced was about the problems of those societies. One of the first series he was associated with, Utopia Limited (1983), made for the then new Channel 4, included his powerful film on child mortality in South America.

A distinctive film-making style emerged. Global Village, for Horizon (1984), contained what became Keefe trademarks: beautiful visuals, a compelling narrative and an instinctive feeling for pace. This film told the story of the impact of satellite television on the Indian subcontinent, and included interviews with Arthur C Clarke and Indira Gandhi, the last broadcast interview before her assassination. It was one of the first independent productions made for the BBC.

Richard followed it with the 11-part Only One Earth (1987), co-produced with the BBC through his company, North South Productions, and bringing environment and development together for the first time for a mass television audience.

Children were important to Richard - increasingly so after the birth of his son - and reaching young minds was at the forefront of his ambitions as a producer. He made a number of series for Channel 4 Schools: the award-winning, 10-part Worlds Of Faith (1987) and Africa's Child (1999), and two series of Earth Tales dramas.

The latter demonstrated his skill in drawing out the talents of young people, further illustrated in the children's musicals he filmed, Ocean World and Song Of The Forest. In his series Stolen Childhood (1989), he highlighted child exploitation and cruelty. North South Productions made many programmes for global agencies like Unicef.

Richard was a gentle giant. I never saw him fly into a rage or treat anyone cruelly. He showed enormous loyalty to his family and employees. But, by nature, he was a broad-brush man: details were like small yapping dogs to him. A similar attitude was apparent in his style of work, for he could be extraordinarily vague and untidy. His office sometimes became an obstacle course, with books, video-cassettes and furniture scattered across the floor as if by a tropical cyclone.

Such habits exasperated employees, and yet most of us came back for more, and in business Richard could be as sharp as anyone. He had vision, and was a champion of the natural world.

He is survived by his wife Sue and son Patrick.

Richard Keefe, film-maker, born December 18 1948; died October 3 2000

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Leighton adds to portfolio
fields.body:
Leighton adds to portfolio

Wilson Connolly Holdings has named former Asda boss Allan Leighton as its new non-executive chairman and managing director John Tutte as chief executive, with effect from January 1.

Mr Leighton will succeed Lynn Wilson, who will remain on the board as non-executive deputy chairman. Mr Leighton has been a director of the company for more than five years . He recently revealed that he is planning to build a portfolio of positions, and was last month made chairman of Lastminute.com.

Names await court decision

Judgment on allegations of fraud made against Lloyd's of London by a group of Names will be given on Friday in the high court, according to a Lloyd's spokesman.

Private investors in Lloyd's, known as Names, allege that the insurance market recruited Names in the late 1970s to the late 1980s with the aim of offsetting huge US asbestos-related losses, and that those recruited were misled into becoming Names.

Lloyd's strongly denies the allegations.

Virgin launches Australian arm

Virgin Group announced the launch of its second mobile phone company -Virgin Mobile Australia.

The business which already employs 175 people is a joint venture with Cable & Wireless Optus.

Virgin also confirmed that it will launch Virgin Mobile Asia next year in partnership with Singapore Telecom, to be followed by a roll-out of the brand in the US, Japan and Europe within two years.

Shire's revenue rises 30%

Britain's Shire Pharmaceuticals announced a 30% rise in third-quarter revenues at $137.8m (£94m) yesterday, a week after it joined the main FTSE 100 index.

Shire, also listed on the Nasdaq, said its income before tax and accounting charges related to stock options to employees stood at $33.5m from $20.1m.

The company's flagship products, Adderall and DextroStat, which treats attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, reported sales of $62.1m, compared with 63% over the third quarter of last year.

Adderall and DextroStat had a combined 36% share of prescriptions in the US in September from 27.3% last year.

NAPF backs options rules

The National Association of Pension Funds yesterday backed attempts by the Accounting Standards Board to make companies which award options to directors to show the impact on their profits.

However, the NAPF suggested that the rules should not be implemented ahead of other countries and that companies should be allowed to adopt the controversial policy only for new schemes rather than ones already in place.

webTitle: BAT chief mounts attack on regulators

fields.headline: BAT chief mounts attack on regulators
fields.trailText: BAT yesterday attacked regulators for suffocating the industry and admitted it was disappointed to be under investigation by the government over alleged smuggling links.
fields.body:
BAT yesterday attacked regulators for suffocating the industry and admitted it was disappointed to be under investigation by the government over alleged smuggling links.

Martin Broughton, the chairman, said calls for global legislation and universal tax rules championed by the World Health Authority and European Union were "invariably unworkable".

Speaking after the decision by trade secretary Stephen Byers to send in a team of Department of Trade and Industry investigators, he said: "The stark choice facing regulators is whether to continue with their battle against the industry leaders, cheered on by a chorus of single issue pressure groups, or to engage in more constructive debate."

BAT, the world's second largest tobacco manufacturer, said pretax profits, including exceptionals, were slightly up at £1.2bn for the nine months to September 30, with adjusted earnings per share up 8% at 42.57p.

However, comparable cigarette sales, without the contribution of the Rothmans acquisition, fell 3% in a "stagnant" world market. Lucky Strike, Dunhill and John Player Gold Leaf sold well.

BAT shares were down 15p, or 2.6%, to 483p last night.

fields.headline: A&L to cut 1,500 jobs
fields.trailText: Alliance & Leicester is to shed up to 1,500 jobs - 20% of its staff - over the next three years. The company hopes to cut costs by £100m and prove to the City that its small size does not mean it is vulnerable to takeover.
fields.body:
Alliance & Leicester is to shed up to 1,500 jobs - 20% of its staff - over the next three years. The company hopes to cut costs by £100m and prove to the City that its small size does not mean it is vulnerable to takeover.

Peter McNamara, the bank's managing director hired from Lloyds TSB, insisted redundancies would be kept to a minimum by reallocating staff to "growth" areas.

Under the strategic review unveiled yesterday, the five executive directors of the former building society will forgo pay rises for two years, but instead link their remuneration in cash and shares to their performance over three years.

The bank, as part of a plan to boost its revenues by 6% a year, also tried to inject further competition into the battle for current account customers by launching a new Alliance Premier Account.

The product, which the bank said would make the average customer £500 a year better off, follows attempts by Halifax to wrest customers from the "big four" clearing banks and is part of A&L's strategy to launch one new product a month under the "Alliance" brand.

The bank is also using its brand to assault the small business banking market in which it wants to win a 10% market share, up from 2%, by the end of 2003.

John Windeler, A&L's executive chairman, said: "In the past the big ate the small; in the future the fast will eat the slow." The bank's shares rose more than 5% to £5.89 as analysts disagreed over whether the cost cutting exercise would be achieved or whether it was a sign the bank was priming itself for takeover.

If A&L fails to meet its ambitious targets, which include spending £140m over the next three years on new technology to "web-enable" itself, the directors' pay will fall. This expenditure will knock £60m off its profits in 2001 and £30m this year.

Analysts said the bank had set itself a tough target of increasing its revenues by 6% per annum in the coming three years. Mr McNamara admitted that to achieve its goal the bank would need to boost sales of its products by 50% over the period. The bank has hired KPMG to help it carry though the exercise.

fields.headline: Footsie welcome for Autonomy
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software company, yesterday came back to Britain to be listed on the London Stock Exchange.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software company, yesterday came back to Britain to be listed on the London Stock Exchange.

The hi-tech company which has been listed on New York's Nasdaq and Brussels' Easdaq but was dismissed as too small and speculative to list in London two years ago, looks likely to break into the FTSE 100 index at the December review. The company, which sells software that sorts the masses of unstructured information floating around the internet, was yesterday valued at £4.7bn.

The listing provides an opportunity for long-term investors, such as seed investor Apax Partners, and chief executive and managing director Mike Lynch to sell parts of their holdings.

Dr Lynch, whose father was a fireman and mother a nurse, yesterday cashed in on his company's success by selling just over 1% of his holding, leaving him with an 18% stake and about £47.4m in his hand. He said: "It is great to be able to come back home and list in London."

Yesterday it emerged that Dr Lynch, who won a scholarship to study at Cambridge University, had shaved off his beard for a bet. He has been reported as saying that the company's goal is to be in almost every piece of software in two years' time.

Yesterday's listing means Autonomy's stock will now be available to funds that are able to buy only shares listed on London markets.

Autonomy, which raised $124m of funding in May when it floated on the Nasdaq, priced its secondary offering at £32.76 per share, which values the offer, at the plac ing price, at about £218m. The offering was more than six times oversubscribed and the shares, all sold by existing shareholders, and none of them newly issued, were placed with institutional investors. The investors sold 6.7m shares, about 5% of the company.

Autonomy's share price yesterday closed at £35.8, up from £32.76, with 5.5m shares being traded. The company's shares have risen by more than six times during the last year, outperforming the hi-tech Easdaq by four times.

The company, which is profitable and, according to Mr Lynch, generates $5m a quarter in cash, has $128m in the bank.

Autonomy, which was formed in 1997, first floated in July 1998. It employs 157 people. Customers for the technology include Oracle, Sun Microsystems and General Motors. The technology the company has created can understand the ideas and concepts within texts by looking at the mathematical patterns in the prose. After reaching an "understanding" the technology is able to realise who needs to look at the information, can send it on to the right person and can also link it to other relevant information.

According to sector research, the market for unstructured data, at which the Autonomy technology is pitched, is forecast to grow from £1.7bn in 1999 to £8bn in 2003.

Autonomy will keep its Easdaq listing, but pricing will shift from dollars to pounds to reflect the London stock.

webTitle: Fighting words as Britpop stars collect their gongs

fields.headline: Fighting words as Britpop stars collect their gongs
fields.trailText: Big names in rock'n'roll proved at the Q Awards in London yesterday that while British pop may be on the ropes it is not quite out.
fields.body:
Big names in rock'n'roll proved at the Q Awards in London yesterday that while British pop may be on the ropes it is not quite out.

Despite the declining singles market, the likes of Oasis, their arch-rival Robbie Williams and the Chemical Brothers were in the mood to celebrate at the 11th annual event, staged by Britain's biggest selling music monthly.

Q's 196,000 sales put it 50% ahead of its nearest rival in a sector that has been in a slump since the mid-1990s, and its success guaranteed a high celebrity count.

The famous are drawn as much by the likelihood of seeing other famous people make fools of themselves as by the gold trophies. This year, with both Oasis and Williams nominated, promised to be memorable. Liam Gallagher did not disappoint his audience, receiving Oasis's best live act gong with the comment: "This one's for Robbie, as usual. Fuck off."

Afterwards Gallagher, who is dating Williams's former fiancee, Nicole Appleton of All Saints, said: "I don't hate him, I just think he's rubbish. If he slags my band off, he slags my girlfriend off and he slags my brother off, I'll have him."

Collecting the classic songwriter award, Williams said: "I'm just going to keep my gob shut."

Few others did. This year's surprise hits, Coldplay, accepted best album by inviting best newcomer, Badly Drawn Boy, outside for a fight, while Blur's Alex James bickered with Liam Gallagher.

Kylie Minogue, who performs with Williams on his current hit, threatened to slap Gallagher when he heckled her. Perhaps their tetchiness was provoked by a report in the trade magazine Music Week that singles sales are down 22% on last year, while the top selling album of 2000, Play by Moby, was released in 1999. It has been such a slack year that the lifetime achievement award was suspended because organisers could not find anyone willing to turn up for it.

"It was supposed to be Bob Dylan, but they couldn't get him," said an insider. It would not have been enough for Dylan to send his best wishes on video: "They have to come in person."

The former Clash frontman Joe Strummer, a fit 48, was applauded when he admitted that his inspiration gong was the first he had received in a 25-year career.

Even the Gallaghers were silenced when he said his talent was dwarfed by that of The Who, with whom he is on tour. Such generosity is not the norm at award events.

Other winners such as David Gray, best single, and Travis, best act, confirmed that after years of domination by dance music, rock is making a comeback. The winners were decided by 12,000 Q readers.

fields.headline: Insulted Rainier turns on France
fields.standfirst: Monaco threatens to declare independence from neighbour
fields.trailText: The mouse roared yesterday when tiny Monaco threatened to throw off French tutelage and "endow the principality with full sovereignty".
fields.body:
The mouse roared yesterday when tiny Monaco threatened to throw off French tutelage and "endow the principality with full sovereignty".

Prince Rainier III, who began his reign in 1949, ruled out war with France to enforce his unilateral declaration of independence, but said he was determined to seek total freedom from French control in retaliation for accusations that Monaco was a paradise for drug dealers and tax evaders.

The Mediterranean principality, covering less than one square mile, is linked to France by "friendly protectorate" treaties. Fiscal, political and judicial liberties were dramatically reduced in 1963.

Prince Rainier's power is kept in check by an executive which is headed by the French ambassador, while French appointees hold key roles in the judicial and economic systems.

The Prince's sudden emergence into international politics at the age of 77 amounted to a showdown between the French Socialist government and one of the world's most powerful financial networks.

More than three quarters of the population are super-rich foreigners - including about 1,400 Britons - taking advantage of generous tax concessions and Riviera sunshine.

Last month, following a parliamentary investigation into allegedly fraudulent activities, France told Monaco to introduce wide-ranging reforms, which posed a particular threat to the 12,000 French tax refugees in the principality and to hundreds of businesses using Monaco to flout French tax laws.

Among the demands was the call for the imposition of a super tax on personal fortunes and company profits.

French officials yesterday demanded an explanation for the prince's reaction, which amounted to a categorical refusal to buckle under.

"I'm not going to declare war on France but Paris must respect us, something they haven't been doing for months," the prince said in interviews in Nice-Matin and Le Figaro.

"The accusations made against us are completely false. The way the French government used the media to make its charges public and the tone and form they were given show a deliberate determination to blacken the principality's image."

The prince said diplomatic action would be taken to "dust off" old treaties so that he could "give back Monaco to the Monégasques".

He added: "The treaties between the wars were drawn up when France feared that Monaco would become a German-influenced base. There is no reason today why Paris should intervene massively in our domestic affairs. Paris is the only capital to accuse us of money-laundering. We're fed up being treated as drug dealers."

The prince, whose wife, Princess Grace, died after a car accident in 1982, took Monaco insiders by surprise with his outburst. Since 1963, he has made no attempt to defy France, preferring instead to concentrate on economic development by attracting worldwide investment. He has also encouraged a glossy showbusiness image.

Prince Rainier's apparent complacency over French control was linked to constant rumours that he was ill and ready to abdicate in favour of his bachelor son, Prince Albert, 42.

But he said in the newspaper interviews that Prince Albert needed to have an heir before he could take the throne. "I do not want to hang on to my function for life. Prince Albert has all the qualities to become one day the next sovereign prince. But, beforehand, I would like him to have an heir because that is essential for the future of the principality and of our family," he said.

The land of plenty

 Granted independent status in 1191 with the vocation of defending Christianity against the Saracens, Monaco has been ruled by the Grimaldi family for more than 700 years.

 In 1993, the principality was made a UN member.

 Only 5,000 residents - out of a population of 30,000 -have Monégasque nationality. The remainder include 12,000 French citizens and 5,000 Italians.

 Intense building, much of it on reclaimed land, has changed the economy of the only city, Monte Carlo , over the past 50 years. Most of its wealth now comes from banking and tourism.

 The principality's casino, founded in 1856, once the main source of revenue, provides only about 4% of Monaco's annual income.

 Legislative power is shared between Prince Rainier, who has more than a dozen other titles, and an 18-member elected national council. The executive is controlled by a French-appointed minister of state.

 The security forces are made up of a ceremonial army unit, which is not issued with ammunition, and 400 police, who are nearly all French nationals.

webTitle: War and Peace too long, say singers

fields.headline: War and Peace too long, say singers
fields.trailText: The cannons on the stage of the Bastille Opera in Paris may finally be in fighting form tonight for the first performance this year of Prokofiev's War and Peace, cancelled repeatedly because the chorus claims the four-hour work is too long.
fields.body:
The cannons on the stage of the Bastille Opera in Paris may finally be in fighting form tonight for the first performance this year of Prokofiev's War and Peace, cancelled repeatedly because the chorus claims the four-hour work is too long.

Audiences may not be sure until the last minute whether a temporary agreement will allow the lavish opera to go ahead.

A recreation of Tolstoy's masterpiece, in which Napoleonic and Tsarist troops fight pitched battles in blizzards, the production needs so much rehearsal time that the 43-strong chorus claims that going on stage would contravene the government's new universal 35-hour working week.

More than half of all French workers already benefit from the restricted hours of work. Most unions have settled for a shorter working day, days off or more holidays.

The chorus, which has 98 members at full strength, including many Russians, wants at least 10 days extra holiday a year to compensate for a programme of more than 300 performances at the Bastille and the 19th century Palais Garnier. So far, they have been offered only five days.

"War and Peace is a classic example of the way less glamorous cast members are put under a moral obligation to work indefinite hours supposedly in the interests of art when the real reasons are economic," a chorus member said.

Whether or not shots at the Bastille will be fired in anger on stage, rather than off stage, could depend on the settlement of a behind-the-scenes row between the government and the Bastille Opera's director, Hugues Gall.

He staved off a potential economic disaster when both state theatres were threatened with prolonged closure by excessive production costs and industrial action by technicians. But he is considered too authoritarian by the culture minister, Catherine Tasca.

fields.headline: Allied Domecq to cut costs
fields.trailText: Allied Domecq, the drinks group, has lined up a further round of cost-cutting despite reporting a 14% increase in annual profits yesterday.
fields.body:
Allied Domecq, the drinks group, has lined up a further round of cost-cutting despite reporting a 14% increase in annual profits yesterday.

The company says it can save a further £7m worth of costs by integrating sales forces, contracting out functions and trimming overheads at regional offices. It would not say how many jobs would be lost.

Allied, which closed its London base last year to concentrate administration in Bristol, increased its spirits and wine marketing expenditure from £275m to £301m over the year to 31 August this year.

The advertising blitz fed demand for Ballantine's whisky and Beefeater gin which played a leading role in producing annual pretax profits of £413m. Group turnover, including contributions from its Dunkin Donuts quick service restaurants declined from £3.5bn to £2.6bn following the sale of its UK retail interests and John Bull pubs.

Sales of Ballentine's rose 8% and Kahlua was up 9% worldwide, while Beefeater was up 10% in Europe. The only disappointment came from Sauz tequila as volumes fell 19%.

Shares in the company declined 6.75p to £35.25 last night. Analysts warned the share price would remain restrained until the outcome of the Seagram liquor sale in Canada was known.

Ian Shackleton, analyst at CSFB, believes Allied is in poll position for Seagram against rival Diageo after Friday's announcement it had tied up a deal with Destilleria Serralles giving Allied an option to buy the Captain Morgan brand.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: From jail to Genesis
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Everyman | Home Front | The Bill
fields.body:
Just when you think born-again Christians are actually quite nice, they go and spoil it all by reverting to type. Unhappily - especially for Grace, the subject of Everyman (BBC1) - type is hypocritical, unforgiving, sanctimonious fundamentalists with absolutely no grasp of what JC Superstar meant when he said "Love thy neighbour." They may play guitars and clap their hands but so did Status Quo and it didn't make them good people either.

Grace was released from prison after serving 18 years of a mandatory life sentence for stabbing a man to death. Then a booze-swilling, drug-using prostitute, on her release she was a born-again Christian married to a troubled but loving man, Anthony, and determined to do and be good in a world that probably doesn't deserve her. Armed with her faith, a ferret and £81 in cash, Grace's release and her subsequent struggles made for an extraordinary, honest and moving story which was more than done justice by a mature, considered and technically accomplished documentary.

With insights from Gitta Sereny and Kent's chief probation officer, Grace's personal journey became a wider exploration and insight into the plight of those released from prison who seek to stay straight. With the excellent Pete Postlethwaite mesmerising in The Sins and Lord Woolf's judgement on Jon Venables and Robert Thompson, Everyman couldn't have come at a better time to contribute to the discussion of life after crime, the shortsightedness of the rabid, hang 'em reactionaries and how civilised (or not) a society we are.

As Grace learned to adjust to a world nearly two decades older than when she left it, her faith and spirit frequently tested, it was made apparent that her chosen church was abandoning her. Volunteering to help run a playgroup for the children of her fellow Christians, Grace was rejected by the elders because they felt she couldn't be trusted. While it is understandable they fear headlines like "Crazy Christians Hire Murderess As Nanny", as people who purport to be religious, they should be ashamed of their ignorant, unchristian behaviour.

When her relationship with Anthony also started to falter, it was hard not to feel for Grace, who more than lived up to her name. As she poured her heart out on a roundabout in the park (these things happen in the strangest places), she cried. She wasn't the only one. As they say in the Bible, Jesus wept.

At least you know where you are with a Satanist. And you are probably in a scary place with lots of black drapes, candles, a pentagram on the floor and an inverted cross on the wall somewhere. Such a delightful scene brings us neatly to Home Front (BBC2), specifically the new-look Home Front which is presented by Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen and Diarmuid Gavin.

Playing their odd-couple roles with abandon (Laurence in full ponce mode, Diarmuid the louche, scruffy Irishman), the pair actually did quite a nice job in transforming a living-dining room and garden, despite their atrocious track records and tendency to speak utter designer gibberish. Personal style is like advertising yourself, Laurence explained in a frightfully outré suit, while draggletailed Diarmuid upbraided his colleague for spouting tosh. "I am amazed that people let you get away with it." Thus spoke a nation, or at least those of us who would consider Laurence an OTT designer and the human equivalent of bromide to boot. I mean, who are the people that voted him among the country's sexiest men?

The worst thing about the new Home Front wasn't Laurence, Diarmuid or the apparent stupidity of council planning departments, who can grant permission for the building of a multi-storey car park but veto shiny metal tiles in someone's back garden, but the fact that it wasn't the old Home Front with the lovely Tessa. Curly-haired and often preggers, Tessa always spoke as if she was about to have a fit of the giggles, whether she was stippling, rag-rolling or just chatting with Jocasta Innes.

Even when Anne McKevitt wasn't sticking blue fake fur to window frames or gluing rude seaside postcards to toilet seats to complete a bathroom's nautical theme, Tessa was on the verge of lilting laughter. That she - like Don Beech in The Bill (ITV) - is never to be seen again would be too much to bear. It may be time to start a Bring Back Tessa campaign. Just don't let La McKevitt make the banners.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What aerobics teachers are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What aerobics teachers are watching on TV.
fields.body:
Sal Warner: "I find I'm working for most of the day and that I don't watch TV like I did when I was a teenager. I used to watch it all then. I was a Neighbours nut, I remember Kylie and Jason getting married! Last thing I watched? I'd say I watch a lot of films. I think it was the one about that porn giant? Courtney Love is in it, I thought she was very good. I don't really like her very much but I think she can act."

Kay Barnes: "I used to watch all those Green Goddess things on breakfast TV, thinking, 'I'll never do that!' and here I am, wiggling around all day! I do get some of the videos that those supermodels do. I've got a keen eye to see what other people do and how they teach people - it can be very sloppy. Elle McPherson and Cindy Crawford workouts often seem just for the male audience! I like TV that is just on in the background. I've got all the Friends videos and I get them out which my boyfriend moans at, but I think he likes them really."

Chenil Dodson: "I watch EastEnders. I'm definitely hooked on that story about Sonia's baby (pictured), it really gets to me. I don't know why, it just must be so terrible to give birth to a baby you didn't know you were going to have. We talk about it, me and my friends, all the time! I think it gets the girls. I think EastEnders is really good at the moment, people slag it off but it really reflects the way people are and the messes they get into. I don't think it's extreme, no. I also liked The Knock with Martine McCutcheon. She was very good. Can't stand those records she makes though."

Charlie Ginn: "I watch videos or I watch cable TV, Sky and that. I watch the motor racing. No it's not boring, it's very good! I like sport, I just do, I always have. You get all these ponces like Frank Skinner talking about it but you can tell he doesn't like it, or watch it with the lads - 'scuse my language but I really dislike him. I think he's a pretender."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Moby Dick | Plein Soleil | Hidden Agenda | The Apostle
fields.body:
Moby Dick
(John Huston, 1956)
9am, Carlton Cinema

Gregory Peck is the main weakness of Huston's ambitious attempt at Melville's classic novel: a fine actor, but no shadow in the soul to suggest the demonic depths of Captain Ahab's pursuit of the white whale. There are plenty of plusses though: the rest of the cast (including Richard Basehart, Orson Welles, Leo Genn); the early, gliding menace of the creature; the breathtaking whaling scenes; and sci-fi writer Ray Bradbury's screenplay, which preserves Melville's gripping narrative and epic sweep.

Plein Soleil
(René Clément, 1959)
6pm, FilmFour

Interesting to see Clément's thriller in the light of Anthony Minghella's recent adaptation of the same novel, Patricia Highsmith's The Talented Mr Ripley. The young Alain Delon (pictured) is an altogether icier presence as Ripley, who conceives a plan to murder the industrialist's dissolute son (Maurice Ronet) and grab the money and the girl (Marie Laforêt): a clever and chilly drama.

Hidden Agenda
(Ken Loach, 1990)
8pm, FilmFour

Hardly surprising that Loach's stern lecture on Northern Ireland kicked up a storm of controversy. It tells the story of Brian Cox's Stalker-esque CID man investigating the murder in Belfast of American civil rights campaigner Brad Dourif and turning up skeletons in CIA and British Intelligence cupboards - plots to undermine the Wilson and Heath governments, that sort of thing. Cox is at his pugnacious best and is assisted by Frances McDormand as the dead man's fiancée; but the real punch is supplied by Jim Allen's uncompromising script.

The Apostle
(Robert Duvall, 1997)
3.10am, Sky Premier

Thirteen years in the making, Duvall's labour of love is the story of Pentecostal preacher Sonny Dewey, on the road to salvation after hitting his wife's lover with a baseball bat. Hitting the road too, he winds up in a Louisiana backwater where he sets up his own church. It's an ideal role for Duvall.

webTitle: Whatever Brown says, there IS a tooth fairy

fields.headline: Whatever Brown says, there IS a tooth fairy
fields.standfirst: Eternal battle of probity v politics
fields.trailText: Politics has its own seasonal rhythm, so when ministers intone gravely in the autumn that they see no room for tax cuts in the spring, the wise observer takes this warning with a large pinch of salt. When the commitment to Gladstonian fiscal probity comes as the parties are gearing up for a general election, it is time to dispense with the pinch and opt for a handful instead.
fields.body:
Politics has its own seasonal rhythm, so when ministers intone gravely in the autumn that they see no room for tax cuts in the spring, the wise observer takes this warning with a large pinch of salt. When the commitment to Gladstonian fiscal probity comes as the parties are gearing up for a general election, it is time to dispense with the pinch and opt for a handful instead.

The facts - such as they are - of the current spat between Michael Portillo and Gordon Brown over tax and spending are as follows. Labour plans to increase public spending by £68bn in the next three years, the Conservatives plan to spend an extra £60bn, siphoning off the other £8bn into tax cuts. The government, seeking to draw distinct battle lines in the run-up to polling day, portrays this as a choice between higher public spending on the one hand against lower taxes on the other.

Politics being politics, things are not quite that simple. Back in the late 1980s, Nigel Lawson was fond of accompanying increases in public spending in the autumn with forecasts which suggested that this left little opportunity for tax cuts. By massaging down the projected size of the Treasury's budget surplus in the autumn, Lawson could then reveal the true picture in the spring, making it seem as though he was as surprised as anybody to find that the government could afford to slice a couple of pence off the basic rate of income tax.

Labour has learned from Lawson's experience. The chief secretary, Andrew Smith, has been ruling out tax cuts in the next parliament, but the Treasury - and every analyst in the City - knows that the size of the chancellor's budget surplus will be at least three times as large as the £5bn he was forecasting in March. Moreover, the better than expected outcome will not be the result of an overheated economy - as it was in the late 1980s - but derives from a structural improvement in the nation's finances.

Tony Blair would like to hold an election in the spring, which means that the Budget will be the springboard for Labour's campaign. The idea that the prime minister and his chancellor will use a surplus of perhaps £20bn to pay down the national debt rather than to butter up the electorate is too fanciful for words. Whatever Labour says now, there will be tax cuts. The only question is how big they will be.

EasyBet

It is not often that a man facing manslaughter charges seeks to float his business on the London market for around £750m. But then anyone who has had the Luton airport experience will know that Stelios Haji-Ioannou, founder of EasyJet and various other Easy-branded wheezes, is a rare type in the world of business.

The charges, brought in Italy and rekindled by the public prosecutor there just three days ago, relate to an oil tanker which sank off Genoa nine years ago, killing a number of crew members and causing serious environmental damager. Mr Haji-Ioannou is snared by the legal action since, at the age of 24, he was working with his shipping magnate father, at the time.

The disclosure, published in EasyJet's pathfinder prospectus yesterday, will not deter the institutions being lined up by investment bankers CSFB and UBS to support the low-cost airline's move to market in two weeks' time, raising something close to £200m in new money.

In fact, fund managers are likely to find the document a refreshing read. It amounts to a warts-and-all description of a business that has been built in double-quick time and which threatens to carry on growing at an exponential rate for the foreseeable future. Aside from all the usual risk factors and caveats, the level of operational detail provided on the day-to-day running of EasyJet is extraordinary. And yes, under "Litigation," prospective investors can read all about Mr Haji-Ioannou's highly publicised spats with British Airways and the Luton airport authorities.

Assessing the value of this business, and the market's likely reaction, is no mean feat. In fact, CSFB and UBS are clearly still struggling since the indicative price range for the global book building has been set at an extravagantly-wide 250p-350p a share - a spread the advisers blame on market volatility.

On the bald figures, the issue looks fairly priced, with a mid-point prospective price/earnings ratio of 22 times suggesting the shares are being offered at a discount of more than 30% to EasyJet's cheap'n'cheerful rival, Ryanair. In fact, the stock does not look much more expensive than sluggish old British Airways.

Retail punters, sadly, are locked out of this flotation, with all the stock going to institutions. But for any size of investor, this issue is not really about comparable valuations and the like. It is about whether this bucaneering entrepreneur, who wants all his staff to get rich on options and who will stand up and scream if his commercial interests are threatened, deserves personal backing. And in the interests of a more colourful world, the answer has got be be "yes."

webTitle: TV and Radio: rock stars stopped shocking

fields.headline: Naughty, naughty
fields.standfirst: Last week, Canadian politicians tried to ban Eminem from performing, claiming his lyrics were offensive. But the truth is that few people are really offended by rock stars' posturing any more. How things have changed.
fields.trailText: Last week, Canadian politicians tried to ban Eminem from performing, claiming his lyrics were offensive. But the truth is that few people are really offended by rock stars' posturing any more. How things have changed.
fields.body:
If you fancy a trip to Canada soon, don't let slip at customs that you think Jennifer Lopez is saucy. Or that you've had a row with your mum. Or that you rap in a voice like Choo Choo from Top Cat. Pity poor Eminem, who was almost barred from the country for being guilty of all the above, the powers that be deeming that such a dangerous personality could incite panic on the streets of Ottawa.

No doubt Eminem is gleefully rubbing his hands - publicity this good can't be bought. Plus, the music media are over the moon; rock'n'roll is still officially dangerous! Of course, what the authorities find offensive is pretty different to everyone else's opinion. No one (apart from maybe his mum and Puff Daddy) could be shocked by Eminem's records.

But we can hardly point and laugh at the Canadians when the BBC have such a wonderful track record. They've been banning records since 1969, a golden age when The Kinks' Plastic Man received no airplay for its inclusion of the word "bum", and Serge Gainsbourg and Jane Birkin's heavy-breathing opus Je T'Aime... Moi Non Plus met a similar fate (the deadpan cynicism of the full title is still impressively cheeky, but that was surely lost on the Beeb). They clamped down on D Mob's dangerously weedy We Call It Acid in 1988 while happily spinning The La's' There She Goes, a joyous love song to smack. And, oddly enough, they didn't show Eminem on Top Of The Pops when he hit number one in the summer because Brian May and Five had turned up at the last minute with an "exclusive" performance. No explanation was offered.

With cheap publicity so easy to come by, no wonder PJ Proby moved over here from the States in 1964. A few carelessly placed rips in his velvet trousers prior to a concert in Croydon and he was front-page news. Ten years later Lou Reed was shooting up on stage. John Lennon could upset the apple cart with a little more class - when asked at a US press conference who Eleanor Rigby was written about he replied: "two queers".

After recording in Berlin and immersing himself in Nietzsche, David Bowie caused a stink by giving a Nazi salute at Victoria station on his return. Paul Weller came up with the cretinous line "I think this 'change the world' thing is becoming a bit trendy" as an excuse for voting Tory in 1979. Both were oddly forgiven. Kula Shaker were less fortunate when singer Crispian Mills said he'd like to appear on stage in front of a flaming swastika.

Of course it's still possible for pop to shock and offend, just not in the trad Keith Moon, telly-out-the-window fashion. Chuck Berry may be notorious for doing time after transferring a minor across state borders in the late 50s, but while his fans may find this most cool, most rock, the police uncovered something altogether uglier when they raided his house in the 90s. Berry had set up a camera to film visitors using his toilet, though the only ones that made it into his collection were the white female visitors. Also there were photographs of him lying on the floor with ladies going to the toilet on his face. Not nice. Drugs may be cool to some, but poo isn't, ever, to anyone.

The panto-goth antics of Marilyn Manson that, incredibly, seem to have genuinely disturbed America are put in the shade by the spirit of 1977. When punk was still young and stupid, Eater, fronted by 15-year-old Andy Blade, were about to have a gig filmed by Don Letts. They obtained a pig's head from a mate who worked in a butcher's and chopped it up on stage. It took forever, and punters at the front were more concerned with Dee Generate electrocuting himself by cutting through a cable than they were by the poor pig.

So much for heavy metal staples, but would Slipknot or Limp Bizkit ever release a single called Pretty Paedophiles? It was all in a day's work for the charmingly named Raped. Even Rough Trade shied away from stocking this one. The Raped were glamorous, they had a guitarist called Fabian Kwest, and singer Sean Purcell looked a true star, kind of like a beaten up Billy Idol. What's more, the records were great. Yet closer to the edge were sonic terrorists Throbbing Gristle. Their Twenty Jazz-Funk Greats album included a song called Persuasion, an electronic drone over which Genesis P Orridge talked to a small girl - "I'm going to keep your knickers in a biscuit tin".

Airplay was thin on the ground.

Some would make a claim for the rude raps of Foxy Brown and Lil' Kim as the most shockable pop moves today, but as Louis Theroux was told by a horrified gangsta rapper "You can't use the word 'vagina' on an American record!" My vote goes coincidentally to a Canadian. When Bryan Adams bought a house in Chelsea a few years ago, the pub next door was a little noisy for his tastes, so the humourless rocker bought the place and shut it. Bryan Adams, a true danger to society. They shouldn't let him back.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Two linked comedy dramas by Alan Plater appear as the Afternoon Play today and tomorrow. Only A Matter Of Time (2.15pm, Radio 4) finds Fanshawe in the Welsh borders early in the 19th century explaining to Meredith, a deeply sceptical farmworker, the imminent wonders of Mr Brunel's new railway. Not least of the benefits, of course, will be the arrival of London time. A sparkling text is splendidly played by James Bolam (pictured) and Alan David. Tomorrow's instalment (equally entertaining) continues the action 150 years later.

All Saints' Day is celebrated with a unique transmission of Choral Vespers (4pm, Radio 3) from the Benedictine Abbey of Solesmes in Normandy. It is the first time this community of 100 monks has ever allowed one of its services to be broadcast, a decision made only after several years of negotiation. The monks are renowned for their traditional Gregorian chant, which regularly attracts hundreds of Christian pilgrims from around the world.

webTitle: Arts: Review of Road to Heaven

fields.headline: The old pretenders
fields.standfirst: A crowd of octogenarians singing Satisfaction? Doesn't sound too promising. But, says Lyn Gardner, Road to Heaven is challenging, ground-breaking - and tender.
fields.trailText: A crowd of octogenarians singing Satisfaction? Doesn't sound too promising. But, says Lyn Gardner, Road to Heaven is challenging, ground-breaking - and tender.
fields.body:
Six white beds or cots stand vacant at the back of the stage like empty coffins. In one corner a doctor in a wheelchair and a couple of nurses huddle around a radio. There is a clap of thunder. The stage is suddenly filled with a crowd of very old people acting as if they are very young.

They look as if they have just raided a dressing-up box. Some wear crowns and elaborate 18th-century-style wigs made from paper. Some of the men are dressed like cowboys: one wears chaps that look as if they have been fashioned out of grass; another's are made of fake ponyskin.

A dumpy little woman dressed all in white steps up to the microphone and starts singing I Know What Time It Is Now. The notes rise like balloons, weightless and pure. The light reflects off her granny specs and her wizened-walnut face suddenly looks as smooth as a baby's. There is something desperately childlike about her. As the last notes die away, a nurse appears and gently leads her away. She shuffles along, suddenly old all over again.

The old lady has barely departed before an octogenarian in drag, his eyelashes fluttering like butterflies, launches into Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend. At the end he whips off his platinum wig to reveal a polished bald head winking in the light.

If a bunch of pensioners singing songs by the Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Elvis Presley and the Clash isn't high on the list of things that you are keen to experience, you are not alone. I have to admit that I too had my doubts about Road to Heaven - a show performed by 23 Americans aged between 70 and 90 who call themselves the Young @ Heart Chorus - despite the fact that it has become a cult hit in mainland Europe and the US.

But at the Restless Gravity festival in Aberystwyth last weekend, bemusement gave way to fascination, and fascination to emotion. By the show's carefully calculated end, a large proportion of the audience - aged roughly between five and 90 - were on their feet, weeping and clapping. And it wasn't just at the sight of someone old enough to be a grandfather doing It's Not Unusual, or a crowd of senior citizens giving a deadpan rendition of Satisfaction. After all, Tom Jones will soon be queuing up for his bus pass and some of the Stones are grandparents. There is more to Road to Heaven than the elderly making a spectacle of themselves.

When the show opens in London tonight under the auspices of the London International Festival of Theatre (Lift), it will raise debate about not only our perceptions of old people but also about the nature of theatre itself - what it is, who it is for and who can do it. It is not by chance that Road to Heaven is the opening salvo in a new Lift initiative that sees the festival move from being a biennial affair to taking its place as a regular year-round producer.

Over the past 20 years, Lift's championing of international theatre and home-grown site-specific pieces has done more than anything else to change British ideas about theatre's place in our culture. Road to Heaven is part of that debate, a show that on paper should make you cringe but actually makes you cheer.

The Young @ Heart Chorus began in 1981 as an activity at a lunch club for poor pensioners in Northampton, Massachusetts. The food was so dreary that organiser Bob Cilman decided to liven things up with a piano and a singsong. That lead to community shows. But it was the arrival of Roy Faudree, an associate of the avant-garde American theatre collective the Wooster Group who also runs his own company, No Theater, that took Young @ Heart into a new dimension.

Faudree was interested in the idea of the elderly as potential artists, and wondered what would happen if, instead of singing pre-war golden-oldie standards, the chorus sang pop songs - the very songs that many of them had told their own children and grandchildren to turn down during the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s. Would the glib lyrics penned by youngsters mean something different and fresh if sung by the very old?

Faudree explains it this way: "If you put an ashtray on a table, it is just an ashtray. If you put a torn glove beside it, it becomes drama. With this show I was trying to create a dramatic landscape and startling juxtapositions." How far it works can be seen from a song such as I Will Survive, which is transformed from a strutting disco anthem into something both absurdly tender and defiant when sung by a frail 80-year-old.

Although Road to Heaven uses material culled from previous Young @ Heart shows, its crazy quilt effect is all the more powerful because of the way Faudree frames the show. It is set on the geriatric ward of a hospital or in an old people's home, and a conductor tries to drill the chorus into shape, into some kind of homogeneous whole. But it is the individuality of each member of the chorus that stands out, even down to the way that their lumpy, bumpy bodies - quite unlike the sleek-toned forms we are so used to seeing on stage - refuse to be invisible. In their Elvis Presley costumes, or perhaps dressed up as bees, these people show a kind of don't-give-a-damn defiance that you normally associate only with very young children. As Lucy Neal of Lift says: "Part of the appeal of the show is that it is deliciously improper."

After years of involvement Faudree says he still can't put his finger on why audiences respond so strongly to Young @ Heart, or even why he himself remains involved with the project when he is much in demand elsewhere as a director. "I think it is because every time I go into rehearsal with these people and I am feeling tired and distracted I end up in a good mood. There is something joyous about it, and that's what the audience gets too. Bob Cilman has a theory that the reason the audience reacts so positively is because it makes them confront their own mortality."

Certainly, Road to Heaven is a rare acknowledgement that none of us is as young as we were and that we are all dying. But hell, we can have some fun as we do. Road to Heaven suggests that old age doesn't have to be all Zimmer frames and regret. When the chorus sings Forever Young it doesn't sound like wishful thinking. It sounds like a manifesto, a statement of intent, a wake-up call.

 At the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6 (020-8741 2311), from November 1-4.

fields.headline: Court in the act
fields.standfirst: Some of the most notorious Troubles trials took place at Belfast's Crumlin Road Courthouse. Now, finds Mic Moroney, it's home to outstanding drama
fields.trailText: Some of the most notorious Troubles trials took place at Belfast's Crumlin Road Courthouse. Now, finds Mic Moroney, it's home to outstanding drama.
fields.body:
With a loyalist feud simmering just up the road, and Halloween firecrackers detonating in nearby estates, there was a charged atmosphere at the opening night of Convictions, inside the bristling razor-wire perimeter of Belfast's now-derelict Crumlin Road Courthouse.

It has been closed since 1998, and is crumbling, just like the tunnel to the empty jail across the road. But the courthouse is a listed building, and its forbidding neoclassical grandeur is now in the hands of a property developer.

Partly because of its history - those charged with some of the most appalling paramilitary acts of the Troubles were hauled before its controversial, juryless Diplock courts - the fate of the building hangs in the balance. Some want to see it become a museum. Others think its should be razed to the ground.

Somehow, the Belfast theatre company Tinderbox got the keys to the place and has mounted a Hydra-headed promenade piece by seven playwrights, an installation artist and a composer. The show burrows through the building's labyrinthine interior, with its courts, underground holding cells, queasy kitchens and urinals.

The playwrights baulk at delving directly into recent history, instead often mocking what they themselves are doing. Marie Jones's 12-minute piece opens the show in the criminal courtroom with a knockaround comedy in which an arts administrator and her musician friend pitch the idea that the prison become an interactive children's heritage centre, complete with defendants and smirking police. Then the 80-strong audience is broken up into groups and marshalled separately through the dank, graffitied corridors of the crumbling building.

Down in the warren of holding pens, Gary Mitchell's piece is a raucous, in-your-face two-hander about a loonish, presumably paramilitary prisoner, who is patiently talked down off the bars by a grimly philosophical prison warden. He howls murderous abuse at a sex offender before being forced down into the underground cells, where he breaks down.

In the jury room, Nicola McCartney's piece is equally disturbing. Taking a break from the courtroom, a young woman is intimidated by a deranged fellow juror (played sinuously by Lalor Roddy) into voting for a guilty verdict. Suddenly the young woman turns the tables on him, in a bizarrely laconic allegory of power and vulnerability.

I had been dreading court number two, where some of the greatest monsters created by the Troubles, such as Lenny Murphy of the Shankill Butchers, were tried. We were led up behind the bullet-proof glass to the high, freezing benches of the public galleries.

Again, actor Lalor Roddy sat alone in the court. At first it was very hard to hear Owen McCafferty's piece about a guy appealing to a disembodied female voice of neutral authority. Eventually we realise he is a bereaved relative seeking justice. This obliqueness is typical of the playlets, which avoid sectarian analysis, but constantly question authoritarian justice.

The humour tightens nicely in Damian Gorman's piece in the judge's room, where a bumptious retired judge holds forth. The satire at times has the subtlety of a blunt tin-opener, but its aim is true, skewering the vanity of those who believe they kept the flame of civilisation alive through the Troubles in the form of Castleward Opera. Launching the Troubles Opera Trust, the Judge suggests a Wagnerian Riverdance to commemorate the Troubles - the Ulster War Cycle. It's in bad taste, but the audience laughs very hard.

After a brief sojourn in a corridor, we are taken down to the men's toilets. Here Daragh Carville treats us to another lark, as a cynical photographer and a dim journalist chat about the notion of the place becoming a tourist centre.

Throughout the entire ghoulish promenade, the paramilitary graffiti is unavoidable. The audience are subjected to the foul cabbage-stink of the disused kitchen, and the canteen where artist Amanda Montgomery has made a psychopath's picnic of the crockery and kitchen cleavers.

If you ever get apprehensive about what you're doing there, Martin Lynch's final monologue in the main entrance hall rubs your nose in it. From high scaffolding, the ghost of a former prisoner roars down: "Good of you to come. You wait until the place closes down, and all the heartbreak has come and gone... Then you turn up, y'shower of bastards. And behave like a pile of voyeuristic, theatre-goin', fun-seekin', hedonistic, facile assholes."

It is hard for playwrights to seize an audience's attention in 10 to 15 minutes, but they all make themselves heard, even against the sheer presence of the building, with its unimaginable accumulation of human tragedy. In fact the building itself seems to goad the actors into hypnotic, haunted performances.

These Ulster artists are trying to grapple honestly with a deeply uncomfortable past. It's an unforgettable experience.

 Until November 11. Box office: 028-9066 5577.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
Yet more legal woe for the Wu Tang Clan 's Ol' Dirty Bastard - who, for the sake of decorum will henceforth be referred to by his real name, Russell Jones - with the issuing of a warrant for his arrest after absconding from a drug rehab clinic a fortnight ago. Having recently served six months for a probation violation, Jones had been living at Pasadena's residential Impact House centre since June. Midway through being transported to the LA Criminal Courthouse, however, to discuss his ongoing treatment with a district judge, Jones promptly took flight, leading the District Attorney's office to observe that "he's probably looking at prison time. We're looking at whether he's suitable for probation and, based upon his actions thus far, he's not." Jones, whose whereabouts remain unknown, also has two outstanding warrants for his detention issued by the New York Police Department, stemming from various charges of crack possession. Just say no, kids.

Meanwhile, hapless gangsta crooner Stanley "Flesh-N-Bone" Howse of R'n'B collective Bone Thugs-N-Harmony has been sentenced to a further two years hard time after being sent down for 11 years last week on firearms and threatening behaviour charges. The original rap (no pun intended) arose after a ruckus last Boxing Day when Howse pulled an AK-47 from a baby's cot, loaded it, and then took aim at his - ostensible - best friend Tarrance Vickers (as you do). After the sentence was handed down in Van Nuys Superior Court, Southern California, an understandably subdued Howse informed the court that he was "sorry for my wrongdoings [and] accepted responsibility for these crimes. I understand that the nature of these crimes makes me appear to be a violent person, but I am not a violent person." No, of course not, Stanley. Who could possibly think you were?

fields.headline: The new logo motive
fields.standfirst: The V&A's Brand.New show
fields.trailText: It has long been the great paranoid terror of the counter-corporate imagination that we might all one day wake up with our personal data neatly encrypted into bar-codes stamped onto our flesh, like concentration-camp numbers. The image turns up again in the V&A's current exhibition, Brand.New.
fields.body:
It has long been the great paranoid terror of the counter-corporate imagination that we might all one day wake up with our personal data neatly encrypted into bar-codes stamped onto our flesh, like concentration-camp numbers. The image turns up again in the V&A's current exhibition, Brand.New. In one of the "anti-adverts" made by polemicists the Media Foundation we see a man watching TV with a code stamped on his neck, then the caption: "Cast off the chains of market-structured consciousness."

This might suggest that Brand. New has a more militant intent than it does. The show is well timed to coincide with a rising public distrust of corporate identity, as articulated in Naomi Klein's book No Logo. Ideally, Brand.New should be able not only to tell us why people get fanatical about Nike and the values attached to its "Swoosh" logo, but also just what it is about Starbucks cafés that makes people want to burn them down.

Brand.New provides a solid grounding in the meaning, function and omnipresence of logos; if it falls short of a certain critical edge, you certainly learn a lot from it. I never knew, for example, about the 300-plus brands of cola that hoped to rival Coke in 1917, among them Coco-Kakus, Koloko, Blisco, Charcola, Gay-Ola (all names too good to waste, and surely worth recycling now as rock bands or record labels).

The eloquent installation in the first room offers a rare draw-your-own-conclusions moment in a very pedagogic exhibition. In a wonderfully literal illustration of the phrase "field of signs", thousands of beermat-sized logos on sticks wave like corn, but with familiar faces - Chris Evans, Tony Blair, the Queen Mother - bobbing away alongside Boddingtons, Tesco and Pulmo Expectorant.

Chris Evans may not be a brand as such, though his Ginger production company is, but he could certainly become one if he ever launched his own line of beer or hair dye. The best example of personality branding is American lifestyle guru Martha Stewart, the curator of an exhaustive lifestyle; her vitrine here includes her own Wasp and Hornet Killer, wittily positioned right next to her heart-shaped chocolate biscuits.

Another room explains how brands highlight various "values": Authority, Authenticity, Status, Irreverence, Friendly (sic)... The most revealing booth is Loyalty, which tellingly counterpoints Man U branding with Hello Kitty, the Japanese brand that sells nothing more specific than a winsome cartoon cat, or more generally, the cultural quality of kawairashisa, or cuteness. This is a prime example of the way that brands can float free of their original meanings. What Hello Kitty means to Japanese five-year-olds is not what it means to British clubbers who use cuteness for their own ironic purposes.

Brand.New could have made more of this strange autonomy of brands, their ability to evade corporate control and the limitations of intended meaning. This is why the last room, on Subversion, is the most tantalising. It includes the Media Foundation's work, and other conceptual and political appropriations of ad language. But you don't have to look to art for examples of logo autonomy. Take the various Indian products that co-opt the Pepsi label, or rough approximations thereof, to sell anything imaginable - such as a set of cricket balls with the cheeky warning: "Be aware of duplicates."

But the Subversion room could easily have been the starting point for another exhibition entirely, and only makes you aware of the gaps. What about the branding of phenomena that are not obviously saleable products in the same way that trainers or Tango are? What about TV branding, for example, and the presentation tricks that distinguish CNN from Sky News? What about corporate sponsorship, or product placement in cinema? A whole room might have been devoted to explicating the mysteries of dot.com branding - the most nebulous enterprise of all, in which millions are spent establishing loyalty for what often seem to be free-floating brands with no tangible product attached.

The last thing you see on leaving the exhibition is the V&A's own logo, a belated reminder that museums and other cultural establishments invest as much in the branding game as anyone else. On a recent Radio 3 Night Waves programme, a Tate marketing person spoke very eloquently about a certain quality called Tateness. The least you can say about Brand.New is that it is a confident and elegant promotion of V&Acity, which could in no way be mistaken for Tateness Modern, Tateness British or Saatchismo.

 Brand.New is at the Victoria & Albert Museum, London SW7, until January 14. Details on 020-7942 2000.

Brand.New could have made more of this strange autonomy of brands, their ability to evade corporate control and the limitations of intended meaning. This is why the last room, on Subversion, is the most tantalising. It includes the Media Foundation's work, and other conceptual and political appropriations of ad language. But you don't have to look to art for examples of logo autonomy. Take the various Indian products that co-opt the Pepsi label, or rough approximations thereof, to sell anything imaginable - such as a set of cricket balls with the cheeky warning: "Be aware of duplicates." But the Subversion room could easily have been the starting point for another exhibition entirely, and only makes you aware of the gaps. What about the branding of phenomena that are not obviously saleable products in the same way that trainers or Tango are? What about TV branding, for example, and the presentation tricks that distinguish CNN from Sky News? What about corporate sponsorship, or product placement in cinema? A whole room might have been devoted to explicating the mysteries of dot.com branding - the most nebulous enterprise of all, in which millions are spent establishing loyalty for what often seem to be free-floating brands with no tangible product attached. The last thing you see on leaving the exhibition is the V&A's own logo, a belated reminder that museums and other cultural establishments invest as much in the branding game as anyone else. On a recent Radio 3 Night Waves programme, a Tate marketing person spoke very eloquently about a certain quality called Tateness. The least you can say about Brand.New is that it is a confident and elegant promotion of V&Acity, which could in no way be mistaken for Tateness Modern, Tateness British or Saatchismo.  Brand.New is at the Victoria & Albert Museum, London SW7, until January 14. webTitle: Arts: Peter Lennon meets Eve Arnold

fields.headline: Moments of truth
fields.standfirst: Peter Lennon meets Eve Arnold, one of the world's great photojournalists
fields.trailText: Peter Lennon meets Eve Arnold, one of the world's great photojournalists.
fields.body:
One of the most difficult experiences recalled by Magnum photographer Eve Arnold is her close encounter with Joseph McCarthy at his witchhunt hearings in Washington. It was 1954 and Arnold had only been working as a photographer for two years. What was the experience like? "Terrible," she shudders.

"He had a kind of oily charm. I had come late to the hearings and his secretary said she should introduce me before I went in. McCarthy held up the meetings in order to speak to one freelance photographer. Everything had to come his way, all the publicity."

She then experienced the same paralysing fear that countless Americans had experienced at the hands of McCarthy. "I was the only woman in the press corps," she says. "So when we broke for lunch McCarthy came over and put his arm around my shoulder. I put my hand up to remove his hand because I could not bear the thought of being touched by him, but with my hand up there I realised I couldn't do that. I found you didn't play games with that man. If he put his hand on you, you didn't want to have your past checked out - although I had nothing to hide. So I wound up holding hands with McCarthy, dying inside.

"The other press men looked at me in horror, with the great man's hand on my shoulder. I said: 'Excuse me, Senator, I got to go to work,' and moved away from him and photographed him and Roy Cohn, who had just been around all the American libraries in Europe throwing out books. When I went down for lunch in the senate dining room, before I could even order my soup, the journalists, about 30 of them, all turned away; nobody would talk to me. So awful was the sense of horror in that room. I could not tell these men why I had done that."

Arnold has now been taking pictures for almost half a century. Perhaps her best known sequences are the pictures she took of Marilyn Monroe, both early in her career and in 1960 on the set of The Misfits with Monroe's then husband, Arthur Miller. But she is wary of the danger familiar to many a photographer of allowing a famous subject to overshadow a lifetime's work. "We had great fun together," she says of her times with the screen legend. "But I don't want to be Marilyn's Boswell."

Arnold got into photography when a boyfriend - or " beau" as she calls him - gave her a camera. She took a job with a film processor in Hoboken, New Jersey, and worked there for five years. They would sometimes get a roll of erotic film to be processed, but the law said these could not be sent through the post. So they were locked in a special file and never returned. "But every now and then," she says, "the boss would drive up in his Cadillac with some friends and ask for the key to the cupboard. Then we could hear them guffawing away in his private office."

She joined Magnum, the celebrated co-operative photo agency, very early, introduced by the brother of Hungarian war photographer Robert Capa, one of the founding members.

Her first great success was a 1952 black fashion show in New York, which was followed by a series on the imperious Marlene Dietrich. She photographed James Cagney at home hoofing with his wife Willy, a former chorus girl. He sang dirty Yiddish ditties for her. (Cagney was Catholic but brought up on New York's East Side.) She did John Huston and his young daughter Angelica, Margot Fonteyn, Rudolph Nureyev and Yves Montand. She did a reportage of a Malcolm X meeting and a series depicting Joan Crawford being dressed by her daughter Christina (who later exposed her in Mommie Dearest).

At one point, Crawford, completely drunk, posed nude. Crawford had begun her career in blue films. "She was a sad, benighted creature," Arnold says. "I never printed the pictures, but I sent her the negatives and that made me her friend for life."

She travelled the world to get some of the great scoops of the century. She was the first American photographer allowed into China, permitted to travel all over that immense territory almost without restriction. She got her visa, she says, with the help of a Chinese friend the day after Nixon reached his rapprochement with China in 1972. "The difference between a fine photograph and a good, useable photograph," she says, "might be a gesture, a movement of the hand, a moment's introspection. You don't have time to notice everything."

In 1966 she had already got the scoop of the decade: a picture of Russian dissidents reclining in baths with motor tyres for pillows, undergoing hydrotherapy intended to cure them of their unorthodox views. How did she get into the psychiatric hospital? She says she works on "robber's time", swiftly grabbing shots, often without the subject realising it.

"The previous year," she says, "I had done a fun story in Russia about the oldest man in the world. The Russians were so pleased when I applied again I had no trouble getting a visa. Of course we knew all about the dissidents being held in psychiatric wards. But if I had asked to see them I wouldn't have got in. I said I wanted to see the psychiatrists. At one point the official who was showing me around was called to the phone so I just took a quick shot through a window."

She talks with passion about the specific details of her art: the virtues of available light ("By the time you set up lights the image is gone"); working with colour film ("With all those colour magazines around in the 70s you couldn't make a living without colour"); and her beloved Nikon cameras.

She speaks of her preference for manual cameras - automatics are, of course, infradig and one does not even bother to acknowledge digital. And she recalls that once in India she had all her Nikons stolen. When she came back to New York, she decided that since she had to replace them she would go high-class and get a load of Leicas (the preferred tool of Cartier-Bresson). "But when I was going out the door I turned back and said, 'I don't want any of these. I had very good luck with Nikons so I'll stick to them.' "

We get into an argument about colour, which she will not admit is more unreliable than black and white. "Colour can be treacherous," I insist. "Take, for example, your celebrated picture Black is Beautiful of a beautiful black girl. She wasn't black - she was glowing red."

"There are many tones of black," she laughs. "Even red?" "Even red," she says, this time with steel in her voice. As the Chinese and Russians discovered, Eve Arnold holds her ground.
