fields.headline: Whitbread to sell 140 restaurants
fields.trailText: Whitbread is to sell 140 of its restaurants operating under brand names such as Cafe Rouge and Bella Pasta after reporting a 6% slump in half year profits.
fields.body:
Whitbread is to sell 140 of its restaurants operating under brand names such as Cafe Rouge and Bella Pasta after reporting a 6% slump in half year profits.

One in 10 of its restaurants will go while the group's Beefeater outlets will be largely rebranded as part of a drive to hit 10% profit growth.

Hundreds of jobs will be affected by the shake-up but there will be no net losses because other Whitbread outlets such as the Costa Coffee bars will be increased.

Whitbread, which last month put its 3,000 pub estate up for sale, reported pre-tax profits before exceptionals of £182.1m for the six months to 2 September. The downturn was made worse by a poor performance from its other brands such as TGI Friday's where sales fell by 6%. A blitz to improve the restaurants is under way.

Whitbread, which also owns UK Marriott hotels, David Lloyd Leisure Centres and Pizza Hut restaurants, has gradually been reducing its dependence on brewing and alcohol-led retailing. It now favours higher growth sectors such as hotels, health clubs and best located restaurants.

Sales from the "new Whitbread" which includes the Swallow Hotels group it bought for £578m in January rose 22% though the group's overall turnover was reduced to £1.7b, down 1.9%.

Analysts said the performance of the restaurant division had been disappointing but the restructuring would go some way to restore confidence. Shares rose 5p to 507.5.

About 35 of the 103 Cafe Rouges and 10 out of 73 Bella Pasta sites are to be shut while the remaining cuts will be taken across the board from Beefeaters to Brewers Fayres.

About 80 of the 258 largely unprofitable Beefeater restaurants will become a new chain called Out and Out, 90 will be rebranded under a "neighbourhood" format. Some Beefeaters will continue to operate but the rest will close.

The company has taken heart from a turnaround at Brewers Fayre and is hoping to obtain £1.5bn for investment from the sale of its pubs, with the privately-owned Pubmaster seen as an obvious buyer. Some analysts have warned of a glut of pub sales but chairman Sir John Banham said he had received numerous expressions of interest.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Cockerell writes: Thank you for publishing Wendy Savage's accomplished obituary of the distinguished surgeon Peter Huntingford (October 30). Other than her, he has been the only medical scientist, clinician, practitioner or teacher of any stature at all to stand alongside women since the inception of the NHS in 1948. His brilliance and solidarity during a dismal era of medicalisation, at the time of the [Asa] Briggs Report and the [Renee] Short Report, contributed greatly to the achievement of women's voice in this area.

His brilliance and solidarity during a dismal era of medicalisation, at the time of the [Asa] Briggs Report and the [Renee] Short Report, contributed greatly to the achievement of women's voice in this area.

Penny Condry writes: RS Thomas (Obituary, September 27) and his wife Elsi came into our lives in the early 1950s, when my husband, William Condry, and I were living in Cwm Einion. We shared many interests: RS was a keen birdwatcher, and Elsi a wonderful painter and gardener. When RS became vicar at Yscuborycoed, we went on many expeditions together, searching for the then very rare kites' nests so that they could be given protection by the Kite committee, of which Bill and RS were members.

One year, RS was granted a travel bursary, and he invited Bill to join him on a camping trip to the Coto Doñana, a wildlife refuge in southern Spain. Bill found RS to be a most merry companion, interested in every aspect of their long journey, and full of patience at Bill's frequent stops in order to photograph a new plant, creature or thrilling scene.

fields.headline: Merger doubts upset investors
fields.standfirst: Glaxo and SmithKline shares fall
fields.trailText: Shares in SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome, the pharmaceutical companies set for a £91bn merger, were among the biggest fallers yesterday after their trading statements sent waves of uncertainty through the City.
fields.body:
Shares in SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome, the pharmaceutical companies set for a £91bn merger, were among the biggest fallers yesterday after their trading statements sent waves of uncertainty through the City.

Despite announcing solid results, the pair both admitted to setbacks with the development of important drugs and failed to convince observers their union will be approved this year.

The completion of the deal, which will create the world's largest drugs company by market share, is being delayed by US federal trade commission concerns over the combined group's dominant position in the anti-smoking market. Glaxo owns prescription medicine Zyban while SmithKline has interests in nicotine patches and gum.

Jean-Pierre Garnier, chief executive of SmithKline, said he hoped the merger would be approved by Christmas without the need for forced sales. "I am looking at the year end for the merger with Glaxo and the creation of a very important company," he said. "That would be a wonderful Christmas present."

But analysts were disappointed there was no definite completion date. "At the moment everyone just wants them to get on with integrating the two business," said one. "There's a risk they won't complete this year and people are worried staff won't know where they are and there will be a lack of direction." Glaxo, reporting a nine-month trading update, said sales were up 12% at £6.86bn on a year ago with growth driven by respiratory, central nervous system and anti-viral products. It also hopes NICE, the health authority set up by the NHS, will recommend in a report, expected imminently, that doctors be allowed to prescribe Relenza, its influenza treatment, on the NHS.

The company's shares took a battering yesterday over continuing concerns about the side effects of Lotronex, its treatment for irritable bowel syndrome. It also admitted Advair, its new product for asthma, would not be available in the US until the first half of next year. As the market closed last night shares had fallen 84p, or 4%, to £19.84.

SmithKline said third quarter pre-tax profits were up 19% to £589m, excluding currency effects, with strong US sales led by anti-depressant Paxil/ Seroxat. Earnings per share rose 33% to 7.3p while sales in the three months to the end of September stood at £2.19bn, a gain of 17% if currency effects are excluded.

However, analysts said the numbers had been inflated by changes to wholesalers' stocking patterns which took the shine off the figures.

The company also gave a warning that further tests on Ariflo, its pulmonary disease treatment, had to be carried out which will put its submission to regulators back by up to a year. As a result, SmithKline's shares also lost 4% with the stock tumbling 43p to close the day at 890p.

Analysts said the stock market fortunes of the two companies were now inextricably linked. "Everyone is already treating them as a merged industry," said one. "People are no longer producing separate forecasts."

webTitle: EasyJet keeps share price up in the air

fields.headline: EasyJet keeps price up in the air
fields.trailText: EasyJet yesterday set a price range of 250p-350p per share for its flotation later this month. Around £200m is being raised from institutional investors, giving the no-frills airline a market valuation in the region of £750m.
fields.body:
EasyJet yesterday set a price range of 250p-350p per share for its flotation later this month. Around £200m is being raised from institutional investors, giving the no-frills airline a market valuation in the region of £750m.

The airline said it expected to announce a narrowing of this price range by November 10, 12 days before the company joins the stock market. .

One source connected with the float said that by starting with a wide range, and declaring an intention to narrow it, EasyJet was hoping to avoid the turbulence encountered by other recent public offerings, notably Lastminute.com.

"This will allow a little bit of head room," he said. "The key point is that airline shares have been moving around recently - affected by the shifting price of fuel - and EasyJet is anxious not to have its price jump up and down too much."

Merchant bank UBS Warburg, which is joint book-runner on the placing with Credit Suisse First Boston, has promoted EasyJet's public offering by claiming it will prove a better buy than rival Ryanair.

Others have cautioned that the volatility of fuel prices, the heavy burden of aviation regulation and political sensitivities surrounding the industry could put many investors off.

Much of the money raised will be spent on a new generation of aircraft. The 18 EasyJet now owns have an average age of 15 years.

EasyJet chairman Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who founded the airline five years ago, said: "Flotation will allow us to maximise the potential for growth in our business by helping fund our planned Boeing 737-700 purchases."

The company hopes to have taken delivery of 32 Boeing aircraft by May 2004, taking the fleet to 44 planes with an average age of under three years.

The company's 1,400 staff will receive £75m worth of shares. The 63m new ordinary shares on offer later this month represent about 25% of the enlarged share capital.

webTitle: First Direct advisers take independent route

fields.headline: First Direct advisers take independent route
fields.trailText: First Direct, the telephone and online bank, is to offer independent financial advice and sell other companies' products from January.
fields.body:
First Direct, the telephone and online bank, is to offer independent financial advice and sell other companies' products from January.

The HSBC subsidiary said it was the first leading bank to change from being a tied agent - selling only products from its parent - to an independent intermediary, offering "the best life assurance, pension and investment products on the market".

Alan Hughes, the chief executive, said: "Our margins will be a bit thinner. We need to sell about twice as many [products] to get the same sort of returns."

The bank said 100 advisers would be offering investment products from 23 providers, and pension and life insurance from six companies. It will carry on selling HSBC products "if they are good enough."

webTitle: Bolton jolted back into race for promotion

fields.headline: Bolton jolted back into race for promotion
fields.trailText: Bolton needed a sharp reminder before rejoining the the promotion race at the Reebok stadium last night, when they came from a goal down to secure a 3-1 win over Queens Park Rangers and move into fourth place.
fields.body:
Bolton needed a sharp reminder before rejoining the the promotion race at the Reebok stadium last night, when they came from a goal down to secure a 3-1 win over Queens Park Rangers and move into fourth place.

After a dire opening 40 minutes of few chances and little excitement, Rangers went ahead against the run of play when their on-loan defender Marlon Broomes, up for a corner, put over a cross for Peter Crouch to head home.

The goal brought Bolton out of their shell and they were level within a minute when Ricardo Gardner's corner to the far post was palmed by Rangers' keeper Lee Harper but headed by the Bolton captain Gudni Bergsson into an empty net.

Gradually Bolton took control and after 61 minutes Robbie Elliott found himself free 25 yards out and hit a wickedly dipping shot into the top corner, and three minutes later Michael Ricketts slotted home a third with Harper stranded.

Burnley rebounded from a five-goal hammering at Nottingham Forest at the weekend with a goal from Andy Cooke for a 1-0 win at Turf Moor over a Crewe side who deserved better. Cooke's fourth goal of the season came from a glancing header in the 33rd minute after a great cross from the left by Graham Branch.

Crewe more than matched Burnley as they went in search of their third win a row but they failed to find a finishing touch despite carving out three clear-cut scoring opportunities before Burnley's goal. Shaun Smith was the worst culprit, shooting wide when it looked easier to score after he had burst clear. Alan Maybury also wasted a glorious chance when clean through.

The Burnley defence also escaped punishment when Colin Little should have done better than miss the target after being on the end of a flowing six-man move.

But all Crewe's attractive approach play consistently went to waste in front of goal and they were hit by the sucker punch when Cooke rose to deflect Branch's cross beyond Jason Kearton.

Burnley were by no means convincing but they will welcome a victory which moves moved them into sixth place, especially after the drubbing at Forest. Crewe remain too close to the trapdoor for comfort.

fields.headline: Spurs fans round on Sugar
fields.trailText: Tottenham 1 - 3 Birmingham
fields.byline: Roy Collins  at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham's manager George Graham has been bemoaning the declining art of defending all season. And having seen his side crash out of the Worthington Cup after a woeful first-half defensive performance, the man who on the other side of north London constructed the country's most outstanding back four must despair of ever repeating the feat here.

Graham himself admitted it was by far the worst defensive display since he took over two years ago. "It was embarrassing," he said. "I couldn't believe it. We improved a little in the second half but we had to; it couldn't have been any worse."

For Spurs, who won this trophy last year and regard it as their best route into Europe, it was humiliating. Their notor- iously grumpy fans, who could make a convoy of fuel protesters seem like reasonable men, were not slow to make their feelings known, chanting, "Stand up if you hate Sugar."

It was the first time this season that the Spurs chairman Alan Sugar was the focus of their anger, Graham taking the stick after the weekend defeat at Chelsea. But both now face a crucial period with their club set for a winter of discontent.

Spurs were without Sol Campbell, Oyvind Leonhardsen and Sergei Rebrov but Birmingham arrived without their two main strikers, replacing them with Dele Adebola and Mark Burchill.

Steffen Freund suffered a hamstring injury in the eighth minute but it did not excuse the lack of Spurs marking when Adebola accepted a cross from Stan Lazaridis and switched the ball to his left foot before stroking it into the corner.

Adebola's second was from the top drawer as he checked inside Ben Thatcher and Ramon Vega before shooting powerfully into the corner.

Spurs went three down a minute before half-time when Burchill converted Martin Grainger's left-wing cross, bringing boos from the home fans and chants of "We want our Tottenham back".

Darren Anderton offered hope of a comeback by scoring from the spot, but by the end they were once again voicing their disapproval and calling for Sugar to quit.

fields.headline: Solskjaer at the double
fields.trailText: Watford 0 - 3 Man Utd
fields.body:
The best that the First Division currently has to offer were no match for half a Premiership team last night. For though the identity of the goalscorers had a familiar ring, this was a line-up that owed more to tomorrow's United than today's.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Dwight Yorke lent some know-how to Sir Alex Ferguson's young set and it was they who made sure that a tie eagerly awaited by the Watford public would become no more than a routine passage to the next round.

Such was Watford's embarrassment at the disparity in class that Tommy Mooney even missed a late penalty awarded for a foul by Raimond van der Gouw, who was shown the red card.

It was lamentable the way a team unbeaten in the First Division failed to impose themselves, but even Graham Taylor seemed taken aback by the quality on view. "If that was United's second team or third or fourth it still looks good enough to finish in the top six in the Premiership," he said.

United's opener arrived after 12 minutes and though Solskjaer was credited with it the donkey-work was done by Ronnie Wallwork, whose strong challenge took the ball away from Paul Robinson and set up Luke Chadwick for a shot which Alec Chamberlain could only parry.

Chadwick continued to be centrally involved, gliding effortlessly away from defenders before sending over crosses such as the one that gave Yorke the second goal eight minutes after half-time. How painful for Watford to see Chadwick dazzling so; he was signed by them as a schoolboy but, Taylor said, it is impossible to keep richly endowed youngsters at a small club.

Wes Brown had a run-out for United as he needs games to build up his fitness and education, and his partnership with John O'Shea offered little encouragement to the opposition. Wallwork and Jonathan Greening got through a hard shift in midfield and offered both strength and skill to a team effort rounded off nine minutes from time when Solskjaer capitalised on a long clearance.

"We knew these lads had the ability, it's a question of whether they also have the confidence to express themselves and I was delighted to see them do so well on a big stage."

So said Steve McLaren, the United assistant manager and with a leading part to play now in the development of the national team. He can reassure Sven-Goran Eriksson that there is a generation behind David Beckham showing equal promise.

fields.headline: Best value reaps rewards
fields.standfirst: Malcolm  Dean
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Much criticised, long derided local councils, which were far ahead of others in the Guardian/IPPR public involvement awards this week. So what's going on?
fields.body:
Identify the following organisation: ahead of all other institutions in tapping the wishes of clients. More imaginative, more inclusive, more ready to take risks in improving services. Puts charities, voluntary organisations, private companies and national government in the shade. The answer? Much criticised, long derided local councils, which were far ahead of others in the Guardian/IPPR public involvement awards this week. So what's going on?

Part of the answer is "best value", under which councils are required to consult. But there is much more than that. Not everything is perfect by any means on the local patch, but for old and new reasons much is improving. Local authorities are closer to people than central government. Councillors are closer to communities than MPs. Equally important, senior council officers are more attuned to the electoral needs of their bosses than Whitehall. Gone are the days when town clerks deemed it below their dignity to talk to the people.

Wendy Thomson, new boss of the audit commission's best value unit, is former chief executive of the London borough of Newham. There she walked down the street knocking on doors asking people what they thought of local services. Her Canadian accent might have helped, but can you imagine Sir Richard Wilson, head of the Cabinet Office, or any of his predecessors, knocking on doors down Brick Lane?

There's a new generation of extremely talented chief officers drawn from a much wider economic and social class than Whitehall's mandarins. This gives them a better appreciation of what makes a community tick. Sir Michael Lyons of Birmingham even includes his two years as a street trader in his Who's Who entry. There are more black faces too. Gurbux Singh, new head of the commission for racial equality and Sir Herman Ouseley, his predecessor, made their names in local government.

Unlike most Whitehall workers, local council officers not only draft policy but have to implement it too. Not for them the arms-length executive agencies, absolving Whitehall from managerial cock-ups. They're closer to what happens when policies fail: children being abused, schools declining, houses falling apart. One reason why Matthew Taylor, energetic IPPR director, dreamed up the awards, was a growing disconnection between government and people. A vote every five years is not enough. In many local elections, people do not even use that. It's down below 25% in places. Participation is part of the answer because it shows people will connect if it is meaningful.

fields.headline: Creating an inclusion zone
fields.standfirst: Cambridge's scheme giving young people a voice in local decision-making scoops first prize.  Malcolm Dean  reports on the winners
fields.trailText: Guardian/IPPR awards: Cambridge's scheme giving young people a voice in local decision-making scoops first prize. Malcolm Dean reports on the winners
fields.body:
It wasn't only the teenagers joining Cambridge's youth participation scheme who were apprehensive about the new venture giving them a voice in decision-taking. So were local councillors - and not just about how realistic the young people would be.

Hannah Reed, one of the councillors, confessed: "I'm 31 but I was nervous about being able to talk their language. I soon learned that by being yourself and not trying to act younger than you are, young people are ready to be straight with you."

The success of the initiative was rewarded today when the city of Cambridge was named overall winner of the Guardian/Institute for Public Policy Research Public Involvement Award.

Young people are one of the biggest excluded groups. Cambridge calculated under 18s represented 17 % of the city's population but, unlike other people, they did not even have a vote. There was cross-party support for getting them more involved in decision-taking. The council decided the best way forward was to let the young people work out what ought to be on the agenda. A three-stage exercise was launched that eventually involved more than 1,150 young people being invited to "shoot your mouth off".

Stage one involved a survey of 700 young people through street interviews and a survey at four secondary schools. They were asked to identify three key issues.

In stage two a grand jury of 40 young people then thrashed out these ideas at two half-day seminars. What emerged were two key priorities: first drugs, alcohol and crime; second "more things to do in Cambridge". The second was seen to be part of the solution to the first.

Stage three was a much longer process in which a jury of 15 young people, trained on how to interview witnesses, were taken on two fact-finding missions to other towns as well as interviews with key Cambridge councillors, officials and leisure service managers.

This was followed by four half-day jury sessions before written and oral reports were presented to council. What has followed has been impressive. The council responded to each of the 32 proposals and have taken up a significant proportion.

These included a fare reduction on city buses for young people; a youth bus complete with computers, video games and youth workers making weekly visits to areas with few facilities; a free one-day summer party for 11 to 17-year-olds, which more than 2,000 attended; a new discount leisure card, designed by young people; a cyber cafe in the city centre for 16 Saturdays; and a review of council premises to see if more use could be made of them for young people's activities.

More impressive still, the participation programme remains ongoing. All are invited to join in. A further 200 have enrolled. The city now has biannual youth conferences - this year's second was held last Saturday. The summer party has become an annual event. Four action groups have been set up dealing with transport, crime and disorder, and cycling.

Andy Barnard, who served on both the grand jury and the 15-member policy jury, was only 14 when he became involved. "I felt apprehensive at first but once the 15-member jury went away for a weekend together, real trust was established. We weren't patronised by the older members. We really bonded. It has given me much more confidence. I was even able to address 500 people from the city party platform. The council has listened and is moving on our agenda. The main aim now must be to widen participation."

Reed feels equally rewarded. She explains: "Young people are refreshing to work with. They're dead straight and honest. They ask much more direct questions than adults. Moreover, they were really realistic in their demands. They recognised the only way to proceed was to start with modest proposals then build on that. There are lessons here for all councils."

While Cambridge was the overall winner, there were plenty more success stories. New means of involving the public - including the most mar ginal of groups - in key decisions that affect their lives emerged across the country. There was a citizen's jury of 16 drug addicts who helped develop a new strategy for detoxification and rehabilitation services for Big Issue vendors; there was a citizens' advisory group in Milton Keynes that is leading to extra permanent sites for travellers.

In a crowded entry list, local councils were ahead of all other public, private and voluntary organisations.

Dr Mo Mowlam, minister for the Cabinet Office, said at the awards ceremony in London that government needed to work with all interested parties in developing policies and services including front line staff. She added: "That is the way we will develop the best policy, the best legislation and the best services. It is also the way to develop trust in the system of government."

"This is why the Guardian/IPPR awards are important. They will encourage government and other organisations that provide a public service to raise their game in finding new, effective ways of involving people. I hope today's ceremony will be the first of many."

Matthew Taylor, director of the IPPR, said involving people in decision-taking had "moved from the margin to the mainstream". Public involvement was "difficult and time consuming and sometimes expensive" but produced better decisions for a wide variety of organisations. One aim of the scheme was to highlight out-standing initiatives with the hope that best practice could spread.

He added: "Sceptics claim that public participation risks heightening public expectations. Experience shows the public are realistic, and are willing and able to take part in decisions that affect their lives."

One reason for the success of local councils is the government's "best value" programme that requires local councils to consult the communities they serve. The criteria selected by the 14-member judging panel required applicants to demonstrate more than just consultation. They had to demonstrate that something else had hap pened as a result: a change in service delivery, a shift in policy, or reform of the organisation's structure to give the public more say. More points were awarded for innovative approaches, sustainable strategies and schemes involving hard-to-reach groups.

The 161 applicants included three community health groups, three police services, four primary care groups, six housing associations, seven private companies, eight health authorities or trusts, 13 charities, 50 voluntary or community organisations and 62 councils.

The judges found charities were effective in organising questionnaires and focus groups but failed to go beyond these traditional techniques. Many voluntary organisations were using good community development techniques to keep in touch with users or client groups, but it was not always clear how these consultations led to a change of agenda. The private sector submitted seven schemes involving public consultation but there was insufficient evidence that the exercises had clearly changed decisions.

Reward for hard work

The other award winners and what their projects achieved:

A campaign to help fight drug addiction and a city's help with the traveller community were two of the other outstanding Public Involvement Awards winners.

The Big Issue in the North Trust, one of the six other award winners, tackled drug addicts. They selected a citizen's jury of 16 addicts, all working as vendors of the Big Issue. Twelve were taking heroin, seven crack and four cocaine. They were brought together for seven days, the first two to get to know each other and the next five to draw up a strategy for detoxification and rehabilitation services. Evidence was taken over two days from 11 expert witnesses including Mike Trace, the deputy drug tsar, Professor Howard Parker of Manchester University, senior drug police officers and specialist doctors.

Their final report helped the trust to develop its own drug service for its vendors, many of whom have drug problems. The pilot, which runs until next year, has included buying bed places at Phoenix House, a charitable detoxification centre, and developing a follow-through residential and rehabilitation service. The report was submitted to the North West drugs commission and, on the advice of Paul Boateng, the Home Office minister whom the jury met, to all other relevant ministers.

The Milton Keynes citizens' advisory group on travellers tackled an equally controversial group. Even while they were preparing their report, a disruptive group of travellers hit the local headlines when they turned up at one of the new town's two sites and began intimidating regular users. A caravan was set alight.

Yet the group has succeeded in defusing the situation with a package that includes stronger action against unacceptable traveller behaviour and more tolerance of traveller families following a local code of conduct. The advisory group emerged from a multi-agency partnership (council, police and two major local landlords, Milton Keynes Park Trust and the Commission for New Towns).

The partnership sent out questionnaires to 800 randomly selected local residents seeking views on travellers. About 180 were returned with 60 ready to join a citizens' jury. These were all invited but only 21 turned up. They renamed themselves an advisory group, believing the name jury to be too confrontational and divisive. The group held two public meetings and consulted in depth with landowners, travellers, residents, police, councillors and officials.

The main recommendations have been accepted. A new traveller management unit to co-ordinate all operational aspects is up and running. The new tough and tender management proposals have been introduced. A recommendation for extra permanent sites (the existing two can only accommodate about 12 families) prompted a search by the partnership which identified four possible locations. Finally, the group has helped consolidate political support. A recent move in the council to abandon the idea of new sites was overwhelmingly defeated.

Many councils have established panels of residents for consultation purposes, but few are as flexible or as extensive as the London borough of Lewisham's 1,000-member panel. The members like it too: 96% of members expressed satisfaction. More than 20 consultation exercises have been conducted involving telephone surveys, focus groups and community workshops.

Overall winner

 Cambridge city council

Other winners

 The Big Issue in the North Trust

 Milton Keynes partnership - council, Thames Valley police, English Partnerships, and Milton Keynes Parks Trust

 London borough of Lewisham

 Bristol city council's action research on parental involvement in schools and lifelong learning;

 South Ayrshire's use of people with learning difficulties and their carers in developing a learning disability strategy;

 Trafford South primary care group's consultation exercises used to review health and social care services.

Runners-up

 Gloucester city and Gloucester county council for road safety consultations;

 Portsmouth county council for its public consultation strategy;

 Somerset health authority for its consultation panels on GP services, NHS direct and priority setting;

 Swansea county council for its youth forum;

 Walsall council for its community plan.

There was a citizen's jury of 16 drug addicts who helped develop a new strategy for detoxification and rehabilitation services for Big Issue vendors; there was a citizens' advisory group in Milton Keynes that is leading to extra permanent sites for travellers. In a crowded entry list, local councils were ahead of all other public, private and voluntary organisations. Dr Mo Mowlam, minister for the Cabinet Office, said at the awards ceremony in London that government needed to work with all interested parties in developing policies and services including front line staff. She added: "That is the way we will develop the best policy, the best legislation and the best services. It is also the way to develop trust in the system of government." "This is why the Guardian/IPPR awards are important. They will encourage government and other organisations that provide a public service to raise their game in finding new, effective ways of involving people. I hope today's ceremony will be the first of many." Matthew Taylor, director of the IPPR, said involving people in decision-taking had "moved from the margin to the mainstream". Public involvement was "difficult and time consuming and sometimes expensive" but produced better decisions for a wide variety of organisations. One aim of the scheme was to highlight out-standing initiatives with the hope that best practice could spread. He added: "Sceptics claim that public participation risks heightening public expectations. Experience shows the public are realistic, and are willing and able to take part in decisions that affect their lives." One reason for the success of local councils is the government's "best value" programme that requires local councils to consult the communities they serve. The criteria selected by the 14-member judging panel required applicants to demonstrate more than just consultation. They had to demonstrate that something else had hap pened as a result: a change in service delivery, a shift in policy, or reform of the organisation's structure to give the public more say. More points were awarded for innovative approaches, sustainable strategies and schemes involving hard-to-reach groups. The 161 applicants included three community health groups, three police services, four primary care groups, six housing associations, seven private companies, eight health authorities or trusts, 13 charities, 50 voluntary or community organisations and 62 councils. The judges found charities were effective in organising questionnaires and focus groups but failed to go beyond these traditional techniques. Many voluntary organisations were using good community development techniques to keep in touch with users or client groups, but it was not always clear how these consultations led to a change of agenda. The private sector submitted seven schemes involving public consultation but there was insufficient evidence that the exercises had clearly changed decisions. Reward for hard work The other award winners and what their projects achieved: A campaign to help fight drug addiction and a city's help with the traveller community were two of the other outstanding Public Involvement Awards winners. The Big Issue in the North Trust, one of the six other award winners, tackled drug addicts. They selected a citizen's jury of 16 addicts, all working as vendors of the Big Issue. Twelve were taking heroin, seven crack and four cocaine. They were brought together for seven days, the first two to get to know each other and the next five to draw up a strategy for detoxification and rehabilitation services. Evidence was taken over two days from 11 expert witnesses including Mike Trace, the deputy drug tsar, Professor Howard Parker of Manchester University, senior drug police officers and specialist doctors. Their final report helped the trust to develop its own drug service for its vendors, many of whom have drug problems. The pilot, which runs until next year, has included buying bed places at Phoenix House, a charitable detoxification centre, and developing a follow-through residential and rehabilitation service. The report was submitted to the North West drugs commission and, on the advice of Paul Boateng, the Home Office minister whom the jury met, to all other relevant ministers. The Milton Keynes citizens' advisory group on travellers tackled an equally controversial group. Even while they were preparing their report, a disruptive group of travellers hit the local headlines when they turned up at one of the new town's two sites and began intimidating regular users. A caravan was set alight. Yet the group has succeeded in defusing the situation with a package that includes stronger action against unacceptable traveller behaviour and more tolerance of traveller families following a local code of conduct. The advisory group emerged from a multi-agency partnership (council, police and two major local landlords, Milton Keynes Park Trust and the Commission for New Towns). The partnership sent out questionnaires to 800 randomly selected local residents seeking views on travellers. About 180 were returned with 60 ready to join a citizens' jury. These were all invited but only 21 turned up. They renamed themselves an advisory group, believing the name jury to be too confrontational and divisive. The group held two public meetings and consulted in depth with landowners, travellers, residents, police, councillors and officials. The main recommendations have been accepted. A new traveller management unit to co-ordinate all operational aspects is up and running. The new tough and tender management proposals have been introduced. A recommendation for extra permanent sites (the existing two can only accommodate about 12 families) prompted a search by the partnership which identified four possible locations. Finally, the group has helped consolidate political support. A recent move in the council to abandon the idea of new sites was overwhelmingly defeated. Many councils have established panels of residents for consultation purposes, but few are as flexible or as extensive as the London borough of Lewisham's 1,000-member panel. The members like it too: 96% of members expressed satisfaction. More than 20 consultation exercises have been conducted involving telephone surveys, focus groups and community workshops. Overall winner  Cambridge city council Other winners  The Big Issue in the North Trust  Milton Keynes partnership - council, Thames Valley police, English Partnerships, and Milton Keynes Parks Trust  London borough of Lewisham  Bristol city council's action research on parental involvement in schools and lifelong learning;  South Ayrshire's use of people with learning difficulties and their carers in developing a learning disability strategy;  Trafford South primary care group's consultation exercises used to review health and social care services. Runners-up  Gloucester city and Gloucester county council for road safety consultations;  Portsmouth county council for its public consultation strategy;  Somerset health authority for its consultation panels on GP services, NHS direct and priority setting;  Swansea county council for its youth forum;  Walsall council for its community plan.

webTitle: New school of thought on drug abuse

fields.headline: Early warning
fields.standfirst: New school of thought on drug abuse
fields.trailText: New school of thought on drug abuse
fields.body:
Research released yesterday suggests that the government's new Connexions service, intended to offer advice and guidance to all teenagers, may fail to get to grips with emerging drug problems. Some youngsters were found to have been experimenting with drugs from age eight.

Connexions will be resourced to the tune of £420m a year by the end of 2002-03. It aims to appoint a personal adviser to each young person at age 13. But the research, funded by the Department of Health and co-ordinated by charity DrugScope, indicates that agencies may need to intervene with children in their last years at primary school and their first two years at secondary level.

The study was carried out in six projects among known drug users and others considered at risk of drug misuse: the homeless, offenders and those in care. A consistent picture emerged of vulnerable youngsters developing drug habits at an earlier age than young people generally.

"Young drug users across these studies had generally tried their first illegal drug at the age of 13, if not before, and were also likely to be smoking cigarettes and drinking alcohol with some degree of regularity by this age," says the study report, Vulnerable Young People and Drugs: Opportunities to Tackle Inequalities. Disengagement from school was common, as was evidence of early sexual activity, and family backgrounds were typically unstable.

"A lack of appropriate and effective supervision of young people by parents/carers appears to be a major contributory factor to the vulnerability of children and young people," the report says. "There were also reports of substance misuse in the family home and of family conflict and disruption, both of which played a significant role in the complex problems experienced by some of the young people."

DrugScope, formed by merger of the Institute for the Study of Drug Dependence and the Standing Conference on Drug Abuse, is pointing to a need for more and earlier assessment of youngsters at risk of becoming drug misusers. Roger Howard, the charity's chief executive, says: "Everyone responsible for vulnerable young people needs to recognise that drugs will be an issue. They need to make sure they are trained to spot where there is a drugs problem and know how to deal with it."

One such early intervention scheme is run in Bristol by the Drugs and Young People Project, funded jointly by the NHS and social services. Project worker Duncan Stanway says the five-year-old scheme has helped identify 100-120 young people whose drug use is causing concern.

"A lot of our work is about trying to engage with the young person and offer them services, based in their community, which feel accessible," Stanway says. "Most young people referred here don't want to go to see a counsellor, don't want to sit formally in that environment, so we tend to work through personal youth workers or support workers. We are looking for alternatives that are interesting - that the young people are likely to go for."

 DrugScope is on 020-7928 1211

fields.headline: NHS treaty with private sector
fields.standfirst: Backbenchers warn against "getting into bed" with private health sector
fields.trailText: The government has broken more than 50 years of ideological tension between the NHS and private hospitals by signing a long-term treaty with the independent sector to establish joint planning and exchange of patients.
fields.byline: John Carvel Social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
The government has broken more than 50 years of ideological tension between the NHS and private hospitals by signing a long-term treaty with the independent sector to establish joint planning and exchange of patients.

The deal is expected to lead to about 100,000 more NHS patients being treated free of charge in private hospitals and nursing homes, often by teams of doctors and nurses working under their normal NHS contracts.

It was broadly welcomed by doctors and health service managers as a pragmatic move to treat more patients more quickly by using spare capacity in the private sector, currently working at about 50% capacity.

But it provoked hostility among Labour backbenchers and the health unions whose support is needed by ministers to push through plans to modernise and expand state sector provision.

David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health select committee, said Alan Milburn, the health secretary, should not have "got into bed" with the private sector. "Giving comfort at a time when it is known that the private sector is struggling is not something that I would expect a Labour government to do," he said.

Tony Benn, the veteran Labour MP, said the deal was tantamount to privatisation of the NHS. "The NHS is run down for lack of money, so you bring in the private sector. Once you have done that, why not make it all private?"

Unison, the health service union, said any concordat with the private sector could only be justified as stopgap politics until the NHS had sufficient capacity to manage on its own.

The concordat was signed by Mr Milburn after four months of negotiations with the Independent Healthcare Association. It will encourage all health authorities to build on informal arrangements already operating in some areas.

Department of Health sources said the NHS spent £1.25bn in 1998/9 on contracts with the private sector, worth 4.6% of the NHS budget. This paid for about 350,000 operations.

The new concordat was expected to boost this by about 100,000 operations a year, but the private sector would remain a minor player compared with the 6m performed by the NHS.

Mr Milburn emphasised: "The patient will remain an NHS patient, the doctors will be NHS doctors, by and large the nurses will be NHS nurses and, of course, most importantly of all, the care will remain free."

The concordat covers:

 renting spare operating theatres from the private sector for hip operations and other elective surgery by NHS doctors and nurses working under their normal NHS contracts;

 commissioning private or voluntary sector hospitals to provide elective care, using their own staff;

 agreements for transfer of critical care patients between sectors, reducing the number of cancelled operations;

 joint work to develop intermediate care to improve preventive and rehabilitation services;

 sharing information on workforce supply and demand, clinical mistakes and local health improvement strategies.

webTitle: Real Lives: The new England coach

fields.headline: Why this man's specs are good news for England
fields.standfirst: They are not just any old pair of glasses. Charlie Porter on what they tell us about Sven-Goran Eriksson, England's coach in waiting
fields.trailText: Charlie Porter on what Sven-Goran Eriksson's bins tell us about England's coach in waiting
fields.body:
Don't you find Sven-Goran Eriksson strangely hypnotic? There he is, very likely the new face of English football. You will believe in him. You will support him and any decisions he makes. It is as if the Football Association had chosen the 52-year-old Lazio coach for his image rather than his skills. Look at his attributes: deep tan, tidy hair, controlled sophistication. It's a complete volte-face from the England team's experience: a man who thinks about how he looks, and knows his style has the power to draw you in.

But look again. Aren't his glasses a little odd? Try to imagine his face without them and you would be clutching at straws for a memorable feature. But there is something not quite right about those specs and they are insidiously fascinating. They are rimless, usually a style which renders glasses invisible, thanks to their thin metal frames (think Arsene Wenger, then look at the picture, since you probably can't remember much about the Arsenal boss's eyewear). But this pair, designed byItalian house Exté, are blatant, meaning-laden creations, with their strange plastic bridge and sides.

"They're very unusual," says Gail Steele, of the London opticians Auerbach and Steele. "Most rimless glasses have a metal bridge and side. He still wants his glasses to be a feature. He has made a conscious decision to contradict his colouring, with the dull blue of the plastic against his skin. In my view they are quite ugly."

Ugly, yes, but effective. Rimless specs, popular with elder statesmen of European politics, send out signals of openness and honesty. Glasses with frames hide features and so can camouflage expressions - the wearer can end up looking shifty, even if they think they have nothing to hide. Rimless frames let you see the reactions of the person behind them, but they can also be almost too Zen: mild functional things that sit on the nose of a philosopher, not disturbing their thoughts.

Eriksson's glasses stand halfway between the two - modern and forward-thinking, if you were to look him dead in the eye, but from the side we see power and control, a man who wants to remain an old-style boss. "He's going for the mixed message," says Steele. "The soft guy and the tough guy at the same time."

Eriksson has only recently adopted this new, über -leader, style. When he joined Lazio in 1997, his round, meek metal rims made him look uncomplicated and concerned. His new look, coinciding with his success with the Rome side, leading the team to the Italian double, completely changed the way he was perceived. "Changing glasses is the only way most people can dramatically change their look," says Steele. "The only equivalent is having all your hair cut off. It does change how people perceive you - even though they are strange, he looks switched on, modern, and ready to motivate people."

Football in this country has seen rimless specs before and, even more threatening to the old-fashioned supporter, has seen them European coaches. There is Wenger at Arsenal and Gérard Houllier at Liverpool, both of whom wear traditional rimless styles that melt into the face, revealing the inner manager. But there has never been an England coach with rimless specs, and never before a European manager with rimless specs in charge of the national team. It is probably just the sort of style earthquake that prompted the traditionalist Jack Charlton to say: "I am very, very upset and I would imagine all the boys I played with in the 1966 World Cup winning team would be too."

For England fans who have known all along that a foreign coach was the only way forward, the image of Eriksson offers hope. Until he officially takes over on July 1 next 2001, we can trust in the knowledge that the Swede will have no time for the laziness and excuses of our recent past. We can picture the national side as if they were Lazio mark II - young, dynamic, fit, even though we know Eriksson can only import his training secrets, not his players.

But think forward, to February 2002. Regardless of the results of his team, Eriksson will have had to endure England and all we can throw at him. He will be exhausted by criticism and the expectation of the country. His tan will have disappeared and his skin will look tired and sad, unable to cope with 90 minutes spent trying not to be blown into the dugout by gales. His handmade Italian suits will be battered and puckered by rain, hail and flying missiles. He may well realise that his bright, breezy spectacles are giving too much away, that he needs to hide from the stresses of the job. Maybe there was some thought behind Graham Taylor's big, round-framed glasses after all.

webTitle: West Ham ease through as Sunderland leave it late

fields.headline: West Ham ease through as Sunderland leave it late
fields.trailText: West Ham booked their place in the fourth round with a 2-0 win over Blackburn at Upton Park.
fields.body:
West Ham booked their place in the fourth round with a 2-0 win over Blackburn at Upton Park.

The Croatian striker Davor Suker broke the deadlock just after the hour mark when he hit a left-foot volley after Frédéric Kanouté headed on a Paolo di Canio corner. And Di Canio made sure of the result six minutes from time, netting the rebound from his own retaken spot-kick.

Although Rovers left out a clutter of first-teamers and blooded the youngsters Darren Dunning and Marc Richards, in midfield and up front respectively, their Premiership hosts fielded a virtual first-choice side. Graeme Souness, denied the services of the cup-tied Mark Hughes, also chose to rest Craig Short, Craig Hignett and Henning Berg.

The Hammers will face either Sheffield Wednesday or Sheffield United in the next round.

Sunderland were pushed all the way by plucky Bristol Rovers at the Memorial Ground, with Don Hutchison grabbing the winner two minutes from time.

The Scottish midfielder had also put the Black Cats ahead three minutes into the second half.

Nathan Ellington got the home side back on level terms just after the hour only for Hutchison to have the final say as a 2-1 win set up a clash with Manchester United in the fourth round.

Tony Cottee looks set to be named as player-manager of Third Division Barnet today. The veteran striker has had his contract at Norwich City terminated by mutual consent. "I have been offered a player-management position and that is something which is right for me and something that I have wanted to do for the past three seasons," Cottee said.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Hartson horror for Boro
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 1 - 0 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Bryan Robson's grip on the Middlesbrough manager's job he has held for six years loosened still further here last night when a penalty six minutes from time gave Wimbledon a thoroughly deserved victory which sees them through to the fourth round.

A largely uninspiring tie had looked destined to be heading for extra time when John Hartson's deep cross was headed back across goal by Per Karlsson. To Robson's dismay the ball hit Curtis Fleming's arm and Hartson despatched the subsequent penalty.

Robson's side needed to concentrate on the league anyway to try to pull away from the bottom four in the Premiership. Their cause last night was not helped by the absence of Jon Harley, who is unavailable for cup duty while on loan from Chelsea. He was replaced by Karlsson, in one of two changes Terry Burton made from the side that drew 0-0 with Sheffield United at the weekend.

Before this game Robson had blamed his side's run of three successive defeats on a growing injury list. Of the nine senior players absent from Saturday's mauling at Portman Road, Gary Pallister returned last night while Joseph-Desire Job replaced Brian Deane, who suffered a head injury against Ipswich. The Croatian Alen Boksic, expected to return here, was nowhere to be seen.

His craft was sorely missed by Boro as Wimbledon, relishing a chance to cause an upset, harried their opponents from the off, fully aware of the brittle nature of Boro's confidence.

After four minutes, Gianluca Festa's ill-timed back-heel found Andy Roberts who fired narrowly wide and, within a minute, Boro's defence creaked again when Hartson's flick found Karlsson, the Swede also failing to find the target.

Middlesbrough eventually found a rhythm without ever striking the right cord. Job's volley was saved by Kelvin Davis and Noel Whelan's long-range volley flew narrowly over.

It was the Dons, however, who should have entered the interval ahead when Karlsson, clean through, was denied at close range by Mark Crossley.

On the hour, Neil Maddison, a substitute for Christian Karembeu, almost eased the manager's palpitations with the goal Boro's play scarcely deserved. His free-kick beat the wall but Davis acrobatically tipped it over.

Robson thought his luck might have been in when Dean Gordon hit the side netting, but still he could not breathe easily. His breath must have been truly taken away by Hatson's penalty.

Their cause last night was not helped by the absence of Jon Harley, who is unavailable for cup duty while on loan from Chelsea. He was replaced by Karlsson, in one of two changes Terry Burton made from the side that drew 0-0 with Sheffield United at the weekend. Before this game Robson had blamed his side's run of three successive defeats on a growing injury list. Of the nine senior players absent from Saturday's mauling at Portman Road, Gary Pallister returned last night while Joseph-Desire Job replaced Brian Deane, who suffered a head injury against Ipswich. The Croatian Alen Boksic, expected to return here, was nowhere to be seen. His craft was sorely missed by Boro as Wimbledon, relishing a chance to cause an upset, harried their opponents from the off, fully aware of the brittle nature of Boro's confidence. After four minutes, Gianluca Festa's ill-timed back-heel found Andy Roberts who fired narrowly wide and, within a minute, Boro's defence creaked again when Hartson's flick found Karlsson, the Swede also failing to find the target. Middlesbrough eventually found a rhythm without ever striking the right cord. Job's volley was saved by Kelvin Davis and Noel Whelan's long-range volley flew narrowly over. It was the Dons, however, who should have entered the interval ahead when Karlsson, clean through, was denied at close range by Mark Crossley. On the hour, Neil Maddison, a substitute for Christian Karembeu, almost eased the manager's palpitations with the goal Boro's play scarcely deserved. His free-kick beat the wall but Davis acrobatically tipped it over. Robson thought his luck might have been in when Dean Gordon hit the side netting, but still he could not breathe easily. His breath must have been truly taken away by Hatson's penalty.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Captain Ferguson stops the rot for Rangers
fields.standfirst: Miller 11, Ferguson 30
fields.trailText: Rangers 2 - 0 Dundee United
fields.body:
None of last night's fare was too heady for the 30,000 crowd but Rangers at least got what they had been praying for in this CIS League Cup quarter-final - a win. For Ibrox fans such treats have been severely rationed of late.

This was a desperate tangle between two teams whose morale and spirit had been visibly draining away. For Alex Smith and Dundee United the search for a cure continues, and they looked every inch a downtrodden team thoroughly perplexed within themselves.

But Rangers, with seven days to go before their crunch Champions League match against Monaco, needed this restorative, however feeble the opposition. Not for 20 years had the Glasgow giants endured such a horrendous run of results - in fact, not since a humiliating night in the 70s when they were removed by Chesterfield from the renowned Anglo-Scottish Cup.

Undistinguished victory it may have been but it was distinguished by yet another Ibrox fall from grace. There have been a few of these down the years, normally involving an episode with a woman or a bottle, but few so tied up with dressing-room revolt as yesterday's removal of the captaincy from Lorenzo Amoruso.

Months of posturing on the pitch, and blaming everyone else for every ill, finally took its toll on the morale of Amoruso's team-mates and the patience of his manager Dick Advocaat, who has handed the armband to Barry Ferguson. A disconsolate Amoruso trudged through this game as if his emperor's clothes had been swiped.

One win in seven matches prior to this was a ghoulish statistic for Advocaat, but his team were two up inside 30 minutes and happily coasting along. For the Ibrox faithful there was also the welcome sight of both Kenny Miller and Billy Dodds starting, two players Advocaat had omitted through, in the view of many, sheer bloody-mindedness.

Miller sprang Rangers into an 11th minute lead, latching onto Tugay's through pass with pace and haring towards Alan Combe before dispatching the ball behind him.

For United, things quickly got worse. Tugay, busy as ever, sent another skidding pass in between defenders and Ferguson, clearly relishing his new responsibilities as he penetrated United's box, met the ball in his stride before firing it low past Combe.

Rangers' best weapon was Miller's explosive pace. In an otherwise listless affair, time and again he turned his marker to hurtle towards Combe's box, usually leaving poor Jim Lauchlan flailing arms in his wake trying to stop the striker. One typically deft pass from Dodds released Miller into acres of space but his shot was hoisted over.

United managed one solitary near-miss, a shot from Mvondo Atangana that flew a yard above Jesper Christiansen's goal.

Rangers (4-4-2): Christiansen; Porrini, Wilson, Amoruso, Numan; Ricksen, Ferguson, Tugay, McCann; Dodds, Miller

Dundee United (4-4-2):Combe; Licina, De Vos, Lauchlan, Partridge; McQuillan, Buchan, Easton, Aljofree; Thompson, Venetis.

Referee: M McCurry.

fields.headline: Charity cases
fields.trailText: Credit cards may soon carry the organ donor symbol if an initiative from Goldfish takes off.
fields.body:
Credit cards may soon carry the organ donor symbol if an initiative from Goldfish takes off.

The credit card provider is writing to its one million-plus customers, inviting them to join the NHS Organ Donor Register and, from January 2001, apply for a new card with the donor symbol on it.

The move, which has the backing of the National Health System, aims to increase the number of people willing to donate organs and solve the country's chronic shortage. At present, over 6,000 people need organ transplants, but only around 3,000 operations take place every year, principally because of the organ shortage and because relatives do not know if the deceased would have wanted to be a donor.

Given that a credit card is one of the few items most people carry with them at all times, having a donor symbol on them is thought to be an ideal way of letting people know they wish to be a donor.

However, Goldfish also hopes to win new credit card customers by aligning itself with a worthy cause and, as such, the initiative is just the latest in a long line of charitable initiatives from financial service providers.

In fact, today sees the launch of two other such initiatives. Discount broker Cavendish Online says it will give customers the option of having their financial product's renewal commission donated to charity. And solicitors all over the country will be drafting wills for free throughout November. Clients pay £50 for a single will or £75 for a double one and the money is donated to charity.

Countless other charitable deals exist. Among the most common are affinity credit card deals, where a charity gets a certain amount, usually 25p for every £100 spent. But other financial service providers including, Halifax, Skipton building society and Newcastle building society, all have funds which donate a certain percentage to charity.

The trend looks set to increase. Wendy Green from the Charities Aid Foundation said cause-related marketing, as it is known in the industry, is moving away from just being affinity marketing of credit cards and taking on several other guises.

"It can be a bit of a minefield," she said, "But can also work very well. To succeed, the company needs to be doing something substantial to help the charity, not just using the name and logo to boost its image."

Sue Atkins, director of cause-based marketing at Business in the Community, an organisation which encourages links between companies and the communities they operate in, agrees.

"The area is diversifying and our research indicates that the public is supportive. In a recent survey, eight out of ten consumers said that if the price and quality of two products were the same, they would choose the one which donates to charity."

Unfortunately, price and quality may be the downfall of some products. Affinity credit cards, for example, frequently charge among the highest interest rates in the market. This puts customers off, especially at a time when the credit card market is competitive and headline grabbing rates of 4% or lower are being offered.

Goldfish charges 18.9% on purchases and 20.7% on cash advances - both among the more expensive rates on the market. Its introductory rate of 4.9% on balance transfers may tempt some people, but only time will tell if the price and quality of the card is enough to attract and keep new customers. After all, donor cards can be carried separately and people can always register direct with the Donor Agency.

fields.headline: Who you gonna call?
fields.standfirst:
A secretive new army of consultants is about to arrive from the US. Their mission: to help keep restless British workers in check. Diane Taylor enters the shadowy world of the union-busters

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A secretive new army of consultants is about to arrive from the US. Their mission: to help keep restless British workers in check. Diane Taylor enters the shadowy world of the union-busters.
fields.body:
The scene could be a call centre, a factory, a supermarket. The first signs of their presence in the workplace seem innocuous - comical even. There are the cutesy baseball caps bearing propagandising slogans, the gaudy leaflets, the "informative" videos made compulsory viewing for all staff and subtly peddling their message. There might - as happened at one major manufacturer in the US in recent months - be time off work for a company picnic, a lavish, feelgood away-day featuring speeches and presentations that seem to be slanted in a certain direction.

And then come the more sinister aspects: the hints that employees are being surreptitiously filmed at work; the workers "let go" in mysterious circumstances; the strangers at out-of-work gatherings pretending to be people they're not. By then, it should be clear: the union-busters - consul tants hired by employers to help them avoid or frustrate plans to organise unions in the workplace - have arrived. Their message to staff: organising a union would see salaries go into freefall and competitiveness take a battering, throwing the very survival of their company into doubt.

There are an estimated 10,000 anti-union consultants in the United States, many attached to law firms - and they are on their way to Britain. Demand for their services in this country is booming thanks to new employment legislation making it easier for unions to win recognition. Their pitch plays on the paranoia of senior managers, summoning images of the most notorious instances of union might: the winter of discontent, the miners' strike. And the first such company to cross the Atlantic, PTI Labor Research, is due to open an office in London any day now.

A specific date is a little harder to come by, since PTI, based in Houston, Texas, proves reluctant to return telephone calls, and certainly doesn't seem to be planning an all-singing, all-dancing opening ceremony. "The opening of PTI's London office hasn't officially been announced yet," a spokeswoman finally reveals, "but we'll know more in the next month or so."

It is just five months since the 1999 Employment Relations Act came into force, setting out regulations aimed at reintroducing compulsory procedures for union recognition for the first time since the 1980s. The new laws mean that recognition must follow if 40% of the relevant segment of a workforce votes in favour. Where union recognition laws are strongest, the consultants calculate, new business will be easiest to come by.

PTI's website gives few indications of how its British operation will function, explaining only that the company is already "advising UK companies on strategies for remaining union-free_ Due to the sensitive nature of our business, we ask that you contact us for further information". PTI partner Stuart Keene is understood to be in London for the forthcoming launch, but he can only be contacted through the Texas headquarters. Even there, he is not returning calls.

The firm has already been outlining its strategies to British managers. At a conference on employment law earlier this year organised by the UK law firm Eversheds, a PTI representative spoke on anti-union strategies before numerous employers, believed to include McDonald's, Gap and Tower Records. (Eversheds partner Roger Steel is anxious to distance his company from PTI, arguing, "If PTI did introduce the same tactics over here as they employ in the US, it would misjudge the mood.")

A leading anti-union law firm, Jackson Lewis Schnitzler and Krugman, which counts the US-based bookstore giant Borders among past clients, is also understood to be advising British businesses. In the US, Borders has been repeatedly involved in controversy for its anti-union campaigns, threatening to shut down bookshops where staff vote for recognition.

The union-busters will bring two decades of US experience to exploiting loopholes in the new British employment law, warns Carolyn Jones of the Institute for Employment Rights. "During the consultation period, we urged the government to adopt the European model of union recognition, which does more to safeguard workers' rights," she says. "We said, 'If you're really serious about strengthening unions and collective bargaining, don't go for laws based on the American system.' But they did."

Employers who panic at the prospect of union organisation can end up in self-defeating dead ends, says Kate Bronfenbenner, an expert on employment relations at Cornell University in New York state. "Sometimes a company which is barely solvent will end up paying tens of thousands of dollars to a union-buster - far more than it would ever have cost to negotiate with the union for better terms and conditions for staff," she says. "Union-busters see a good business opportunity in the UK: they're telling British employers that the unions will destroy their businesses, and that they are the one group of people who can protect them."

But the Trades Union Congress, having previously undertaken confidential investigations into the consultants' activities, now argues that British workplace culture will prove profoundly antipathetic to the American import. "Making it compulsory to wear a baseball cap won't go down well over here," a spokesman says firmly. "In fact, companies like PTI could be handing unions the best recruitment tool they've ever been given. In the UK, there's a significant union-friendly sector and only a small anti-union one, often in US-owned businesses. The new legislation is complex, and for those companies who don't want unions, good old-fashioned British bureaucracy is likely to be a more effective tool than Texans in baseball caps." The process involved in rejecting calls for recognition involves employers in an arduous process that requires them to canvass employees and seek a ruling from a central arbitration committee if negotiations break down.

But bureaucracy has also proved a useful tool for the anti-union consultants, according to Greg Tarpinian of the US union-backed Labor Research Association. "They will resort to any tactics, advising employers on specific legal strategies to deploy. In the US, it's illegal to fire a worker because they're involved in a union - but the penalties are so minimal that it's worth it. It can take up to 10 years through the courts to get people reinstated."

webTitle: Our top five cyber cinema picks

fields.headline: Our top five cyber cinema picks
fields.standfirst: Kate Stables picks her top five cyber shorts
fields.trailText: Kate Stables picks her top five cyber shorts
fields.body:
405
Think Duel, with a DC10. More than two million viewers have sought out this CGI-packed three minute action spectacular, where a Los Angeles commuter finds that one man's freeway is another man's runway.

George Lucas in Love
Can The Force save young George Lucas from flunking out of film school with writer's block? Will his villainous asthmatic rival triumph? Why is this the best of countless Star Wars parodies? Because it's got a light comic touch in an often leaden genre, it's packed with charming detail, and it's even funnier than that Princess Leia Danish-pastry hairdo.

Kleingeld (small change)
Because it was Oscar-nominated in 2000. Because it's never been out of the 'Highest Rated' chart since. Because it's in German without sub-titles, for heaven's sake. Because it's a small tragicomedy about human dignity which transcends language and nationality. Because you'll be glad you saw it

Undercover Brother
Screenwriter John Ridley (Three Kings) created this slick animated blaxploitation spoof series, whose claim to fame is as the first original web property to be acquired for a movie adaptation. Hipper than Shaft, smoother than Superfly, Undercover Brother takes on the Republican Party, the US TV networks, and anyone else who wants 'to get niggers off the golf courses and back into the cotton fields'.

Where my dog?
After they'd microwaved the gerbil and blended the frog, 900,000 visitors chose to give this hapless jeep-driving yokel some interactive help with a high-speed search for his delightful doggie. But who's that tethered to the fender?

webTitle: Working Lives: clothes shopping in the office

fields.headline: First floor: accounts, personnel, menswear
fields.standfirst:
No need to leave work to go clothes shopping - the stores are coming to your office, says Lucy Atkins

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: No need to leave work to go clothes shopping - the stores are coming to your office, says Lucy Atkins.
fields.body:
You walk into the conference room. But instead of a shiny table and bored employees, you find yourself in a shopper's pleasure dome: brushed-steel racks display rows of purple leather skirts, stylish jumpers and slinky trousers; shoppers caress suede boots, tended all the while by highly trained sales staff. The lights are soft. Music plays. No, you're not about to wake up: this is the next wave of workplace living - in-office shopping.

As is generally the way with such things, it is already happening in New York. A magical combination of marketing genius and an urge for corporate "team-building" last month brought Banana Republic, the US-based clothing company owned by Gap, into the offices of New York e-consulting firm Scient.

Scient employees are far too busy to get to the shops, but they need casual work clothes. Banana Republic, purveyors of smart, unimaginative clothes to people who don't want to stand out in a crowd, want customers. The logic is clear: if the customers can't go to the shop, the shop must go to the customers.

The clothier has sensed - quite rightly - that there is a market out there that is increasingly desperate for safe workwear that is not (God forbid!) a suit. For those given freedom to dress as they please at work, life is fraught with pitfalls. "Business casual," explains Cristina Gabriel of Banana Republic, "has lost its meaning. What to wear to work is a daily dilemma."

Scient was one of three companies picked to participate in this new retail enterprise. A place full of unappealing geeks in stained T-shirts, then? "Not at all," insists Wendi Sturgis, managing director of operations at Scient's New York office. "We're not terrible dressers: we just appreciated the innovative idea. It was a lot of fun."

The retailer set up a temporary store inside Scient's offices. Employees could browse through, try on and purchase a new but socially acceptable wardrobe. Of the company's 300 employees, well over half participated. (With a 20% discount, clothes delivered to your desk and free alterations, would you refuse?)

Is this really the future of shopping for the busy worker? Certainly, with more and more companies allowing us to slip into something more comfortable, the need for "smart casual" is greater than ever before. And those who are too busy to shop could probably do with a little help.

However, if in-office clothes shopping does take off, the originality-killing spread of a smart-casual uniform becomes an even more likely prospect. And where's the fun in that?

A "casual uniform", on the other hand, does have its benefits from a management perspective. Evidence is beginning to trickle in that the wearing of any clothes we wish at work encourages us to behave rather badly. And uniformity is comforting. This way, at least, you're not going to get fired because of your Gap khakis - provided you keep them done up.
fields.bodyText: You walk into the conference room. But instead of a shiny table and bored employees, you find yourself in a shopper's pleasure dome: brushed-steel racks display rows of purple leather skirts, stylish jumpers and slinky trousers; shoppers caress suede boots, tended all the while by highly trained sales staff. The lights are soft. Music plays. No, you're not about to wake up: this is the next wave of workplace living - in-office shopping. As is generally the way with such things, it is already happening in New York. A magical combination of marketing genius and an urge for corporate "team-building" last month brought Banana Republic, the US-based clothing company owned by Gap, into the offices of New York e-consulting firm Scient. Scient employees are far too busy to get to the shops, but they need casual work clothes. Banana Republic, purveyors of smart, unimaginative clothes to people who don't want to stand out in a crowd, want customers. The logic is clear: if the customers can't go to the shop, the shop must go to the customers. The clothier has sensed - quite rightly - that there is a market out there that is increasingly desperate for safe workwear that is not (God forbid!) a suit. For those given freedom to dress as they please at work, life is fraught with pitfalls. "Business casual," explains Cristina Gabriel of Banana Republic, "has lost its meaning. What to wear to work is a daily dilemma." Scient was one of three companies picked to participate in this new retail enterprise. A place full of unappealing geeks in stained T-shirts, then?
