fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst:
An employment tribunal lawyer writes

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: An employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
I am starting to wonder why every case I do under the Disability Discrimination Act seems to turn on the question of whether the applicant has a disability at all. I begin to think that there are two kinds of lawyer in the world - proper lawyers doing cases involving people in wheelchairs and the blind, and joke lawyers doing cases involving people with obsessive paperclip bending disorder or internet pornography downloading compulsion. Or maybe it's just me doing these cases?

This week I am representing an accountancy firm. The applicant is an accountant who resigned from her job because she suffers from what her expert witness describes as "acute anxiety about her work performance". I am sure this is very nasty.

Although I am now old and battle-hardened, there was a time when I used to drink a large bottle of beer before a careless driving case to overcome my terror of being responsible for someone's licence being endorsed. It didn't help that I couldn't drive and was convinced that one day some technical issue would arise about carburettors that would expose me as a know-nothing fraud, or that someone would spot the words "nearside" and "offside" Biroed on my hands.

What is hard to understand about this case is exactly how the applicant is "disabled" by her anxiety and what she wanted the firm to do about it.

Expert: "Well, she wouldn't be able to work at all if she had to work to any sort of deadline."

Me: "So she would be allowed to do work at any pace she wished?"

Expert: "Yes."

Me: "Even if, for example, some accounts were actually due, so that tax could be calculated and paid?"

Expert: "I can't comment on that. I am not an expert accountant."

Me: "You also said that she would not be able to function if any criticism were made of her work?"

Expert: "Well, any comment at all would have that effect, whether positive or negative."

Me: "So the firm would never be able to appraise her work in any way?"

Expert: "It's not for me to say how the employer should have adjusted the job."

We never get to the stage when the tribunal has to decide whether the applicant has a disability because, having oozed tears all morning while her expert gives evidence, she disappears at lunchtime and never comes back. The accountants look glum as we shake hands, and I can't blame them. No one has won this case. An unhappy woman has made herself more unhappy, and the accountants have spent a lot of money on irrecoverable legal costs. Sometimes I miss those old careless driving cases.

fields.headline: Light
fields.standfirst:
Almeida, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Almeida, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
In the past Complicite have found a rich source in the work of unfamiliar European writers, most famously in Bruno Schultz's The Street of Crocodiles. But their latest work, Light, derives from a novel by Torgny Lindgren about a plague-infested 14th-century Swedish village. As always, the company's physical skill is prodigious; but in this instance I found it placed at the service of a story lacking in metaphorical resonance.

I guess the intention is to explore a society poised between order and anarchy. One day a traveller returns to the remote village of Kadis with a plague-carrying rabbit. The villagers drop like flies. The corpses mount up. Among the tiny handful of survivors, a carpenter, Konik, and his temporarily paralysed wife, Eira, struggle to live decent lives. But they are surrounded by inbreeding, bestiality, theft: even their child is stolen from them. And when a king's deputy arrives he offers less the promised clarity and light than the darkness of perverse misjudgment: it is left to the villagers to reconstruct their own community through a mixture of chance and choice.

Clearly the story is an allegorical fable in the style of William Golding: one that deals with isolated individuals in an extreme situation. But, although our own world is hardly immune to viral infection and the adaptation by Simon McBurney and Matthew Broughton establishes a firm narrative line, I found it hard to connect to the story. We are confronted by a remote peasant society that has a residual faith in divine providence and in the notion of regal justice up to the point where the king's man threatens to hang a child-eating boar: fascinating historically but of questionable modern relevance. Even the tension between law and disorder that exists in this supposedly microcosmic community seems worlds away from the kind of mobilised selfishness that threatens our own stability.

One is left admiring the skill with which the company, under McBurney's direction, reconstructs a lost world. Dick Bird's curving, wood-planked set implies a vast hidden burial ground. Scaly, scabbed puppets become corpses or children. Columns of light - created by Paul Anderson - at one point evoke a forest. And the actors show the burning commitment that derives from their being part of the creative process. Tim McMullan's Konik is a wonderful study of naive decency struggling to survive in a disintegrating world. Lilo Baur's Eira is the incarnation of maternal love. And Dermot Kerrigan switches easily from linen-suited narrator to tormented regal emissary. But, for me, this is one of those rare Complicite shows where the formidable expressive technique is put to the service of an opaque parable: one that dauntingly implies that you have to accept plagues, as well as plenty, as evidence of an ambivalent divinity.

 Until November 18. Box office: 020-7359 4404.

fields.headline: Universal Ballet
fields.standfirst:
Sadler's Wells, London
Rating:***
fields.trailText:
Sadler's Wells, London
Rating:***
fields.body:
Giselle is famously a ballet in two halves. The first takes place in sunshine; the second is bathed in moonlight. The first is peopled by peasants; the second is haunted by ghosts. Many ballerinas, just as famously, dance one act more credibly than another - some winning their audience with the gentle realism of their acting in the first act, others shining in the palely exquisite choreography of the second.

When Universal Ballet danced Giselle on Monday night, however, we saw a whole company present the same division: the ensemble was oddly unconvincing in the first act but confidently commanding in the second.

There is no single stylistic or national explanation for this split. Universal Ballet may be based in Seoul, but during the company's brief and bizarre history (it was founded in 1984 by the Rev Sun Myung Moon as a showcase for his dead son's fiancee, the dancer Julia H Moon) it has absorbed an international variety of influences. Its core of Asian dancers has been supplemented by Russians and Americans, and its current director is Oleg Vinogradov, who was for more than 20 years director of the Kirov.

It is thus not a purely Korean Giselle which is up for discussion, rather a non-British one. In the UK we like our dancers to act as an ensemble - remaining in character even when they aren't centre stage and aiming for the kind of collective spontaneity that allows us to believe the ballet is unfolding here and now, rather than being a nightly ritual. The members of Universal Ballet, whose acting is perfunctory and expression highly stylised, don't even attempt a realistic telling of the story, which is why much of the first act, with its village gaiety and its growing tensions between Giselle's two suitors, seems cardboard.

Yet in the more abstract second act, the startling discipline of the company's corps de ballet and its shimmering fusion of Russian and Asian lyricism makes us sit up and take notice. The eerie symmetries of the Wilis' dancing, the cobwebs in which they trap duplicitous men, are so finely drawn that the dancers look as if they have graduated from one of the old European schools. At their centre is Julia Moon, who absolutely ranks as a major Giselle.

The delicate impassivity of Moon's face in the first act is disconcerting - she seems like a Giselle from a Noh play - and this certainly doesn't help the overall stiltedness of the company's acting. Yet from the moment she starts dancing there is such a febrile interplay of nuance and rhythm in her body that we sense rather than see how fatally her passion for Albrecht is intensifying and how inevitably it will rip her apart. In the second act, though a foot injury may account for some slight lethargy in Moon's jumping, the eloquence of her phrasing and the airborne lightness of her arms make her seem transparent. Jae-Won Hwang as her Albrecht has style and stamina but lacks the technical magnificence to justify his overinflated posturing as the tragic hero.

In rep until Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

fields.headline: Philharmonia/Sawallisch
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/Sawallisch
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia/Sawallisch
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
An emblem of Victorian self-confidence and a beloved party piece of choral societies across the land, Mendelssohn's oratorio Elijah is almost as ubiquitous a landmark of British musical life as Handel's Messiah. Just like the modern monarchy, these Germanic imports have been subsumed into the fabric of national identity. So any professional, 21st-century performance of Elijah carries a unique burden of received opinions and performance practices: the work's aura of genteel respectability threatens continually to overwhelm Mendelssohn's musical achievement.

Wolfgang Sawallisch's account with the Philharmonia Orchestra - the opening concert of a Mendelssohn mini-series - was an object lesson in how to sustain and refresh an overfamiliar masterpiece. Without self-conscious histrionics or hollow interpretative shocks, Sawallisch stripped away layers of reception history to reveal Elijah's essentially dramatic core.

Far from a reverential wallow, Sawallisch turned Elijah into a narrative of operatic vividness. Most obviously in the work's dialogues, such as between Simon Keenlyside's Elijah and Barbara Bonney's Widow, Sawallisch brought the variety of Mendelssohn's recitative and arioso writing to life. But throughout, it was Sawallisch's rhythmic characterisation that made every number a component in a powerfully involving drama.

The Philharmonia Chorus responded enthusiastically to Sawallisch's expertly shaped phrasing. In their roles as the narrator of the story, the idolatrous priests of Baal, and the devotees of Elijah's true Lord, they conjured an epic range of colours and dynamics. The pedantic galumphing of Mendelssohn's music for the followers of false gods was gleefully characterised by the singers. The contrast with the scene in which God's fire descends was made all the more telling: the chorus became rapt followers of Elijah's God, in one of Mendelssohn's most sincerely felt chorales.

With the support of Sawallisch and the chorus, the nine soloists - a double quartet with boy soprano Timothy Hegarty - had the firmest of musical foundations. Keenlyside and Bonney were the highlights, as his heartfelt, human Elijah was complemented by the reflective concentration of her solos. Christoph Prégardien's tenor and mezzo-soprano Katharina Kammerloher were soft-toned and thoughtful, while Gail Pearson's Angel and Iain Paton's Ahab, from the second quartet, were outstanding.

webTitle: Working Lives: Tricks of the trade

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sarah Barnes, 39 sales director
fields.body:
Sarah Barnes, 39 sales director

I found out that the company I worked for was offering bribes to overseas clients to keep their business. I had to work with one customer who liked money to be paid into accounts abroad before he would do business. As soon as he mentioned a payout I refused to deal with him. I went to my manager and asked him to support me. Of course, my boss couldn't tell me to bribe the client because he knew it was illegal, and we lost the business. My actions were seen as naive at the time, but I would still react the same way. It weakens your hand if you rely on something other than your sales skills to clinch a deal.

Patricia Stevenson, 29 PR executive

I used to work for a publicity agency where one executive was stealing press samples and selling them to her friends. She'd been there for a long time and was quite brazen about it. I was frustrated that my boss turned a blind eye: if a client queried anything, he would say samples had been lost. Eventually I told him that if he didn't confront her I would tell the clients myself. I did this because I thought what she was doing was wrong and because I didn't want to be seen to be working for a shoddy company. When my boss confronted her she was so affronted that she left. I think it's important to blow the whistle on someone in a situation like that, especially if you think the company would be better off without them.

Steven Collins, 31 IT consultant

In a former job, a colleague used to make comments about a gay workmate behind his back. Eventually my gay colleague found out what was going on but couldn't act on it without evidence. I offered to write him a report, which was read out at a disciplinary hearing. Only my line manager and my colleague knew I had written it, but it was still a risk. I don't regret it at all. I think you have to act on your morals at work, but only if there is a established route for dealing with a grievance.

Sarah Collins, 46 telecommunications manager

In my last job I found out that a male colleague on the same level as me was earning a higher salary. I challenged my boss, who basically told me I could leave if I wasn't happy. My union representative said he could take my case to a tribunal. After six months of correspondence between myself, the union rep and my boss, I got a pay rise. It was so important to me to sort this out - it was bad practice, and adversely affected my self-esteem at work.

Karen Wilson, 25 PR executive

I used to work in an office where my boss bullied a junior executive. He singled her out and complained about her work and intimidated her if she was late, but let others off the hook. Once I found her crying and she said she was on the point of leaving. She wouldn't complain to head office, so I did. I told one of our directors, who went straight to my boss and confronted her. He was furious and so was the junior. What was worse, they both denied the situation and turned against me. Luckily I'd been job hunting in the build-up to all this and was offered a new position a couple of weeks after the incident. My advice? If you blow the whistle on someone, be prepared to suffer the consequences.

 Interviews by Cayte Williams

fields.headline: Ronan Keating works hard at winning over the mums
fields.standfirst:
Ronan Keating
Royal Albert Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Ronan Keating
Royal Albert Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
At 23, Ronan Keating is "can-do" theory made flesh. Acknowledging no limits, he finds he can be anything - TV presenter, boyband heart-throb, co-manager of Westlife, and now a solo artist aiming to levitate himself gradually into the adult-pop bracket. He isn't a great songwriter, and his voice is puzzlingly unmemorable, but he is brimming with self-belief and he works his socks off.

Still, admitting that he deserves his success isn't the same as adoring his work. It didn't help that the Albert Hall had been made to resemble a shambolic TV studio, with video cameras ringing the auditorium, cameramen crawling around the back of the stage, and a couple of giant camera booms see-sawing over the crowd. If the punters (mostly teenage girls, you'll be amazed to hear) had not been so gaga at the mere sight of Ronan taking off his jacket or wiggling his bottom, it might have occurred to them to demand a refund for being lumbered with a restricted view. Doubtless the tour video will be on sale in time for Christmas.

Somehow, Ronan has always been middle-aged, as if he started designing his brilliant career when he was still gurgling in his pram. A lot of his material, particularly the soupy ballads like In This Life or When the World Was Mine, makes Des O'Connor sound like Eminem. As a sex symbol, too, the boy Keating seems worryingly smooth and harmless. Even though the girls know they are supposed to scream at him, their hearts aren't really in it, and when he left the stage they meekly stood up, put on their coats and left.

But credit where it's due. For his debut solo disc, Keating shrewdly recruited grizzled old songwriting veterans such as Diane Warren, Bryan Adams and Pat Leonard to supply some ballast, and tunes such as Life Is a Rollercoaster and When You Say Nothing At All have that air of predestination about them that only the practised pop hack can supply. During the encores, Ronan plugged into his Irish roots by duetting with Maire Brennan on Fairy Tale of New York and rocking out (albeit cautiously) on Whiskey in the Jar. For a finale he delivered the ponderous The Long Goodbye. He co-wrote it with Paul Brady, but it might easily have been churned out by a software program designed to clone adult-orientated megaballads. Ronan has already grabbed the daughters. Now he is after their mums.

 Ronan Keating is at the Brighton Centre (0870-900 9100), tonight, then tours.

Acknowledging no limits, he finds he can be anything - TV presenter, boyband heart-throb, co-manager of Westlife, and now a solo artist aiming to levitate himself gradually into the adult-pop bracket. He isn't a great songwriter, and his voice is puzzlingly unmemorable, but he is brimming with self-belief and he works his socks off. Still, admitting that he deserves his success isn't the same as adoring his work. It didn't help that the Albert Hall had been made to resemble a shambolic TV studio, with video cameras ringing the auditorium, cameramen crawling around the back of the stage, and a couple of giant camera booms see-sawing over the crowd. If the punters (mostly teenage girls, you'll be amazed to hear) had not been so gaga at the mere sight of Ronan taking off his jacket or wiggling his bottom, it might have occurred to them to demand a refund for being lumbered with a restricted view. fields.headline: Yallery Brown
fields.standfirst:
Yallery Brown
Greenwich Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Yallery Brown
Greenwich Theatre, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
The Wellingborough and Kettering Film Society is holding one of its occasional midnight film presentations in a theatre that is shortly to be turned into a multi-storey car park. After the trailer for the forthcoming The Killer Tomatoes, it's on to the main feature, The Phantom Gobstopper, a 1901 silent horror classic by Gunter Von Earwig. Things take a turn for the terrifying when the film starts to go wrong. Gloria the popcorn-fixated usherette steps through the screen, and a 19th-century factory worker, possessed by a restless, tormented spirit from beyond the grave, steps out.

The first 10 minutes of this collaboration between Forkbeard Fantasy, whose surreal and dotty attempts to mix film and theatre began long before such ideas were fashionable, and writer Sean Aita, is so funny, spooky and inventive that the show seemed destined to become a theatre classic for family audiences. Unfortunately, the first 10 minutes is as good as it gets in an evening that turns into a cross between RL Stine's Goosebumps series and a lecture on the power of the imagination and storytelling.

Aita mines a good comedy-horror vein, with plenty of groan-creating moments of the "There's no 'arm in it" variety when a character appears to lose a limb. Throughout, the special effects and the giant puppets have a brilliant over-the-top tackiness. There is beauty too: at one magical moment a miniature ship appears to float across the stage as if in the dream of a dying man.

But for all its visual appeal, the show is let down by writing that's never sharp enough to be a spoof on the appalling writing of the horror genre, and it lacks any depth or subtext. Audibility is also sometimes a problem. For such a simple story, in which the powers of evil must be defeated by recalling a story from childhood, coherence is an unexpected problem, and the audience participation is much too childish for an audience that is more sophisticated and more open to real substance than perhaps Aita realises.

The cast perform with larky high spirits and, as ever, Forkbeard Fantasy amaze with the clever way they operate at the interface of theatre and film. But while this is good fun, it is not nearly fun enough to turn young people on to theatre.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-8858 7755.

fields.headline: Closer
fields.standfirst:
Library Theatre, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Library Theatre, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
In the three years since it first appeared, Patrick Marber's viciously funny play has become a modern classic, picking up a batch of awards while continuing to shock audiences with its candid look at lust and infidelity. Chris Honer's sharp production features a post-industrial set of pillars and slats that looks like the downstairs bar in the now-defunct Hacienda down the road. Indeed, this is theatre for the clubbing generation, and the between-set music and video graphics would work as well in any chill-out room. This streetwise edge may give the play a young urban credibility, but the strength of the writing is such that the context is not as important as it first seems. Even the hilarious internet-sex scene feels timeless.

Marber's lines have all the urgency and spit of a stand-up routine, but allied to this fervour is a deep awareness of how people relate to each other. Closer is all about people coming together and coming apart, and we see the often desperate first meetings and always desperate endings of all four characters' relationships. Emma Cleasby catches nicely the childlike sarcasm and sneer of Alice, the play's siren and cipher, "the belle of the bullshit", who undergoes more transformations than any other character: from street-kid casual to evening-gown elegance to gold-lamé lap-dancer and pyjama-clad girl. Perhaps, though, Cleasby's delivery is a little muffled beneath Alice's shifting insecurities.

Closer asks if love is anything more than narcissism and the need for reassurance. And when you consider the men in the play you would have to say no. Julian Protheroe, as obituary writer Dan, gives a fine performance, at first all clean heels and assertiveness but soon reduced to blubbering and hitting out.

As the quartet's love lives become ever more despairing and entangled, the power oscillates between the needy and the needed until you're not too sure who's manipulating who. Christian Burgess is excellent as the suave doctor, Larry, whose insecurity is easily piqued, while Julie Riley is equally assured as the sophisticated Anna, perhaps the only character not to unravel altogether . By the end of the play, you're sure to feel exhausted, enlightened and a little relieved. But then breaking up is hard to do.

Until November 25. Box office: 0161-236 7110.
